PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap can be terminated from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) Notice be given by 19 October 1986 that the Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated by October 1987.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasiblity of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights because:
The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as:
The right to own your own home and other property and not to be deprived of it without just compensation.
The right to insulate our children from radical forms of education and the right to choice of schools.
The right to a referendum for constitutional amendments.
The right to true freedom of speech.
The Bill gives dangerous, unlimited powers to an unelected Human Rights Commission with no appeal, no legal representation and closed hearings.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote to reject the Bill, believing that such a Bill should only be determined by the people at a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am pleased to announce that the first set of Resource Agreements in the field of education between the Commonwealth, all the States and non-government school system authorities has now been successfully concluded to the satisfaction of all concerned. These Resource Agreements represent a major Commonwealth initiative in funding for schools. In the first major policy statement on education after we came to office-the funding guidelines issued to the Commonwealth Schools Commission in July 1983-I declared that the Commonwealth in future would be determined to establish firm education objectives, to set clear priorities and to focus on the achievement of educational outcomes. We are committed to concentrating our funding and our policies on the key goals of improving outcomes, enhancing performance and raising quality. To this end, the Government requested studies by the Schools Commission and by the Quality of Education Review Committee to review existing Commonwealth funding arrangements. These studies have dealt with arrangements for general resources funding, new non-government schools funding policies, enhanced accountability arrangements and a comprehensive review of the Commonwealth's specific purpose programs for schools.

SPEECH.PARA: In August 1984 I announced the Government's new eight-year general recurrent funding scheme. That scheme provided significant increases in financial resources for government and non-government schools, giving all school systems a stable basis on which to plan and ending the unduly divisive and unduly prolonged debate over State aid. At the same time, I indicated that the additional funds to be allocated to schools by the Commonwealth would be provided on the basis of resource agreements which would in turn be negotiated with the States and non-government school authorities. These agreements are an essential mechanism in the achievement of our goals to set national objectives and improve educational outcomes.
The Government set four basic priorities for funding under the resource agreements. They concern:
the importance of primary education, and particularly junior primary, as a foundation for future learning;
the need to raise participation in years 11 and 12 by disadvantaged groups;
the importance of expanding representation and attainment of girls in major subject areas; and
assistance for teachers to bring about the necessary improvements.

The Commonwealth Government does not directly supervise school administration, except in the Australian Capital Territory. Detailed administrative arrangements for balancing and implementing change in our priority areas have therefore been left to the school systems themselves.

When the concept of resource agreements was first mooted, it was feared in some quarters that the Commonwealth would intrude on the constitutional rights of the States and the autonomy of non-government school systems. Those fears have proved groundless. All States and systems have signed agreements. Genuine co-operation has been achieved, with State and non-government school system authorities proposing general activities for inclusion in the agreements which are consistent with Commonwealth priority areas as well as addressing specific problems in local systems within the priorities set by us. Initiatives costing $37m will be covered by the resource agreements for 1986. The money spent-taxpayers' money-will be better directed and better accounted for. All of us will gain from our decisions to target resources and set priorities. For example, a number of school systems are using resource agreement funds to improve the teaching of literacy in the early school years by maximising access of junior primary school teachers to the early literacy in-service course, which helps them develop the necessary attitudes, knowledge and skills. Another approach has been to improve number and language skills amongst primary and secondary students through the use of consultants to assist schools in following up diagnostic testing in these areas. These initiatives are consistent with the Government's view, based on advice from QERC, that real improvements in the quality of educational outcomes depend in the long run on ensuring that students move into secondary school having already achieved a high level of proficiency in the basic competences.

Another system is improving the general competence-and hence participation-amongst disadvantaged groups through specialised support for intellectually handicapped students, focusing on behavioural adjustment, appropriate work experience and integration into normal settings to ensure that competences are developed as a normal part of daily living; support for an Aboriginal education unit to provide more relevant experience in schools for Aboriginal students; enhancing relevant, direct learning experiences for isolated rural students through projects within the satellite communication trials; and supporting the role of the equal opportunities officer. This, of course, is also of special importance in promoting more equal representation and attainment of girls in major subject areas.

We are encouraging all systems to concentrate on improving outcomes, not just to demand more inputs into the education systems, whether those inputs take the form of more staff, more money or more specific purpose programs. For instance, one school authority has identified as an area for action the lack of assistance for teachers encountering students who are not learning satisfactorily and who sometimes show behavioural problems as well. This lack of assistance has been most evident in primary schools serving areas with high concentrations of children from deprived socio-economic backgrounds, backgrounds where English is not the first language, or from Aboriginal families. This school authority has decided to use funds made available under the resource agreement to provide additional guidance officers to identify the extent of each referred child's difficulties, and to work with the child, teachers and parents in devising a management strategy. Outcomes anticipated by the system include improvements in the general competences amongst referred children; improved student behaviour resulting in reduced absenteeism and less need for serious disciplinary action; and, in the longer term, increased post-compulsory school participation by members of disadvantaged groups. The authority will monitor these outcomes in order to assess the effectiveness of the initiative. This authority will also be using some resource agreement funds specifically to develop broadly based indicators of system effectiveness.

The Government welcomes this approach. Commonwealth funding has been targeted in such a way that relatively small sums can make a significant contribution to improved educational outcomes in the longer term. Further, the desired outcomes have been made explicit. This, if after an appropriate time the desired improvements are not evident, the system is in a good position to vary its policy response to the original problem. In other words, under the outcomes approach, we can no longer accept on faith that increased resources lead automatically to better educational outcomes. Nor can anyone sit back complacently and assume that because additional money has been spent, an identified problem will now go away. We can now account for the money we spend and monitor progress towards the goals we seek in the context of strict restraint on expenditures. We must insist that our education spending be fully disciplined, tightly managed, and directed to our wider national objectives.

A major policy objective of the Government is the pursuit of more equal group outcomes of education. For the first time, the Commonwealth will have access to information on the extent to which this goal is being achieved. As part of the resource agreements, all States and non-government school systems have agreed to provide to the Commonwealth information to allow it to monitor trends within each system in post-compulsory school retention by groups who have traditionally been disadvantaged in education. These include those of low socio-economic status, those of non-English speaking background, rural students and Aboriginals. School authorities will also provide to the Commonwealth information on post-compulsory subject choice by girls as well as available information on student attainment in relevant areas.
Once again, our plans to increase equity and efficiency are being developed congruently and systematically. All students will benefit from this approach. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ministerial statement which has been brought down by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) is apparently a statement about resource agreements. It is, in fact, much more than that. It is a statement which has to do with the proper distribution of power between the Commonwealth and the States. It is a paper that has to do with ideology in education and it is a paper that has to do with control over educational activity in Australia by a level of government which lacks the constitutional power properly to exercise that control.
—What a load of codswallop!

—It is absolutely correct. The Government has a lot of interest in a style of government. We operate under a constitution which apportions power and functions between different levels of government. The educational function in this country is only a Commonwealth function insofar as it refers to benefits for students. That is the only legitimate power which the Commonwealth has. Education is otherwise a function which is part of the remaining residual plenary power of the States of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt, when one looks at this document, that the Government is moving to intrude further and further into a control over education by the States and within the States. These resource agreements represent one stage in that movement. The Government makes no secret of its intention to use the power of the purse to control education and educational activity in Australia. I remind honourable senators, if they have forgotten, that Senator Boswell asked the Minister, Senator Ryan, a question on 9 April, about one month ago. I will read the question and part of the answer given by Senator Ryan because the answer indicates quite clearly the extent to which this Government is prepared to go in threatening educational institutions and in laying down the extent to which it expects educationalists in Australia to be responsive not only to what they see as academically necessary but also to what they see as the policy of the Government. The question asked by Senator Boswell was part of a series of questions about certain research into the Star Wars or strategic defence initiative of the United States of America. Senator Boswell asked:
Will the Minister give a guarantee that the Government will not seek to prevent universities and other tertiary institutions from becoming involved in aspects of the SDI program?
That was a perfectly simple question. Senator Ryan, in her answer, said that some of the features had been outlined already by other Ministers, but she then went on to say:
As far as we are aware no universities are engaging directly in SDI research and as universities operate within government policy we do not expect that they will.

That is what she said. It was not an assertion about the administrative function of universities. Senator Ryan was asserting that, because the Commonwealth funds the universities, they operate within government policy and that there should follow some limitation on the exercise of academic freedom or the freedom to take up or not take up any kind of academic pursuit which is seen to be appropriate.

We think that answer by Senator Ryan was not only a disgraceful answer and a disgraceful intrusion into the freedom which should apply to tertiary institutions in Australia but also a clear indication of the road which this Government is travelling and of which this statement today is one part. It has to do with a style of government, it has to do with the ideology behind the Government's activities and it has to do with the desire of this Labor Government, which is in so much trouble in many ways, to bring increasing centralisation of power into education. We know that already in other areas. We have seen the effective centralisation of power within the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. We have seen that the power now rests firmly in the hands of the Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. We have seen the abolition of much of the advisory apparatus that operated so well for a number of years. We are concerned that what is being presented to the Parliament today in the guise of agreed resource agreements represents one more stage--

TALK.START.PARA: —You voted against our amendment on that.

—We voted on that legislation on the totality of our consideration, but we were very much aware of what Senator Ryan was attempting to do to centralise power. We agreed with Senator Macklin in his concern. I come back to what the Minister's statement is trying to lay down. The States have had to agree to do certain things if they wish to continue to receive Commonwealth money in an area which is constitutionally theirs and not the Commonwealth's. People should be aware that there is increasing intrusion by the Hawke Labor Government into educational activities which are properly those of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: We agree with the Minister that certain outcomes of education need to be improved. I agree with the rhetoric in her statement in which she referred to the need for approved outcomes. We do not agree that the pursuit of better educational outcomes should necessarily involve equality of outcomes. Once again the Minister was talking about equality of group outcomes. We must produce generally better outcomes and improve the resources available to disadvantaged groups to improve equality of opportunity in education. This is one of the value questions which will continue to be asked. We are concerned too about the misstatement of facts which continues to be part of the rhetoric of this Government and which annoys people who are taking part in education and contributing so much to it.

The Minister talks about the `historic settlement' on non-government schools. She was able to end the basic grants that have been available to every Australian child so that today some children in schools receive no Commonwealth support whereas previously every child received some. That is one of Senator Ryan's educational achievements. An historic settlement! An historic settlement indeed! That settlement will exclude some children. We now have a rigid policy which restricts the emergence of new schools and the approval for new schools to obtain Commonwealth funding. The accountability provisions, whatever their merits, are the thin end of the wedge of increasing Commonwealth control.

About the time the Minister brought down the States grants Bills in November 1985 the list of new schools approved for funding was made public. The first problem was that many of the new schools were not new. We were concerned that many schools which had existed for years were forced to go through the new schools assessment procedure merely because they had relocated to a new campus, perhaps only a few doors away, or had extended their range of offerings by increasing their classes from, for example, year 6 to year 10 or 12. One wonders how Radford College in the Australian Capital Territory will end up. If a school had gone from being a single sex to a co-educational school it had to go through the new school procedure. Instead of making it easy for those who wish to offer education to get support, the Minister has done all she can to make it difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —Responsible.

—The Minister says that that is responsible. I say she is making it more difficult. We are aware of many schools which have established themselves and set up a campus and have then been told by the Labor Government that they will not receive any funding. The Minister has set out to entrench educational monopoly whether it be the monopoly of existing government schools or of existing government and non-government schools. The Minister has laid down that one of the factors which should diminish the right of a new school to funding is if there is already adequate provision in a region. We say: So what? We believe that extra provision means extra choice. When the Minister brought down her list, we had the example of the Maronite Christian school in Parramatta, Our Lady of Lebanon at Harris Park. It wanted to extend its primary school into the secondary area so that Lebanese children who had been through the primary sector of that school could continue their secondary schooling there, but no extra recurrent funding funds were provided.
—Wrong. It has been approved.

—Ah, the Minister was forced on appeal to reverse the decision. That is the other point. That school and the Armenian school in Terrey Hills were refused funding initially. Only when they appealed were they able to get funding. To make my point clear again, the Government is intent on making it more difficult for schools such as these to get recurrent funding to educate Australian children. We are concerned at what this Government has done and at the misstatements of fact which have characterised the Minister's public comments. She wrote a letter to the Bulletin magazine on 19 November 1985 in which she claimed: In fact, there has been no sudden change in our funding policies. I suppose it all depends on what one means by the word `sudden', but there certainly have been major changes in the Governments funding policies. I come back to providing a basic grant for every child in every school.
—That was never our policy.

—There has been a sudden change in funding policies for Australian schools. The Minister now makes it clear that she says merely that she has not changed direction. I point out to the educational establishment that it knows that educational funding policy and direction have changed and that rights which it previously enjoyed have been removed under the stewardship of Senator Susan Ryan.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister went on to say that, far from feeling uncomfortable about the new funding mechanisms, they were welcomed by every major non-government school organisation. I read the statements from the major non-government school organisations. They were the most careful and lukewarm statements I have seen. From myriads of schools I have received howls of complaints that they have been treated unfairly. The Minister might as well know that many parents and schools believe that they are not getting a fair go. If these resource agreements are further evidence of the Government's moving in to control an area which it does not have constitutionally, to intrude further into an area properly under State authority, to make it more difficult for people to offer educational opportunities and to help their fellow citizens, we will have little of it. This resource agreements paper represents clear evidence of further Commonwealth intrusion into educational areas under State control. I have no doubt that the institutions signed because they were probably given the choice of signing or doing without the money. The Minister is succeeding in increasing Commonwealth power, ramming home her ideology and increasing her control. The answer the Minister gave to Senator Boswell made it clear that she expects universities, in choosing their research priorities, to regard themselves as being instruments of government policy. Let me state again what the Minister said: As universities operate within government policy, the Government does not expect that they will engage in any SDI research. That represents the gravest breach of and the gravest threat to academic freedom of anything I have heard over the last few years, even from this Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has put down refers to ongoing discussions between the Commonwealth and State governments over funding, particularly at the primary school level, but also in terms of a number of ongoing Commonwealth programs for the disadvantaged. I am tempted to respond to some of the points Senator Peter Baume made but I am not quite sure whether I should. The criticisms that I have of the Government go to the facts of the matter; that is, that this Government has abandoned its policy with regard to government and private school funding. In fact, private schools in Australia are now funded at a higher level than they have ever been funded under Liberal-National Party governments. That is my concern. When I look at the actual figures, not only in dollar terms but also in percentage terms, I find it passing strange that the decisions made by the Government, in terms of its eight-year commitment, to put money into the private school sector have corralled its ability to look at a diversity of educational possibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back even further. I remember that when Senator Baume was Minister for Education the comments he made in this chamber referred very clearly to the fact that there was only one educational cake, that there was a certain amount of money to go around and, really, the question was not how it was to be divided. Senator Baume would probably get very loud applause if he carefully chose his words and talked to the teachers unions, because the teachers unions are not very happy with the Government's policy either. But theirs is the opposite viewpoint: They see the government school sector being disadvantaged in the amounts of money which are going to private schools. I suppose that it depends very much on where one stands and that, in a political debate on education, one cannot expect that attention will necessarily be paid to facts. It is a pity, but that seems to be the case.

I would like to refer to the points that the Minister has raised with regard to disadvantage in education in Australia. I feel coming through the Minister's statement an optimism that I do not share. I believe that it is misplaced optimism in terms of the ability of educational institutions to deal with disadvantage in Australia. It has been an acceptable part of the education wisdom of this country that somehow or another schools can be a major ingredient in overcoming dis- advantage. Unfortunately, educational research has never established that. In fact, educational research has established more and more that, to a very large extent, schools have a peripheral effect on disadvantage within our society. That is to be expected. At one stage schools were almost the entire source of information for young people entering society. They are no longer the entire source of information; in fact they are a very small source. They also have a very minor effect on the way in which young people act and think. The role that the school once had has been taken over, irrevocably, by the operation of various forms of media, by media promoted or advertisement induced youth movements of one kind or another.

The education system is battling on all fronts to try to do the work that it is served up by the community. When young people are drowned or killed on the roads or they take drugs we hear constantly that the solution to the problem is to do something about it in the schools. This is a major Australian cop-out. These problems are supposed to have nothing to do with parents, the media, or society in general. There is no way in the world that schools can cope with the type of societal changes that they are supposed to be able to cope with. They are struggling merely to cope with the basic educational tasks in the modern world-to address themselves to the basic operations of knowledge and understanding. It would be a refreshing change if, in the general media-society organisational structures that we have, a few other groups took responsibility for the induction of our young people into society.
I express support for what the Minister said on page 5 of the statement that she has put down:
For the first time, the Commonwealth will have access to information on the extent to which this goal is being achieved.

I find it passing strange that Senator Baume should have criticised that notion. I would have thought that it is not a matter for criticism to attempt to make decisions based on information. One of the matters on which the Australian Democrats were unable to get Liberal-National Party support was precisely the matter of information regarding the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. We were arguing that the Tertiary Education Commission could give certain advice to the Government. We believed that, in that way, the Government would have a larger data base. We certainly support State governments, in a co-operative arrangement with the Commonwealth Government, having agreed to provide the Commonwealth Government with information so that the Commonwealth Government, in tailoring its economic program, its expenditure, will have access to information which it previously did not have.

Senator Baume said that this is an inducement by way of the power of the purse. I am not at all sure that many Commonwealth governments have been reticent about using the power of the purse in a whole range of policy areas. After all, that is precisely where the power of this chamber comes from. Indeed, it is a fact that he or she who controls the purse strings will control the final outcome of policy. The Commonwealth Government, through its revenue-raising operations, obviously has a role to play. We may decry that in a theoretical sense with regard to the Federation structure, but surely we must accept the realities of the matter. The political realities of the matter are that the Commonwealth Government has the money and it determines, very largely, what goes on. If it is to provide money for special programs for the disadvantaged, I would have thought that, in any situation, it ought to know what happens as a result of the expenditure of that money.

Let me outline what follows from the agreements made between State and Commonwealth authorities, particularly with regard to four major areas. I refer, firstly, to the importance of primary education, particularly junior primary, as a foundation for future learning. In the past five or six years all State government departments have structured primary education programs and all the non-government school authorities have done likewise. What the Commonwealth Government is doing is merely coming in behind something which was already under way in the States and in the private school sector. It has been a move not so much of educational philosophy but a move on the part of the various systems to acknowledge the primacy of that foundation and the necessity for a good foundation at the primary school level. Hence one finds, for example, that State authorities have slightly raised or strengthened the conditions regarding early entrance into primary school. Almost universally throughout Australia now, it is no longer possible to get a child into primary school unless he or she is five years old, or six years old in some States. That is a direct acknowledgment of what we have discovered from educational research; that is, that earlier inducement to primary education as a system is not a good educational practice. It has been linked with the increasing development of the pre-school sector, and that has been a totally different type of educational approach, educational philosophy and educational activity. It is seen that the pre-school sector is a far better way of dealing with younger children than the more formal operations of the primary school sector.

That development has been undertaken by the States in the last 10 years, and again, the move by the Commonwealth is not a move, as it were, up front; it is a move coming in behind. I believe that it is useful that the Commonwealth has come in behind on this factor, and that is one of the reasons why State governments were quite happy to sign most of these agreements. They were already expending money in this area, they were already heavily committed in this area, and they welcomed the infusion of extra funds from the Commonwealth. There was really very little haggling with regard to that aspect.

The second aspect - the need to raise participation in years 11 and 12 by disadvantaged groups - again met with no resistance by State governments. Every State government - including my State Government in Queensland - has already put in place specific programs with regard to the retention of disadvantaged students in the higher school sector. Again, State governments welcomed the availability of additional funds to allow those programs to be extended.

The next point mentioned by the Minister was the importance of expanding representation and attainment of girls in major subject areas. Again, every State government has a specific unit within its State education system and its State education departments dealing with the specific educational problem of girls. Every State already has in motion certain programs-which in some States, admittedly, are not very extensive in this area-and again, every State found it easy to accept additional money from the Commonwealth in order to enable it to expand and enable the promotion of educational opportunities for girls. So there was no problem on the part of the States in signing those agreements.

The last matter raised-assistance for teachers-is not only not new but also has hairs on it. Every State government has had professional development programs. The major problem with those has been the cutback in moneys provided by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is now seeking to reverse this trend by specifically trying to tie professional development to the attainment of certain educational goals. It seems an excellent development. It is one which the States are very happy to pick up, and again there is no problem with it.

There was no problem on the part of the States in signing the resource agreements. The States did not have to be induced, hit over the head with a large stick or pulled or pushed in any way. They were already involved and all they were looking for was extra funds. They were happy to share with the Commonwealth the outcome of those programs because they saw that by doing so they might get further funds down the line to enable them to develop and pursue those programs.

This statement is a very good example of Federal co-operation. The fact that this was able to be achieved in such a short time, in spite of the diversity of political parties in government in the States, illustrates the fact that there has been very little heartache over this exercise. When Federal governments undertake exercises such as this that are acceptable to State governments, they should be commended rather than attacked. I would have thought that the whole notion of federalism is that when there is a co-operative arrangement we should say `Good'. Where there is an imposed arrangement, the problem of federalism arises. There is no imposed arrangement with any State government and in this operation I have sought to explain why State governments were quite happy with it.

I conclude by returning to my original point, which was concerned with equality and disadvantage within our society. I would hope that in future educational debates we will have more time to expand on this subject. However, we must be clear, we have to make it very clear in the wider community, that equalities in our society which exhibit themselves in the educational sphere are not educationally induced; they are societally structured and systematically related to various income levels, race, and the sex of the individuals concerned. We know that from social science research and educational research. We have to acknowledge that the relationship between those factors and the parents or home environment is incredibly strong.

The health of our society depends on the degree to which all young people in Australia are treated equally. It is an essential ingredient of a democracy that that be so. We should not only treat people equally but also valued people equally. Therefore, it is only when all Australians, not just those in government and not just those who are teaching in schools, accept the responsibility to eliminate racial practices, sexist practices and other practices which bring about disadvantage to specific groups and undertake to change their attitudes with regard to these matters, both individually and collectively by talking and discussing them with their friends, that any real advance will be made to overcome educational disadvantage. It cannot be overcome by schools on their own; it can be overcome only by everybody in society, including all those in positions of responsibility, tackling the societal sources of disadvantage.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORLD HERITAGE PROPERTIES CONSERVATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 to make more effectual provision for proper protection and conservation of property to which the Act applies.
Bill presented by Senator Macklin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The convention for the protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage of which Australia is a signatory, imposes an obligation on the signatories to identify cultural and natural heritage of ``outstanding universal value'' and to protect that heritage.

The Australian Government has sought to fulfil its obligations under the Convention through the enactment in 1983 of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. The Act provides in the first instance for the identification of World Heritage Property, and secondly for the protection of that property following proclamation. Whilst identification is a condition of protection, identification of property as World Heritage Property does not in itself provide protection. That is a distinction worth noting, given recent statements by the Minister for the Environment suggesting the contrary.

Where the Governor-General is satisfied that any identified World Heritage Property is being or is likely to be damaged or destroyed the Governor-General may, I repeat may, by proclamation bring into force the protective provisions of sections 9, 10 and 11.

Sections 9, 10 and 11 state that it will be unlawful except with the express permission of the Minister for a person to do any one of a comprehensive list of acts including excavation, drilling, use explosives, construct a road, damage trees, erect or destroy buildings.

Section 9, which relies on the foreign affairs power, and section 11, which relies on the Races power were held invalid in a number of respects by the High Court in the Dams case. As the Government has not however chosen to amend the Principal Act to take the High Court ruling into account this Bill amends sections 9, 10 and 11 only insofar as is necessary to achieve the purpose of removing the requirement for proclamation before the protective provisions apply to identified World Heritage Property.
Section 6 of this Bill provides that all World Heritage Property will be immediately protected.

If the Government could be trusted to proclaim any World Heritage Property immediately upon threat of damage or destruction to that Property this Bill might not have been necessary. That is obviously not the case. This Government cannot even be trusted to nominate for World Heritage Listing property which has been unambiguously identified by world experts to be worthy of nomination. The Australian Heritage Commission for instance commissioned a report on the Queensland Wet Tropics rainforests. That report, delivered in June 1984, unequivocally recommended World Heritage Listing. The Government, for two years, has failed to act on that obligation. The failure is attributable, not to any doubt as to the international importance of the wet tropic rainforest, but to a lack of political will.

While this Bill will not compel nomination of World Heritage quality property it will make protection of listed property mandatory. As important, once protection is mandatory environment organisations will, under ss. 13 and 14, automatically have standing to seek an injunction or prerogative writ. At present such groups have standing under ss. 13 (5) and 14 of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act only after the relevant property has been proclaimed.

Such groups cannot, in the absence of proclamation, seek a writ of mandamus to have a court order the performance of a public duty or exercise of a discretion according to law by a public official as in the absence of proclamation there is no obligation on or capability of the Minister or his or her delegates to make a decision under ss. 9 or 10. Nor can such groups seek a declaration or injunction as the Act does not confer public rights. In a situation where property has not been proclaimed and acts are being done which damage or destroy that property such groups are powerless under the Act.

If all the identified properties were protected on identification and the property is being damaged or destroyed and where a Minister does not act to prevent or cease the damage then such groups may seek a writ of mandamus to compel a decision to be made and once a decision has been made the group may have standing as an aggrieved party under ss. 13 (5), (6), for the purposes of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and/or seek an injunction under s. 14 to restrain the unlawful acts.

If this Bill becomes law, environment organisations such as the Australian Conservation Foundation, and the Queensland Wildlife Preservation Society will have the right to go to the Federal Court to compel the Government to prevent a development such as that proposed by East West Airlines for Lindeman Island proceeding. That would be a massive step forward in environmental law.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend several acts relating to aspects of the wheat industry and which will further improve the ability of the Australian Wheat Board to meet the increasingly difficult world trading environment it faces.

The Bill is consistent with the Government's Policy Statement ``Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities'' released as a White Paper on 29 January 1986. A greater level of responsibility has been placed on the members of the Australian Wheat Board both individually and collectively, but with this, the Board has been given more autonomy to act in an independent commercial way than previously; there will be less direct ministerial involvement in the Board's operations; and there will be a greater level of formal accountability by the Board to industry. The bulk of the changes relate to the Wheat Marketing Act 1984, and are contained in Part II of the Bill.

This Bill provides explicit power for the Board to set up or take an equity interest in subsidiary companies if this will assist it to perform its functions more efficiently. It will be necessary for the Minister to approve the Board exercising its powers in this regard, with or without conditions. There will be the opportunity for public scrutiny of any approvals given by the Minister as the notice of approval is to be tabled in both Houses of Parliament.

The Board is to be given the power to trade in additional types of contracts in order to hedge the wheat crop. It already has the power to engage in a number of different hedging activities, but in order to protect returns to growers from sudden adverse movements in international wheat prices and exchange rates, the Board must be able to utilize the range of hedging instruments available to other commercial international marketing organisations. Because new instruments are continuously becoming available, the Minister is to be given a power to approve other hedging instruments should this be necessary.

The Bill provides a clearer statement of the Board's relationship with the Minister than previously. For example, the Minister's power of direction over the Board is to be amended so that it will now only be able to be exercised in exceptional circumstances where there is a conflict with major government policies. A consultative procedure is set down to ensure that the Board has had an opportunity to put its views to the Minister, and the direction will be open to public scrutiny.

Another aspect of the changing relationship of the Board with the Minister, and which will ensure that the Board carries out its functions in a business-like manner, is contained in clause 27 of the Bill. This clause provides for the Board to develop corporate and operational plans.

Corporate plans will be developed each year for a three, four or five year period, as appropriate, which will define the principal objectives of the Board and outline its intended strategies. In the development of the corporate plan, it is expected that the Board will consult with the industry to ensure that the industry's needs and priorities are taken into account.
An annual operational plan will set out, for each successive one year period, the particulars of the strategies to be pursued by the Board in giving effect to the corporate plan over that year.

Both the corporate plans and annual operational plans are to be submitted to the Minister for Primary Industry for approval. In this way, accountability arrangements focus on the strategies and longer term performance of the Board and free it from the need for constant reference to the Minister for detailed approval of each major activity.
While it would be expected that key parts of the Board's corporate plans may be made widely known to industry, the Board may wish to keep certain elements confidential for commercial reasons.

The Board's relationship with industry is also to change. It will become more accountable through the requirement, detailed in clause 11 of the Bill. For a meeting to be held, at least annually but more often if the Board considers it appropriate, with the members of the executive of the Australian Wheatgrowers' Federation. This meeting is to provide the opportunity for industry representatives to receive an address by the Chairperson on the Board's most recent annual report, and on the performance of the Board during that year and for industry representatives to question Board members concerning any aspect of its activities.

Because of this increased level of accountability to industry, it is not appropriate for the President or the members of the executive of the Australian Wheatgrowers' Federation to be members of the Board. Clause 17 of the Bill provides accordingly.

Other significant reforms which give the Board increased authority to perform in a commercial manner, but which place a commensurate responsibility on it to do so within a properly accountable framework are contained in clauses 26, 32 and 33 of the Bill.

Clause 26 removes the requirement for the terms and conditions on which officers of the Board are appointed to be approved by the Public Service Board. This will mean that the Board will now have the total responsibility for the management of its relations with its staff.

Clauses 32 and 33 will enable the Board to appoint a company auditor to audit its accounts. This is consistent with the greater level of accountability by the Board to the industry through the requirement for an annual meeting at which the annual report is formally presented. Should the Board seek to use a commercial auditor, appointment is to be by the Minister for Primary Industry, subject to the agreement of the Auditor-General that the auditor is suitable and the agreement of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to the appointment.

The efficient functioning of the Australian Wheat Board as a corporate Board is crucial to ensuring that wheat growers continue to get the best possible returns for their wheat. In addition to the major restructuring of the Board which the Government put into effect last year, there are several clauses of the Bill which bear directly on matters at the Board level. For example, clause 18 provides for a new position of Deputy Chairperson on the Board, to be appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry after consulting with the Chairperson and the Presiding Member of the Selection Committee. The Deputy Chairperson will take over all the responsibilities of the Chairperson at any time the latter is unavailable.

Also, clause 20 amends the term of office of members from a fixed three year term to a period of up to three years. This will enable, for example, members to be appointed for staggered terms to provide for greater continuity of membership and for casual vacancies to be filled for specified terms when a three year appointment may not be considered desirable.

Because one aspect of the Tasmanian wheat freight arrangements was identified as being constitutionally vulnerable, clause 16 of the Bill provides for an amendment to the Wheat Marketing Act to remove this difficulty.

Parts III and IV of the Bill make amendments to the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 and the Rural Industries Research (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1985 to correct an omission that occurred when those Acts were prepared, thus including the Wheat Tax (Permit) Act 1984 in the scheme provided by those Acts for rural industries research funds. Part VI of the Bill alters the effect of the Rural Industries Research Regulations to ensure that the research component of the levy imposed by the Wheat Tax (Permit) Act 1984 is included in the Wheat Research Trust Fund.

The passage of this Bill will involve no cost to the Commonwealth. On the contrary, it will enable the Australian Wheat Board to repay to the Commonwealth moneys expended during 1985 on the selection process for new grower and specialist members of the Board.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
FUTURES INDUSTRY BILL 1986

The Bill that I am introducing today represents an important step in the process of bringing the futures industry within the ambit of the co-operative companies and securities scheme. I am introducing this Bill pursuant to the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. A detailed description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.
Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme

The Formal Agreement executed by the Commonwealth and all the States on 22 December 1978 provides the framework for a co-operative Commonwealth/State scheme for a uniform system of law and administration regulating companies and the securities industry. The scheme covers the relevant law operating in the six States and the Australian Capital Territory. The Northern Territory Government has now joined the co-operative scheme and has introduced legislation to apply Commonwealth companies and securities legislation in the Territory.

The parties to the Formal Agreement have agreed that the co-operative scheme should be extended to cover the regulation of the futures industry and franchising. The necessary amendments to the Formal Agreement have been approved by each participating Government and the Amending Agreement is presently in the process of being signed by each of the parties. In accordance with that Amending Agreement, the proposed futures legislation has been agreed to unanimously by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. In the coming months, the other parties to the Formal Agreement will be introducing legislation that will apply the Commonwealth legislation throughout Australia.
Background
Futures trading basically involves entering into agreements on a futures exchange to deliver or make delivery of a commodity at an agreed price at some time in the future.

Futures trading in Australia has developed from a specialised market of interest mainly to wool producers, into a market in which producers, consumers and participants in the financial system seek to redistribute economic risks or secure a speculative profit.

In the last decade, the major growth area in the futures industry has been in financial futures markets. Financial futures enable business risks, such as changing exchange rates, interest rates and share prices, to be protected.
The need to have a uniform regulatory system governing the futures industry in Australia was recognised by the Campbell Committee and has been endorsed by the Sydney Futures Exchange.

The Campbell Committee stated that ``there should be a national approach to the regulation of futures exchanges'' and that the same co-regulatory approach that is adopted in relation to stock exchanges should apply to futures exchanges.

At present the only legislation in Australia that specifically deals with the futures industry is the New South Wales Futures Markets Act. Experience with the administration of this Act, the manner in which some non-members of the Sydney Futures Exchange have promoted and conducted their business and the failure of a number of futures brokers have clearly indicated the need for Australia-wide legislation in this area.

Exposure drafts of the proposed legislation dealing with the futures industry were released for public comment on two occasions, in October 1984 and November 1985. This consultative process has been invaluable in shaping the legislation to the needs of the industry and the protection of the public who invest in the futures markets.
Outline of Proposals
The Futures Industry Bill will establish a framework applying prudential controls to participants in the futures industry. Briefly, the Bill will:
(a) require futures brokers and advisers to be licensed;
(b) establish a system for the approval of futures exchanges and clearing houses;
(c) require futures exchanges and futures associations to establish a fidelity fund for the protection of clients;
(d) provide criminal sanctions for manipulative and fraudulent practices; and
(e) require futures brokers to maintain adequate records and separate client funds from their own funds.

Much of the public debate about the Bill has concerned the definition of futures contract and hence the reach of the legislation. I would draw your attention to paragraphs 29 to 34 of the explanatory memorandum. The definition aims at ensuring that it is sufficiently wide to include all contracts generally considered to be futures contracts, whether traded on or off market, so as to overcome any avoidance techniques (denying clients the benefits of the protections in the Bill). At the same time, the definition provides for the exclusion of legitimate commercial arrangements that clearly should not be subject to the legislation.

Paragraph 10 of the Explanatory Memorandum sets out the regime that will apply in relation to the futures industry and the securities industry. At this stage, it is not proposed that the futures industry legislation should cover deliverable commodity options that are not traded on a futures exchange: if it becomes apparent that these or related arrangements are being used to circumvent the purpose and spirit of the legislation then the Ministerial Council will consider extending the scope of the legislation.
Financial and Regulatory Impact
Statement
These proposals will involve the Commonwealth in funding half the cost of several additional staff for the National Companies and Securities Commission.

The Futures Industry Bill will impose costs on people involved in the futures industry: licensing, record-keeping and segregation of client funds are examples of prudential requirements that will increase cost. This must be compared to the cost that many clients of failed futures brokers have had to bear in recent years.

Although the cost to participants (brokers, exchanges and clearing houses) is not possible to quantify, the Government believes that the legislation is justifiable: it will ensure confidence in the futures markets and will assist futures exchanges in this country to compete successfully in attracting international business.
The Government commends this Bill to the Senate.
FUTURES INDUSTRY (FEES) BILL 1986

The Futures Industry (Fees) Bill is the second Bill in the legislative package dealing with the futures industry. I am introducing this Bill pursuant to the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. A description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.

The Futures Industry (Fees) Bill provides for fees payable under the Futures Industry Bill. The fees payable under this Bill impose costs on participants in the industry that relate to administrative matters (lodgement of documents etc.) handled by State and Territory Corporate Affairs Commissions.
The Government commends this Bill to the Senate.
COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FUTURES INDUSTRY) BILL 1986

The Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment (Futures Industry) Bill is the third Bill in the legislative package dealing with the futures industry. I am introducing this Bill pursuant to the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. A description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.

The Bill contains several consequential amendments to companies and securities legislation. The only one that I would specifically draw to your attention is that providing that a dealing in a futures contract will not be a dealing in securities for the purposes of the Securities Industry Act. This will ensure there is no unnecessary regulatory overlap between the futures and securities industry legislation.
The financial and regulatory impact of the package of Bills dealing with the futures industry is discussed in my second reading speech on the Futures Industry Bill.
The Government commends this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1985-86[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1985-86APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1985-86]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills before the Senate represent an opportunity for the Opposition to examine the performance of the Hawke Government in its economic management of the country. Quite clearly, as everybody in Australia knows, the Hawke Government in the three years it has been in power has been an extra- ordinarily lucky Government in terms of economic management. It came into power with the breaking of the drought of 1982-the longest and worst drought that we had seen for some 70 years. There has been some economic recovery since 1982, when there was a considerable downturn in the world economy which had a significant effect on the economic fortunes of this country. Of course, at the same time the stimulatory Budget of the Fraser Government in 1982, which sought to set the scene to lift the economy from the recession of that year, had very significant impacts upon the performance of this Government in later years.

SPEECH.PARA: What did this Government do when it came to power? We are now facing the real test of the Government's mettle in terms of its economic management. Quite clearly, there are big question marks about that. Let us just test one or two things, for a start, in relation to the Government's direct financial management. For instance, if we look at how expenditures are running, as administered by this Government, we find that public debt interest rose 38 per cent in the first six months of this financial year compared with the same period last year. More of that later, because I would like to go to the root causes of that. In the area of Medicare-a significant and flagship policy of this Labor Government-we find that there was an increase for the six months to the end of December of 18.8 per cent on the same period last financial year. That is running ahead of the Budget estimate of 11.4 per cent. Expenditure on other pharmaceutical services and benefits is running 16.4 per cent above the level for the same period last year, and of course the Budget allowed for an increase of only 71/2 per cent. Health services in the Australian Capital Territory are running 37.9 per cent above the same period last year, while the Budget allowed for an increase of only 11.6 per cent. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation's expenditure is 18.6 per cent ahead of last year, while the Budget provided for an increase of only 13.8 per cent. The Australian bicentennial road development program, incredibly, is up by 48.2 per cent over the same period last year, while the Budget allowed, would you believe, for an increase of 5.5 per cent. Does this demonstrate competent economic and financial management? One has to have very serious doubts about that.

As I mentioned earlier, the real tests for this Government are yet to come. It has been living since 1983 on a program of increasing its overseas borrowings and of course keeping a high interest rate policy, which is damaging business, farms and the housing sector, in order to attract private and government capital into Australia to make up for its huge foreign account deficit. Every month we fall back; our deficit, our fo-reign debt, rises by some $1 billion or more. It is expected that this year we will have a record current account deficit, to the tune of maybe $13,500m, which will bring the aggregate debt in this country to a level of about $80,000m. That has occurred at a time when one would have expected that there was a fair degree of prosperity, when from all the trumpetings of the Government one would have expected marvellous opportunities for this Government, with proper management, to reduce debt, not increase it. Yet the opposite has happened.

In 1983, when this Government came to power, our foreign debt was of the order of $35,000m. By the end of June it will be $80,000m -a fantastic increase in just three years. It reminds me very much of the two-income family which, by virtue of the two incomes, has a fair degree of security and a standard of living which is above the average. Then, suddenly, one of the partners loses his or her job. As a result there is only one breadwinner, one income, but the family strives to maintain its standard of living by raising its borrowings-by borrowing by way of personal loans from its bank, by increasing its bank overdraft or by buying a new car on some other kind of finance when it might otherwise have paid cash. In those ways a continuing level of debt is built up until the point is reached where the income is not large enough to service that debt and to meet repayments of capital and interest. The family then finds itself having to borrow in order to make such repayments. Under this Government, this country is rapidly heading towards such situations, with the increasing debts at a massive level, which in the longer run, must have a dramatic impact on our living standards as we repay them.

I have already drawn attention to the fact that repayment of public debt, including our foreign debt, is up 38 per cent compared with the figure last year. This arises directly because of our commitment and the need to service the huge burden of debt imposed on the Australian people by this Government. People in the community generally have been complaining bitterly about the level of interest rates, which are killing investment and the housing industry. Yet very little is done by this Government to redress that problem. The level of interest rates has a direct relationship to the economic management of this Government, because the level of debt only increases the level at which interest rates have to be set by the Government to attract foreign capital to ensure that we can meet our overseas problem. That is a continuing difficulty which this Government must face. Apparently it will not face up to the basic reasons why this is occurring. We all know that the basic problem lies in the question of what it intends to do about wages policy. That is the big no-no for this Government. It is forced to deal with its own constituency in the trade union movement and, as the tool of that movement, it is not able to negotiate a proper arrangement on behalf of the Australian people. Rather, it will always first take into account its political interests rather than the true welfare of the Australian people.

I mentioned earlier that the overseas debt is placing a greater and greater burden on the Australian people. That can be seen no more clearly than by the fact that of every export dollar we gain by selling our coal, wool, wheat and other produce on world markets, 40c is now going to service the cost of our foreign debt. In other words, 40c of our exports are mortgaged to repay the debt which has been swallowed up in consumption in the last three years. There is no doubt that this Government is the highest taxing, highest borrowing, highest spending Government Australia has ever seen. For that reason it deserves to consider the alternatives being put by the Opposition, which I shall come to in terms of the amendment we shall propose to the second reading motion.

I turn to some of the broken promises that have been a factor of this Government's life since it came to power three years ago. First of all, there was the magnificent promise-this happened even in 1984, in the election campaign of that year-that there would be a reduction in interest rates. What has happened? We have seen interest rates go in exactly the opposite direction, to the highest levels they have been in real terms since the 1930s. There was a promise to bring down inflation below 5 per cent. The latest figures show that inflation is of the order of 9.2 per cent at current levels. The level of inflation is running twice as high as the level among our trading partners in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. But that is without taking into account the fact that because of the huge fall in the oil price, countries that are energy deficient, such as Germany, Japan and the USA, now have negative rates of inflation. This is happening because the cost of living is falling rather than rising. Yet we have a cost of living rising at 9.2 per cent when our major trading partners have lowering inflation rates. Those countries have a negative inflation rate and a cost of living that is actually falling, whereas in Australia it is rising. That is not encouraging for our potential.

The tax package was introduced six or eight months ago, and I will deal more fully with that topic a little later, but one of the most fundamental promises that was broken following the introduction of that package concerns the capital gains tax. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his Sydney Opera House policy speech, which we remember so well, made it quite clear that there would be no such tax. However, immediately after this Government was re-elected came the capital gains tax. It was very like the promises made by Senator Grimes at the economic summit back in 1983 that there would be no assets on pensions, that there would be no lump sum superannuation tax-only to be overturned later by a decision of the Government, when there was a total breaking of the promises to the Australian people that that would not occur.

I turn to some of the details of the tax package. First, we have before us-we have only just seen it-legislation in respect of the abolition of negative gearing in property development. We are also seeing legislation for the infamous and iniquitous fringe benefits tax. The Government has sought to make something of the point that the Opposition will be opposing those two pieces of legislation and that somehow this will undermine the Government's capacity to deliver its tax cuts, which it has promised by September 1986. The first thing that must be said is: Who can believe any promise from this Government about reducing taxation? All the Government has done since coming to power is to impose more taxes. One needs only to ask the pensioners and retired people to appreciate what happened with the assets test on pensions, the lump sum superannuation tax, the income test for people over 70. They know that this Government cannot be trusted. How can the rest of the work force of Australia feel that they can trust this Government on statements about tax cuts? The fact is that they cannot. If we examine the promises made on tax cuts, we can see quite clearly what the Government is on about in trying to besmirch and scapegoat the Opposition as being the Party that will bring some collapse of its policy in reducing taxation.

Let us get one or two simple statistics in our minds. First, for the next two years this Government promised taxation cuts totalling $4.5 billion. The Government, by its own admission, back in September last year made clear that the maximum amount of money that can be raised to fund the tax cuts is $1.5 billion. That leaves a $3 billion overhang that this Government has to find from some other source. It can find it by imposing other taxes, or by relying on inflation-which it is doing a great job in helping to keep high-and in that way pay for future tax cuts. It can rely on growth in the economy, but all economists are suggesting that in the next few years the rate of growth in the economy will fall from levels around 5 per cent to levels around 3 per cent. That gives the lie to the Government's claim that somehow the taxation policies on fringe benefits tax, negative gearing and so on are basic to the Government's capacity to deliver the tax cuts. That is a nonsense. It is time that people heard the truth, that this Government is gambling the future of the Australian people by using and mortgaging $3 billion worth of inflation in the next two years to fund the tax cuts it intends to deliver in the next year.

Let us look at the Government's record on the question of raising taxation. Already there have been announcements-thank God-that there will be no action to disallow the quaranti-ning of farm losses. We are not quite sure whether we have the whole story on this matter because the Government has not yet told us-nor has the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh-what it intends to do to raise funds to offset that loss. Senator Walsh seems quite adamant in this place every day that there will be no other imposts on farmers to offset the withdrawal of the quarantining of farm losses proposal. There is the question of the Australia Card. This proposal was designed to raise in a few years time some $300m or $400m. Yet the Government is in internal turmoil over the question of whether it intends to introduce the card. Quite clearly, those two factors alone will have significant effects on the Government's so-called capacity to deliver the tax cuts.

Another issue is the rather silly, petty approach to the abolition of the tax deduction for entertainment expenses. That proposal was put through the Parliament back in November last year. We recall that the Government boasted that this proposal was to save some $300m in taxation. The truth is that business and those who claim entertainment expenses merely have shifted their expenditure from what are now illegal areas of expenditure, on entertainment, to other promotional expenses which are tax deductible. So how can the Government say that it will obtain greater sums from that source? I would be very surprised if the revenue increased at all as a result of that measure.

Let us consider what the fringe benefits tax will do to the car industry. The industry estimates indicate that this measure will have a devastating effect on the industry. There is a possibility that 10,000 jobs will be lost in the motor car industry as a result of the fringe benefits tax. It is not just the Opposition that is telling the Government these things. It is the Government's Party. The Labor Premier in South Australia, whom the Government propped up before the last State election by not telling the truth about interest rates, is now pleading with the Government to face the truth and realise that its tax policy is wrong and that it will destroy jobs in South Australia and other States. Regional centres such as Bendigo, Ballarat and areas of Adelaide will be subject to enormous pressure as a result of this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Repco in Tasmania.

—And in Tasmania, as Senator Newman points out, particularly around Launceston. Senator Grimes's solution is to build more restaurants to replace the lost jobs in the car industry. He believes that can be done by wiping out tax deductions for entertainment. I guess that shows us the level of the Government's thinking in relation to job creation. I mentioned that Mr Bannon, the South Australian Premier, is fighting the Government on this issue. Senator Button has now joined us in the chamber. If he were of a mind he could get up and tell us of his real thoughts on the fringe benefits tax and its impact on the car industry. It is widely reported that he has been undertaking continual debate within the Caucus and Cabinet on this very issue, seeking to get the Government to see sense. We congratulate Senator Button on his efforts but we are worried. We believe that he is not fit for office because he has failed, very clearly, to deliver the goods in this most important area. Senator Button does not have to believe us. He has only to believe his own Party's Premier in South Australia. He has only to believe the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia. He has only to believe the backbench members of his own Party who, hopefully, will cross the floor and vote against the fringe benefits tax.
—Oh, Senator Messner, you are a laugh.

—Senator Crowley, of course, will not do anything to support her State. We know about Senator Crowley. If the Government has the real interests of South Australia at heart it will face up to its obligations in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the proposal to abolish negative gearing which is also before the Parliament at present for debate. Apparently, this measure is designed to get rid of another tax rort. It is nothing of the sort. It is not a tax rort to negatively gear a property development. With interest rates at their present level, it is practically an impossibility not to negatively gear property developments these days unless they are almost 100 per cent injected with equity capital. Any amount of borrowing bears such high interest rates these days that it is very difficult to get enough income from a property to be able to repay the interest. That is the fundamental point which this Government fails to realise.

The Government assumes that there is no economic value from the development of property. We say that there is economic value in making sure that housing developments and rental housing are provided by the free enterprise sector, the private sector, as opposed to the public sector because that takes the load off the taxpayer. But this Government has exactly the opposite view. It seeks to develop public housing as against private rental housing and so has taken this step to put the pressure on the public sector. This move comes at a time when, during the three years of this Government's occupation of the treasury benches, the waiting lists in the States for public housing provided by the housing commissions in various States-for example, New South Wales and Victoria-and by the Housing Trust in South Australia, have grown by nearly 30 per cent. Yet the Government seeks to impose a further imposition on the taxpayer which will reduce the capacity of the Australian private enterprise sector to deliver rental housing to people in need. As I said, there has been a 30 per cent increase in the waiting list for public housing. The Government cannot service that requirement now, yet it seeks to put more people on the public sector waiting lists by destroying the opportunities of the private industries to provide housing for private renters. Clearly, I have a very great concern about this Government's sanity, not only in regard to housing but in particular to what it is doing to jobs in the car industry, which is becoming more and more of a problem and which must be faced in the weeks and months ahead.

Quite apart from the points that have been made in relation to what these new taxes are all about, the red tape that is resulting from the introduction of these new taxes will place enormous burdens on business and private taxpayers. As we said right from the outset when the `Reform of the Australian Taxation System' proposals were announced by Mr Keating in September last year, this legislation is for the benefit of accountants and lawyers. Today in the Australian Financial Review an advertisement appeared by Coopers and Lybrand, the famous chartered accounting firm. The advertisement advertises a vehicle logbook which one can buy for $3.50 in order to keep all the records one must keep to determine one's tax deduction for motor vehicle use. Coopers and Lybrand say in the advertisement:
Here at last, the book Paul Keating's been raving about.

We can see the job opportunities in the accounting profession as a result of this Government's measure. Yet the further impositions on people to keep detailed records will achieve very little in terms of increasing Commonwealth revenue. Another advertisement appeared in today's Financial Review, also by a firm of chartered accountants, Arthur Young, which states:
Fringe Benefits. Will you get stuck with the Bill?

Indeed, they said that taxpayers will be left in a very sticky situation. They are producing tax reports to help people to understand what this tax legislation is all about. People will need an enormous amount of help. I notice that Senator Crowley has not opened a page of the fringe benefits tax Bill. If she were to, I believe she would be absolutely horrified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I do not think I can stand here and take that gross slur against my character with a claim from the honourable senator about which he has no knowledge.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I notice that Senator Crowley did not deny the point. The fact is that, if she did open the Bill and look at it, she would find the task of understanding it as difficult as when she studied for her medical degree at some earlier stage. One probably needs to have a law degree to understand what the fringe benefits tax legislation will impose on people. There are some 30 pages of definitions in the Bill, defining practically every word that is set out in the parts of the Bill. It is incredible. I challenge Senator Crowley to look at it and to give us a detailed analysis of what it is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will have an enormous impact on small business. It will have an enormous impact on ordinary taxpayers who will have to employ accountants and lawyers. Obviously, this represents a red tape led recovery in order to put more cash in the hands of accountants and lawyers. It is really an accountants and lawyers benefit Bill. That is what it is all about. Of course, there is more to come. We have not yet seen the capital gains tax proposal, which will clearly add to the burdens on small businesses, farmers and ordinary taxpayers and take away from them the incentive to develop their own investments in order to build up a nest egg for retirement.

The issue of a gold tax still hangs over us. Western Australians are very interested in whether there will be a gold tax. Senator Crowley would not know this but many South Australians are very interested in the issue also.
