Companies operating in South Australia-such as Western Mining Corporation Ltd at Roxby Downs and, of course, Poseidon Ltd-have very substantial investments in the gold industry. They are very interested in this Government's intentions with a gold tax. The Liberal and National parties are opposed to a gold tax, but this Government appears to be on the road towards instituting one. We want to know why it wants a gold tax and when we will hear about it. Now that the Western Australian election is out of the way, we feel it is appropriate for the Government to come clean and tell us properly what it intends to do. I notice that the Government is silent on this, so clearly it is considering the matter very deeply at the moment.

I conclude merely by pointing out that it is time that the Australian people learned the truth about the Government's problems in managing the economy. The economy is in the hands of the Government and the problems are home grown.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, well, well, I am delighted to have been edified by that remarkable half-hour contribution from Senator Messner. I particularly want to make the comment that he seems to be very clear about what I do not know. For a start, seeing as he seems to require me to deny categorically his claim, I will tell him for his edification, knowing that he will take not the slightest notice of it, that I serve on the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. That Committee is required to examine all legislation coming into this place so, for his edification, yes, I have looked at that legislation. But whether I know about the fringe benefits tax legislation matters much less to the Australian population than whether people of this country know what the Opposition proposes to do. Senator Messner said that he would tell us what the Opposition would do, but he proceeded to tell us nothing of what it would do except that, believe it or not, the Opposition is opposed to a gold tax. I had to wait through half an hour of that unmitigated piffle to hear that the Opposition is opposed to a gold tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Is the Opposition opposed to a fringe benefits tax? Would it remove such a tax if it ever came to government? Why did Senator Messner not say so if that is the case? Is the Opposition opposed to a capital gains tax? Will that be taken away if the Opposition ever gets back on to the Treasury bench? My goodness, why does not Senator Messner go around and tell people the answers to those sorts of questions instead of serving up to the community of Australia rubbish and nonsense about whether I read Bills, which is monumentally irrelevant.

What this Government has done it stands by and is unashamed of. What the Opposition proposes is totally unclear. Inasmuch as the Opposition makes statements about anything, there are statements on the left hand and statements on the right hand. Mr N. A. Brown may say one thing and Mr Howard may say something else. The Opposition is divided and confused. It has no policies. No wonder all that Opposition members can do is to carp at and criticise the Government. They have nothing to say on their own behalf. I would like to be much clearer about what the Opposition proposes on these matters. I love the way that the Opposition is able to furphy around with the facts.

Fancy suggesting that this Government has not had any successful achievements! This Government, in its three and a bit years, has actually presided over the creation of more than 600,000 jobs. Yes, it has reduced inflation. Yes, it has reduced unemployment dramatically. Yes, we acknowledge that on any hard evidence interest rates rose last year. But Senator Messner was not prepared to tell the people of Australia over the air today that interest rates have fallen considerably in the last few months. I refer Senator Messner to a question from Senator Cook that Senator Walsh answered one day. When asked whether interest rates had fallen, the answer was yes. Certainly, they are matters of grave concern to the Government; but if Senator Messner wishes to give the facts he should give them all and not just a few here and there in order to make his grubby little argument in this debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1985-86, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1985-86.

I do not really want to spend very much time going over what Senator Messner had to say because by and large it is not worth the time. I rose to speak on the appropriations to address some points that emerged from the sittings of Estimates Committee B. These are of considerable interest and I want to take them up today in the second reading debate on these Bills. The first area to which I refer is that of child care. In Estimates Committee B, during examination of the estimates for the Department of Community Services, questions were asked about the provision of child care. These questions seemed to focus more on problems or difficulties in the child care area. While the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, who has never been one to shy away from the hard facts on any matter-this can be said of all Ministers in this Government-acknowledges the need for continuing discussion and negotiation with the few centres not yet open, the estimates did not do justice to the Government's achievements in the child care area. Therefore, I take the opportunity to mention these.

I notice that Senator Messner has left the chamber. I do not suppose he wanted to stay around for any list of the successes of the three years of Labor Government. One of the things that has happened over the last three and a half years has been the dramatic increase in the number of child care places funded by the Commonwealth. The figures show an increase in costs. The expenditure on child care in 1981-82 was $47.4m and in 1984-85 it was $122.7m. That represents a very great increase in an area that may not grab Senator Messner as being critical to the scheme of things, but anybody with an interest in creating work opportunities, particularly for those in the community with child care responsibilities-which of course largely means women-will know that this achievement by government is of great importance, not only to the provision of child care but also to the provision of the opportunity for increased productivity in this country.

Over the same period the number of full time child care places has risen from 37,580 in June 1982 to 63,129 in 1985. It is important to make comment about those full time places. Perhaps the words `full time' should be in inverted commas as, whilst the figures do refer only to full time places, many more children will be catered for. The Government estimates that the figure for full time places represents about 60 per cent of the number of children who will have access. However, that is still a rough estimate at this stage; we cannot be absolutely sure of that. It is important to understand that the figures include not just centre-based child care provision but also family day care provision, both of which take considerable funding from the Commonwealth Government.

Points were raised in discussion during the Estimates Committee about some difficulties in the delay in opening of centres. In relation to a question from Senator Peter Baume as to whether any centres have closed, any places have been lost or any of the anticipated hardships have come to pass, I refer to Senator Grimes's answer as reported at page 304 of the Estimates Committee B Hansard of 15 April 1986, in which he said that he would ask Ms Murnane to answer further, but that no centres have had to close. Senator Grimes said that the difficulty goes to centres that have not opened; that no places have been lost, just a delay in establishing the new places; and that the hardships anticipated by certain centres and certain workers involved in centres have not in fact come to pass.

The problem has been localised to centres in Victoria-although there are a few isolated instances in other places-which have had difficulty in being ready to open under the new arrangements. It is important to acknowledge that no centres currently operating were required to close or did close; there was no loss of existing places; and the delay in the provision of new places was consequent upon the delay in opening of some centres. It is my understanding that some of these centres have already come to arrangements so that they are now comfortable and agreeable with the provisions and able to open. A few more centres in Victoria are still negotiating with the Government about conditions, et cetera, and are not yet open.

In the scheme of things, the enormous increase in places and the enormous achievements in child care provision around this country are matters of great success and deserving of great praise. Certainly it was not, as I understand it, Senator Peter Baume's intention in questioning on the Estimates to make any carping criticism about this matter; rather, that Senator Baume was looking for information. I believe that the child care area, while there are difficulties, as there always are, with the introduction of new provisions or arrangements, is deserving of nothing but considerable congratulations because of the commitment to increase places and because that commitment has been achieved to a large extent.

The second point I turn to is something that also emerged from the Estimates Committee. I suppose it could be said that it emerges from all Estimates Committees on which I have sat, because either I or some other honourable senator has asked about the matter of repetitive strain injury. I found it quite interesting to observe that the Additional Estimates reported quite remarkable differences in the response to questions about RSI. I refer honourable senators to page 327 of the Estimates Committee B Hansard, where it will be seen that Mr Harris from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was able to explain that there has been a significant reduction in the number of people suffering from or becoming afflicted with RSI in that Department. That is most satisfactory, because in the recent past that Department was very concerned about the considerable number of people with repetitive strain injury in the Department. It is interesting to note that the Department has had considerable success in the reduction of cases.

It is very difficult to say precisely what may be the reason for that reduction, partly because in tackling the problems various departments have taken on a number of areas of concern, such as the description of jobs, the provision of work in stages, free time for resting up from the use of machines, changes in furniture, more comprehensive occupational health and safety programs, negotiations with unions, and so on; so it is difficult to say that one specific item contributed to the reduction of RSI cases in the Department. The most important thing is that while we do not know the reason, we know the outcome, and that outcome is satisfactory. If we turn to page 340 of the same Estimates Committee Hansard, we find a quite different response to the question of the importance of RSI. I quote from a question by Senator Peter Baume, where he asked:
RSI has been blamed for a delay in the processing of pharmaceutical scripts in the Pharmpay system. Is that correct?
Mr McKay, from the Department of Health, said:
That is correct.

What is not clear to me-Senator Baume did not seek further clarification-is whether the claim for blame is correct or whether the RSI being blamed is correct. At the moment I presume that it is the claim that is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Smarten up, Baume.

—That may be a piece of pedantry that will wake up Senator Withers, but it is an important distinction that needs to be drawn. The Department is saying that people with RSI in the Department have been of such concern that the Department has blamed, at least in large part, the RSI problem for the delay in the processing of pharmaceutical benefits. I quote from the report of Estimates Committee B to the Senate, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence presented by the Department of Health indicated however that RSI has been partly responsible for a substantial delay (of approximately 51 million items, representing a backlog of about 5 months pro-cessing time) in the processing of pharmaceutical scripts in the `Pharmpay' system. It appears that a combination of automatic direct entry of claims, together with the introduction of new furniture and equipment for ope-rators, is reducing the incidence of RSI.

We go on to say that Estimates Committee B will seek further evidence on what does happen, both with the delay in the payment of pharmaceutical benefits and with the reduction of RSI in the Department of Health. It is important to note, firstly, that there is a problem of RSI, although the Department of Health notes that it is falling, but the Department wants to attribute RSI as being considerably causal to the difficulties it has in the Pharmpay system. Secondly, there is the importance of that delay and how it is being reduced or solved.

Finally, Estimates Committee B wanted to say in its report that it was a bit concerned that a department could blame something like RSI for the difficulty, yet not convey to us assurances that the arrangements put in place to accommodate that kind of difficulty were sufficient to maintain an adequate service in that section of the Department. That is, any administrative procedures ought to take account of whatever difficulties may emerge from time to time. In any large department there are bound to be those sorts of difficulties from time to time. In this case the repetitive strain injury problem contri-buted enormously to a delay and to a building up of a considerable backlog, but I would like the Department to clarify the matter and confirm that it was not attributing all of its admi-nistrative difficulties to RSI or, better still, that it had some fall-back procedures or mechanisms to cope with that difficulty or any other.

The final comment I have on RSI is that one way or another we have had evidence to the Estimates Committee that the number of people with RSI, either being initially diagnosed or being under continuing treatment or compensation, has levelled out and in some departments has fallen. I take great heart from that because there has been a series of difficulties associated with repe-titive strain injury, not the least being the claim by many people that it does not exist at all, or that whatever it is it is all in the mind. I do not think that that approach was at all helpful. In fact, it was while that approach existed that we saw a considerable increase in the number of cases of repetitive strain injury.

It would certainly be interesting to correlate the fall in the number of cases with the different attitude by those in charge who actually took a decision to take this condition seriously, to put in place change in work patterns, perhaps change in furniture, and change in the encouragement of people who felt pain in their arms or shoulders to feel free to report it, in the knowledge that they would not be regarded as neurotic or fakers, but that they would be taken seriously and assisted. It is interesting that with all those changes-as I said earlier, we cannot say which one if any was causal in the fall-there has been a turnaround and a reduction in the incidence of repetitive strain injury. It should be an edifying lesson that before we start accusing people of being liars, cheats or fakers perhaps we should take seriously what they are presenting by way of complaint and try to address it. It certainly seems that since the problem has been addressed it has been resolved or the numbers have continued to fall.

I think that it has been very fortunate that we have had a condition called repetitive strain injury in the world over the last few years. It seems to me that it has been blamed for everything, and it is almost in danger of replacing mothers as responsible for everything evil and a cause for concern in this world. I say that with heavy irony.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has something of a reputation.
—I agree.
—Is there any pathology yet agreed on what underlies it?

—I am not sure that we should debate the pathology underlying this, but my understanding is that yes, there is in some areas quite observable pathology; but on the whole we are not in the business of cutting out chunks of muscle in people who have sore arms, so it is not an area which has been comprehensively examined from pathological terms. To presume that everybody who complains of pain in the wrist, neck and shoulders is forthwith to be regarded as a poseur, is not a constructive way of behaving. The other thing that has made it difficult for society is that this condition tended to emerge amongst women mainly because the people processing information on word processors were women. It was a humble, lowly paid task and, therefore, it was the area of work that was filled by women, not because they lacked the skills but because they tended to find themselves in lower paid jobs which are more repetitive and boring. Of course, they were the people more likely to get repetitive strain injury. It was then regarded as a sort of middle class, feminist, rat-bag disease, to quote some of my honourable National Party colleagues from that other place. They have lines like that for when women get anything, particularly RSI. `They were all in it madly for the compensation', they said. The full payout for RSI goes all the way to $36,000. One could get very rich on $36,000, particularly if one is totally and permanently incapacitated and in one's twenties. For the honourable senators opposite I note that that was a piece of very heavy irony.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing that is said is that compensation premiums have dramatically risen both within the Commonwealth Public Service and in private insurance companies. A piece in the Australian Financial Review of, I think, a couple of days ago talked about proposals for a 70 per cent increase in compensation premiums throughout New South Wales, which is very interesting and very difficult to account for. Why have compensation premiums so dramatically risen in the last few years? There are some quarters that would say that it is all due to RSI. Blessed be RSI because, while we have that, it saves us from looking, in much harder detail, at what, in fact, contributes to the compensation premium increases, or what are the other criteria that insurance companies have to take into account, or do take into account. I am not sure whether it all can be attributed to RSI. Even when people with RSI do seek common law judgments on their conditions they do not draw the very large sums that we sometimes read about a judge awarding. The RSI area is very interesting. It tends to get tucked away in the Estimates, but I think it has very much more significant ramifications in our society than perhaps we are aware of. I am very interested to draw the attention of the Senate to them today.

The final comment I wish to make relates to another question I raised in the Estimates Committee hearings. The question of Filipino brides and the difficulties that they have experienced was brought to my attention by a number of people in South Australia. The people who raised this matter with me worked with a variety of women's services around South Australia and were very concerned about the problem of Filipino brides. They were also concerned to know how big was the problem and, certainly, so was I.

If one meets three Filipino brides who have come under the so-called Filipino brides arrangement, been involved in domestic violence situations and finish up in the women's shelters movement, one may have an impression that that is what happens to all Filipino brides. So I was interested to seek from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs information, if it had any, about the whole question-the numbers of Filipino brides arriving in this country, the categories of Filipino brides, how they get to meet their Australian husbands and what is the outcome. I congratulate the Department on its comprehensive answer. It is quite clear from the answer that the Department is well aware of the Filipino brides arriving in this country, has a very good understanding of the outcome of some of those marriages-some are a success-and has a considerable understanding of the problems that arise from some of those marriages. The Department has given me considerable information about steps it is taking in conjunction with other community groups to address the difficulties and provide support for the Filipino brides in particular, but also anybody involved in those marital breakdowns-the Australian men occasionally, and certainly the children of such marriages.

It seems that there are any number of committees and support groups throughout Australia. There are grant-in-aid workers in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland. Not only does Queensland have a half time grant-in-aid worker in Brisbane but the Catholic family care service in Cairns has a grant-in-aid worker specifically for the Filipino community. There is a further grant-in-aid worker at Mount Isa Ethnic Community Council who works extensively with the Filipino women there. South Australia has a grant-in-aid worker half time and as well there is assistance from the Salisbury migrant resource centre. In Western Australian the Anglican Church Care Centre has grant-in-aid assistance, as does the Young Women's Christian Association at Karratha in north-west Australia.

In Tasmania there seems to be no formal Filipino welfare organisations, but the Department tells us that there are relatively few Filipinos in that State, at least to this point. In the Northern Territory one of the two grant-in-aid workers at the Darwin migrant resource centre is specifically working with Filipino women. In the Australian Capital Territory the Canberra migrant resource centre has a grant-in-aid worker with some Filipino clients, and other welfare groups assist in the Filipino women's problems.

The Department tells me that in 1984-85 approximately 2,000 women arrived in this category-that is, sponsored spouses or fiances-from Asia, 1,600 of whom were Filipinos. The latter figure is increasing and it is estimated that there will be a 10 to 15 per cent growth in 1986. It is estimated that about 30 to 40 per cent of couples meet through introduction agencies, and many of the Australians involved-I guess honourable senators might have noticed that when I listed where the grant-in-aid workers were working-lived in isolated areas, including mining towns and rural properties. It is interesting that that is where a number of the Filipino brides are coming to Australia to live-in Mount Isa, Karratha and on stations far out from large urban areas-and it seems from the Department's figures that those are the partnerships that are more vulnerable to breakdown and give rise to concerns to both the Philippine and Australian governments.

It is estimated that 30 to 40 per cent of Filipino brides meet their spouses through introduction agencies, 45 per cent through friends and relatives while 15 per cent or so begin their relationship on meeting in the Philippines. The number of relationships being instigated through personal introduction, that is through family and friends, is rising. This presumably is because of the number of successful Australian-Filipino marriages and introductions of Australian men to Filipino women through the friendship or family contact rather than through the introduction agencies. Many Filipino women who have met their problems through introduction agencies claim that they were unaware, for example, that their husbands had criminal records or histories of domestic violence, mental illness or previous failed marriages. I guess what that means is that the examination of the cases coming before either the Department of Social Security or the Department of Community Welfare shows that that is the history of some of those Australian men seeking Filipino brides.

It is also to be noticed that some Filipino women marry for economic reasons and that they perhaps have put an overrated value on what they see as the Australian man's income or monetary value. Australian husbands are perceived as tending to marry Filipino women for company, sex or child care. I do not quite know where they get the children. The report does not list that, but presumably that happens too. The interesting thing is that Australian men are perhaps not aware that Filipino women are not just compliant and passive; in fact, they are very often of much higher educational and social standing than the men anticipated and sometimes that is judged to be the cause of the conflict that then arises.

The problem, of course, for many is that the marriage will come to a stage of domestic violence and almost invariably it is the Filipino bride who is the victim of that violence. Nobody can give precise figures on the number of breakdowns, but it is to be noticed that one-third of those women who avail themselves of Darwin's only women's refuge are Filipino women. Nearly all are married to Australian-born males. It seems from these figures that there is quite clearly an area of grave concern. I think the Department has already acknowledged that by the number of grant-in-aid workers it has supported and the number of agencies around the country it is working with to try to address the problem and provide more data as well as the important support. It is also to be noticed that the age of Filipino brides is rising and the age of Australian men seeking Filipino brides is falling. Perhaps this is due to the changing nature of the way these people originally meet. It is to be hoped that the problem, now that it is very well acknowledged, will be more satisfactorily dealt with, particularly in the provision of satisfactory support for those women who perhaps live in isolated areas of Australia. I again commend the Department for the very comprehensive information it provided on that question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats note the second reading amendment proposed by the Liberal-National Party Opposition to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86. We do not agree with everything in that Bill-for instance, the decision not to introduce a capital gains tax. I make the point briefly at this stage that that tax, which would have borne much more severely on the Australian business community and the community at large had it not been for Democrat intervention, was because of our intervention very much ameliorated. I will not go into this in detail but the fact that the Bill is entirely prospective and that it is indexed for inflation so that, indeed, it represents little more than income and should be taxed as such, has been due to the intervention of the Democrats. These matters will be dealt with later in this debate by Senator Siddons and we will indicate our justification for other amendments to the Liberal amendment which has already been circulated in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak particularly to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86 and I am especially interested in that part of the Estimates for the Department of Resources and Energy, division 523, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, $753,000 for running expenses under the Atomic Energy Act 1953. This expenditure permits the continuance of experiments in the nuclear power and weapons field being carried out at the Commission's establishment at Lucas Heights. I refer in particular to the experiment in centrifuge enrichment which I understand is being run down but I have not had any definite undertaking from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) on its determination. That experiment, among other things, led to a dangerous leakage of uranium hexafluoride gas at Lucas Heights in 1984. Australia ought not to be meddling in this dangerous technology. Enrichment for nuclear power reactor fuel is the same as for nuclear bomb fuel. It is only a matter of how high a proportion of U235 the material contains, and that is only a matter of how many times the gas is passed through the centrifuge cascades.

I also raise again, as my colleagues Senator Chipp and Senator Sanders have done in recent days, the question of the safety of the Commission's HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights. That reactor is now quite old and on a number of occasions scientists at the establishment have questioned its safety if it is kept in continued use. Although it is a small reactor, I was not altogether reassured by the Minister's response to my question to him last week about the possible effects of an accident there. The Lucas Heights reactor is not graphite moderated, it is true, but it does contain significant amounts of flammable graphite in its construction, just as the Chernobyl reactor did.

My main purpose in entering this debate is to plead with the Government to discontinue these areas of expenditure, to get right out of all aspects of the nuclear industry, especially to legislate as soon as possible to stop all uranium mining and exporting from Australia, and to reverse its stand on the Roxby Downs uranium field in South Australia. From what we gather, there are no customers available for Roxby Downs uranium anyway, and I would expect that after the Chernobyl disaster that will continue for a long time into the future. It is ridiculous that this Government and the South Australian Government should be contemplating huge areas of public expenditure backing a furphy, something which is not going to be of any value to anybody but which is going to be a great danger to many people.

In the Government's assessment of this very important matter it may be helped to a decision-the Democrats want a decision from the Government-by the latest assessment of the Chernobyl disaster since what actually happened there and its effects are today a lot clearer than they were even a day or two ago. The radioactive cloud from Chernobyl has extended 3,500 kilometres west to include all of Europe, including Spain. It has extended eastwards to 12,000 kilometres so that this week radioactive rain fell on Japan, on the other side of the world from Chernobyl. While the Japanese authorities said the levels were not high, they advised people not to drink that water. In several European countries children are not being allowed to drink milk. There was a run on chemist's shops all over Europe to buy iodine for children so that the radioactive iodine 131, which has now permeated all of Europe, will not enter their systems and create the inevitable thyroid cancer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inevitable thyroid cancer? Come on, speak accurately.
—Does Senator Peter Baume dispute that there is a risk of thyroid cancer after exposure to iodine 131? What technical expertise--
—You said `inevitable'. That is absolute nonsense. It is a risk.

—Since Senator Peter Baume is a doctor, I take his words on board. I will say that there is a very strong likelihood of cancer of the thyroid. I am sure that Senator Peter Baume, as a doctor, will agree with that. I note from his silence that he does agree. In Italy, fresh vegetables are being thrown away. Some 100 British students who have been in Kiev and Minsk have been told that while their radiation counts of up to 50 times more than normal are not dangerous, they all risk incurring cancer at some time later in their lives.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Otto Huber, head of the Swiss radioactivity monitoring commission, said that nobody had expected such high levels of radioactivity in Europe. Swedish figures quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald today suggest that Chernobyl will cause between 80 and 8,000 additional cancers in Western Europe over the next 40 years. I stress the words `Western Europe' because that does not, of course, concern itself with areas closer to the explosion, which I intend to deal with a little later. Austria has banned the sale of leaf vegetables, cauliflowers, beans, peas and tomatoes, and barred their import from Italy and the Eastern bloc. Some Finnish scientists have reportedly advised against conceiving children during the next few weeks. It has actually reached that stage. At its peak, according to Swedish figures, Swedes were exposed to about two millirems an hour, some 1,000 times the normal area of radiation in the community.

Householders in Scotland, north Wales and the north of England only today have been told not to drink fresh rainwater, and tests on water, milk and vegetables have been stepped up in Britain. The National Radiological Protection Board in Britain said today that radiation levels could rise with more rain. It said that Britain was not yet over the worst. While the iodine 131 contamination will be relatively shortlived, it is still very dangerous and has been for the last week or more. The caesium contamination is much more serious since the half-life of caesium is some 30 years. That means that in 30 years time it will be half as dangerous as it is now. Hence, that contamination will be significant for at least half a century, and probably longer. These things are happening very long distances from Chernobyl.

What is happening around Chernobyl? That region, I understand, is quite highly settled. It includes an industrial city, Pripyat, of 25,000 people, which Pravda has described today as a ghost town. That city has had to be evacuated. There are other areas of dense population close by. As the days go on, more and more significant admissions about what happened are coming from the Russians. One of the more significant was made in Hamburg by a senior Soviet official, Mr Boris Yeltsin, who said that 50,000 people had been evacuated from their homes. He also said that the radiation levels were still so high around the Chernobyl plant that it could not be approached. According to Mr Yeltsin, on that basis it was still not possible to know exactly what had happened. Taken together these statements represent a very serious situation indeed. Later information indicates that most of the people who were evacuated from the area were not evacuated until at least 40 hours after the accident. In other words, they were obviously exposed to very high and dangerous levels of radiation for 48 hours and possibly longer. It is not good enough just to remove people from a contamination area and try to treat them afterwards. Once they have been exposed to that radiation the damage has been done.

The nature of radiation is such that 50,000 people evacuated from a high radiation area cannot in any way be considered to be safe. On the contrary, they are all at serious risk of developing radiation sickness over the next week or two. Many of them will already have shown initial symptoms and of these many will die. The degree of the danger has been indicated by the unprecedented steps taken by the Soviet Union. It has asked the Americans to send their experts on bone marrow transfusions. Such transfusions would be a last desperate measure to save people who have acute radiation sickness. It is not known how successful that method will be. On only a few occasions in the past has the technique been tried. It is also notable that the Russians have asked hospitals outside the Soviet Union for assistance in treating radiation sickness. Plainly, the situation in the Ukraine is one which the world has not experienced before and which is of enormous importance not only to the people there but to everybody on the face of the planet, particularly to countries such as ours which are in the uranium business up to their necks. My purpose in speaking in the debate today is to seek a reconsideration of this country's trafficking in uranium.

The view of the Russian experience is confirmed by the apprehension expressed by a Japanese expert on radiation, Mr Ryushi Achikawa who, after analysing food and soil samples sent to him by the Japanese Embassy in Moscow, said:
I am seriously concerned that pollution in areas within several miles from the scene may be serious.

Meanwhile, four Japanese engineers who returned from Mogilev, 300 kilometres north of Chernobyl, were found to have been exposed to low level radioactivity. Over the last week or so the Russians have been doing their level best to subdue and conceal facts which are quite appalling and harrowing and which are of deep significance to the rest of the world, including Australia. I will not pull any punches in speaking about those consequences. Much of what I have to say will be unpleasant and alarming, but it is no answer to pretend that something which is happening has not happened, especially since there is a lesson in this for every human being.

What is happening at Chernobyl is of the utmost importance to every man, woman and child in Australia, even though Chernobyl seems far away. I am speaking not of what happened when the reactor exploded or burnt but of what is happening now. At the moment in and around Chernobyl and at emergency hospitals in the Ukraine people will be dying in abject and agonising pain. That is absolutely predictable. Their hair is falling out. They vomit continually, cataracts are forming in their eyes. Wounds that will not heal are draining their life blood. Behind all this is the deadly attack of gamma radiation on their bone marrow, slowly destroying their immune system so that those people will succumb eventually to a host of infections which will prevail because of the failure of the immune system. Those of us who do not like those facts will be aware, or I hope we are, that they are thoroughly scientifically substantiated. This has happened before. It is an immense tragedy that it has happened again.

Pregnant women in that region face the appalling prospect of giving birth to babies which are virtual monsters, with gross physical deformities, serious brain damage and latent cancer. The numbers of human beings involved in this cruel fate will not be small. On any reasonable view of the facts those numbers must already run into hundreds, and with the known, demonstrated and researched progress of radiation sickness, the numbers must grow to thousands over the next weeks and months. Very many of these people will die quietly and in obscurity. The Soviet Union will see to that. But they will die nonetheless, and they will die in their thousands because of the failure of a single machine whose only merit was to produce electric power and plutonium to be used to make nuclear bombs.

The basic point for urgent consideration is our direct implication as a nation. We are conniving in these matters. We actively promote and participate in the nuclear power industry. We mine and sell uranium. We pretend to have safeguards but they are not worth the paper on which they are written. Time and again it has been demonstrated, especially since the notorious agreement on reprocessing which the Fraser Government perpetrated and the present Government has continued, that it is not possible to trace where Australian uranium goes. It is beyond doubt that, probably through Finnish reprocessing, Australian uranium is being included in Soviet nuclear weapons. If we want that sort of thing to happen we are absolutely crazy-quite insane. We try to absolve ourselves with the excuse that if we do not sell uranium somebody else will. How can that be the answer to any kind of problem? What if everyone said: `We will have an opium industry. Why shouldn't we all grow opium? Why shouldn't we flog off heroin around the world, as much as we can get, for whatever price we can get? If we don't do it somebody else will'? Where would the world be then? What sort of morality and justification is there in that? There is none at all.

For eight years the Australian Democrats have been saying in this place that what happened at Chernobyl could happen. Every time we have said it people in this place and elsewhere have said: `No, it could never happen. You are whistling in the dark. You are intimidating the public'. We have been called wicked and malicious because we have said to the public things which might frighten them. I take it that those people would prefer us to leave the Australian public like sheep in a slaughter house, ignorant of the facts until the worst has happened. We do not propose to do that. It is important that the community knows what happens when there is a nuclear accident, and knows every unpleasant, bitter truth about it, so that it can consider its morality, its viewpoint and its part in it.

I hope that I do not hear any honourable senator say again that we are excused and absolved because if we do not sell uranium somebody else will. We are one of the largest uranium producers in the world and our moral influence if we decided to cease this trafficking would be of crucial importance, especially now after the Chernobyl disaster when people who have done their homework know what is happening as those facts unfold. This is the time for the Australian Government to summon its courage, to put itself in a proper historical position, to become the Government which took an historical decision of importance and value for once and to say that we do not want to traffic in uranium any longer.

We take no pleasure in the fact that the accident at Chernobyl happened, but it has happened and I suggest that it would be the utmost folly for the Government not to take pause at this stage, to duck out on this issue and to try to ignore what has gone on, to proceed with uranium mining and trafficking in uranium just as if nothing had happened. I suggest that that would be intolerable. We are involved as a senate, a parliament and a nation. It is within our power to take a leading role in an international campaign to rid the world of its nuclear reactors, to see humanity take the necessary step back from its current insanity, and to see that a major, international research and economic effort is put into alternatives which are now becoming increasingly viable. Those things exist.

The year before last I was in Japan at the research centre of Sanyo, a large and respected company in Osaka. I was delighted and surprised at the enormous promise of current Japanese research into solar alternatives, which are already producing non-polluting, self-sustaining sources of power well up into the megawatt range. I am speaking, of course, of amorphous silicon photovoltaic cells, which are cheaper by far, especially when the economies of scale come into account, than the present silicon cells, which have to be sliced from a piece of silicon crystal grown in a laboratory or a factory. The process is now well past the research stage and is into the practical stage in Japan. To simplify it, one can spray a substance on to any substrate, plastic or metal, of any shape or size one likes, and when it is exposed to sunlight on one side it will provide electricity on the other. I was shown by the Sanyo scientists glass roof tiles made to the same size and dimensions of those currently used on Japanese houses. These tiles simply plug together on a roof and provide the houses in Tokyo with much of their electrical power-but not all of it. Natural gas will provide heating and cooking, but everything else can be got from the roof.

This is not airy fairy stuff in the future. A major Japanese manufacturer of houses is already planning to put these tiles on every house he builds within the next three years. The technology is established; it exists. It is only a matter now of putting the money, the time and the effort into it to get it into vast mass production. Those people who look at their solar-powered calculators and watches will see the very beginning of that technology. I am talking about that little brown strip that creates solar electricity. That is now being done. It is at the stage where it creates massive amounts of electricity, up to the megawatt range.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens when they get a couple of feet of snow on the tile roofs in winter?

—Senator MacGibbon has asked me what happens when people in Tokyo get a couple of feet of snow on their tile roofs. It is a good question. It takes me right to the point I was next going to make. I could not thank Senator MacGibbon more for that interjection. This technology is such that it might do something which I will commend to Senator Button. I know that Senator Button is a visionary and that he has the future welfare of the world close to his heart; I give him that much credit. I see that Senator Button is smiling because he is pleased by my comment.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, through you, I take honourable senators to the problems of the Third World, which are relevant. Around the hottest, most desert-ridden areas on our planet we have a group of countries that we call the Third World countries, which have the most appalling economic problems. I think it is not too much to say that the world's major problem is to somehow fit the economies of the Third World into a logical and sensible world economy. I ask Senator Button to try this one on: What about the prospect of providing them with an industry which would be self-sustaining, which would give them a source of income and which would be ideally suited to the places where they live? In other words, it is not necessary-I give Senator MacGibbon the credit for knowing this-for solar energy to be delivered precisely in the place where it is generated. There are many means of transporting to other places. What I have in mind in this Third World proposal is using the vehicle of hydrogen, which can be broken down and reconstituted, as honourable senators know. This has already been established. In fact, research has been done on that point in Canberra and the Australian National University, and it has reached an advanced stage. Many other areas are being considered in that way. So we certainly have a situation where solar energy could be generated in the tropical areas of the world and it could be moved quite readily and quite easily to the areas that need it most.

I think one thing is absolutely predictable. If anything like the amount of money is put into developing that technology as has been poured unsuccessfully into nuclear power, we would have no difficulty at all in establishing it as a viable alternative. After all, nuclear power is only a very small contributor to the world's energy requirements. In most parts of the world it would have no consequence at all. Unfortunately, firewood happens to be the major contributor to the world's energy needs, as statistics from the United Nations show. It is a gross indictment on the planet and everyone on it at this stage that that happens to be the case.

In the United States of America the Californian Energy Commission is already building wind generators as fast as it can. They are not only competitive with nuclear power stations but also, on the latest figures I have had from the Energy Commission in that State, they are more than competitive-better than competitive-with nuclear powerhouses, and current Californian policy is being based on that assumption. My colleague Senator Macklin recently brought forward a notice of motion in this place which drew our attention to that. As I have said, there are alternatives; not one, but several. It is not good enough for us to say that we are going to go along with a dangerous, undeveloped technology, such as that of nuclear power, with all its problems and consequences-especially now, and I stress this again. We have had one lesson. How many more do we need? If we allow the Chernobyl disaster to pass without making that kind of effort, I suggest that we will go on accepting a series of reactor disasters. Every one of them will cause the kinds of consequences that I mentioned earlier. How many people do we want to go through their lives in terror of whether or not they will incur a cancer? How many people do we actually want to incur that cancer? How many stillborn children and how many spontaneous abortions do we want before we learn sense? I know that there are people who are opposed to my view and who say that we should go on and allow more nuclear disasters will come. But the disasters will come; we all know that. No technology is perfect, as Senator Sanders has said. Predictably, those disasters will come. One aspect which I think everbody should consider most carefully is that many of the isotopes released by these accidents cannot be cleaned up in three or four days or three or four weeks, or by a big effort 20 or 30 years, like that which dealt with London smog pollution. This is not so. Some of these isotopes have half-lives going up to thousands of years. Caesium alone has a half-life of 30 years, and we know that that represents pollution for a century. Every time there is another nuclear disaster the radiation level worldwide will go up. Every time the level goes up the danger will increase. Gradually, the world's background radiation will increase to an intolerable level, at which the health of all human beings will be in constant and permanent danger. To quote the poet T. S. Eliot, for whom I know Senator Button has considerable respect, `that would be the end . . .' I see that Senator Button is smiling again. I like to see Senator Button smiling. It does good things for me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been trying all along to understand what you are talking about.
—Senator Button will understand T. S. Eliot's quotation. He will probably recall the quotation about the `end of the world, not with a bang but a whimper'.
—Eliot?

—That is right; Eliot. I am saying that he could not have put it better. I think we must make our citizens aware of the terrible consequences of nuclear accidents and the dangers of this kind of technology. At all costs we ought not to try to cover up the facts. As I have said, we ought not to keep our people in ignorance as if they were sheep grazing peacefully in the paddock until the moment comes when they are in the slaughterhouse and it is too late for us to have any influence on events.
—You have never tried evangelising, have you?

—I can see that I am getting through to Senator Button; I know him well enough to know that. That is good, because it reassures me. I believe that, underneath all that political cynicism, a heart of gold is beating away. It is good to know that. I will say this, finally, as I think it is an important point to leave in the honourable senator's mind. The degree of political cynicism and the total irresponsibility of any attitude to conceal or somehow play down the consequences of this disaster must be absolutely intolerable. My final words to Senator Button, to the Labor Government and to the Liberal and National parties are that the uranium debate is on again. It will now rise to a new level of urgency and importance. I implore any people listening to this parliamentary broadcast who have been concerned with that debate to take my words to heart. The time has come for them to make the biggest push that they can. If they do not do it nobody else will. I think people may have gathered from the interjections in this chamber that nobody in this place is particularly anxious to do it. It rests not in the hands of people in this place but in the hands of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1985-86, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1985-86. They broadly provide more money for parliamentary departments than was appropriated when the Budget was brought down in August. For the sake of brevity I wish to confine my speech to the Department of Defence. The original Budget that came down in August appropriated $6,535m and the additional appropriation lifts that amount to $6,702m. Last week I took the time to make a speech in the Senate about the apparent financial inability of this Government to meet the targets it has set with respect to forward funding of the Department of Defence. I think that this is a most serious problem. The Government did not inherit these targets; it set them and, having made them public, it is not showing that it has the ability to meet the expenditure in a planned way through the next part of the five-year plan.

SPEECH.PARA: The target for the five-year defence plan announced by the Government included the expenditure of $3 billion for additional new equipment. That does not mean that we will buy $3 billion worth of new equipment over the next five years; it means that there was provision over and above the new equipment that we have recognised for the next five years to the extent of $3 billion. The plan is gaited over a five-year period of increasing expenditure because if all the equipment comes at once we could not afford it. The program called for the expenditure of $235m on additional new equipment for the financial year 1985-86. When the Budget came down we learnt that only $77m was allocated, which left a very serious shortfall with respect to the program set by the Government.

The Government has embarked upon a policy of deferment. Two good examples of that are the purchase of the Seahawk helicopters for the Royal Australian Navy for the FFGs. The Government was a year late in making that decision so that put that expenditure into another financial year. A second example is the decision last week to buy the Blackhawks for the Royal Australian Air Force. I applaud this decision because I think it was by far the preferable choice of the two helicopters on the short list. Again that decision was a year behind schedule. So two big blocks of expenditure have been deferred a year. If this goes on we will reach a situation when all expenditure will come together and it will get quite out of hand.

Another point I raised was how the proportion of expenditure on new capital equipment had risen within the annual Budget. It has climbed from 17.4 per cent in 1982-83 to 25.9 per cent in 1985-86. The consequence of this is that there has been a rundown in capability and a rundown in the number of people in the Defence Force. This financial year alone, from a very meagre base we have reduced the defence forces by 1,049 service men and women. However, most importantly, we have cut back on our training capability, our operational readiness. This theory is fine if it is only for a finite period-if it will be for only three or four years. However, I suspect that it is a long term program and we simply do not have enough money in the defence vote to do the things that this Government has said are necessary.

The last five-year defence plan that the Fraser Government brought in was structured around a 6.3 per cent annual real growth in the defence vote. When this Government came into power it reduced that 6.3 per cent to 4.5 per cent annually and in May 1985 that 4.5 per cent was further cut to 3.1 per cent. Then without any fanfare the Department lifted its estimates at the end of last year to 3.75 per cent real growth, which is a blatant admission that the Department of Defence was able to convince Treasury that the 3.1 per cent of planned real growth was absolutely unrealistic.

This Government has claimed that on average it is increasing the defence vote by 3.3 per cent per annum. It is giving itself a big pat on the back for being so generous to the Department of Defence. However, I would argue that that amount is not enough and that the growth has not been a planned growth by this Government; it has come about accidentally because some of the new equipment programs that the Government is contracted to have resulted in equipment being supplied ahead of time. In the first year of this Government $80m of foreign military sales of defence equipment were delivered ahead of time and brought into the first financial year of this Government. Last year $62m of foreign military sales equipment under contract came ahead of its delivery time and it had to be paid for. Those two forward deliveries enabled the Government to reach the figure of 3.3 per cent. I suspect that the Department knows this very well. One of the underlying reasons why the Dibb review was set up was to give the Government a shelter to hide behind. It could say that the report from Mr Dibb recommended certain capabilities had to be cut. Everyone on this side of the Senate would have no difficulty in supporting the proposition that the capabilities we have at present are inadequate and that further cuts just could not be tolerated.

It is interesting to look at the remit from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) directing Mr Dibb to undertake his review. The first requirement was for him to undertake a review of the content, priorities and rationale of Defence forward planning in the light of the strategic and financial planning guidance endorsed by the Government. The financial planning guidance endorsed by the Government is the key part in that statement. It is the only hard condition there because strategic planning is a nebulous concept, which everyone knows. The strategic assessment that the Government gets is tailored to the views of the government of the day and it is a movable feast. However, financial planning guidance is 3 per cent of gross domestic product. It has been made very clear by the Minister for Defence that while the Australian Labor Party is in power there will never be any increase on this 3 per cent. Quite clearly, 3 per cent will not buy the ability to maintain the capabilities we have at present, let alone reach the level that we need.

The Parliament has not seen the Dibb report although the Minister and the Cabinet have been sitting on it probably for over a month or six weeks. The Australian public and those interested in defence are being conditioned by a propaganda effort coming from the Government. It started last year after the exercises at Shoalwater Bay. One correspondent wrote a big article which stated that the Leopard tanks and the armoured corps would disappear when the Dibb report came out. Since then we have had a planned campaign of conditioning the Australian public towards new concepts in defence. Proposals are being presented as new, relevant and important. In reality, it is the incorporation of long term Labor defence policies and beliefs.

I think it is a matter of great regret that this Parliament will not see the Dibb report at a time when it can debate it. Presumably the report will come down in the closing stages of this session of the Parliament-when the Parliament has no opportunity to debate it when everyone is interested in it-or, more likely, Mr Hawke or Mr Beazley will release it after the Parliament rises. When the Government releases it there will be a public outcry against it but the Parliament will be hamstrung and unable to deal with it because it will be during the parliamentary winter recess. We will not be sitting through June, July and August. By the time we come back we will be in the high drama of a Budget which will be presented on the first sitting day of the new session and the Dibb report will pass by default.

I believe that the propaganda campaign that is being run to condition the Australian public does reflect what the report will state. Obviously it will give defence a low priority. This will be garnished with the no-threat doctrine and the claim that we have 10 years to prepare for any threat. The report will clearly incorporate the Fortress Australia concept but the Minister for Defence and the Prime Minister will swear on a stack of Bibles that it does not incorporate the Fortress Australia concept. However, it will be that in reality because the Labor Party has a great xenophobia. It does not like people from other countries. There is nothing racist about that; it dislikes the Americans as much as it dislikes the Indonesians. The Labor Party is also isolationist. It would love to be non-aligned and not tied up with any alliances in any form with any other country. Insofar as the Government leans over backwards to have a defence force structure that is demonstrably not a threat to anyone, it ends up with a totally ineffectual defence force. Unfortunately the Labor Party believes in the crocodile theory. It thinks in relation to foreign affairs that if it feeds the crocodile, it will be the last to be eaten. It does not see the relevance of providing our defence forces with a strong deterrence posture.

The importance of the Dibb report should not be underestimated. We are told repeatedly that the Government will implement the Dibb report. This report is from one man who has no detailed knowledge of defence at all. He has never been in any of the Services; he has never had any involvement with defence planning, defence organisation or defence doctrine. He has a long history of strategic analysis, but that is a rather genteel game of sitting around tables and assessing options and things like that. I was horrified to learn, from unimpeachable sources, that in September last year Mr Dibb had been up to Darwin for the first time. I said: `You don't mean that, do you?', to which I received the reply: `Oh yes, we took Mr Dibb up to Darwin; he was up there for a day then we spent two days coming down in a Caribou from Darwin to Alice Springs'.

If we accept the Fortress Australia doctrine, the defence of Australia will be based in the nor'-western part of the continent. To have writing a prescription for that area someone who went up there only after he got the commission to write the report is absolutely incredible. The effect of the climate, the distances to be travelled and the logistics problems are enormous and dictate the sort of structure we have to have. Here we have someone who was raised in the gentle fields of England, where in any part of the country a pub is literally within walking distance down a leafy lane, going up to Darwin for the first time and writing a prescription for Australia's defence.

The third factor we have to look at in regard to the importance of the Dibb report is that it will be accepted by a Caucus that simply has no interest in let alone any knowledge of defence and approved by a Cabinet which again has neither interest in nor knowledge of the subject. If the conditioning is accurate, and I believe it is, we will have a very serious problem downstream. Mr Beazley has promised that the Labor Government will implement this report. If it implements this report it will create a completely inappropriate force structure for the Australian defence forces, and the consequence of that would be that any future Australian Government will find it difficult to turn it around in the short term. Most importantly, in the exercise of powers by the Government in looking after our national interests in foreign affairs and defence, the range of options open to us will be almost zero. We would cut off any effective international role for Australia if the Dibb report were introduced.

I would now like to develop a few points in a little more detail. I shall deal first with the no-threat doctrine. The no-threat doctrine has always been very dear to the Australian Labor Party. It is based in part on the naive belief that if we are no problem for anyone, no one will ever be a problem for us. That simply does not apply. We find that doctrine enshrined in Hansard. If we look in the library we find that only six months before the outbreak of the Second War in September 1939 Mr Curtin was saying on the record, in Hansard, that Australia and the world had no threats at all. Yet a few months later we were involved in the biggest conflict of arms the world has seen. That view was revived under Mr Whitlam, because Mr Whitlam, with his grandiose vision of the world, could see no threat either, and of course it has come back stronger than ever under the Hawke regime.

Tied in with the no-threat doctrine is the implicit belief that someone will ring a bell, send us a letter by registered mail, telling us in 10 years time that we will have a defence crisis on our hands. We do not have knowledge of what will happen ahead, and the history of the human race shows that 90 per cent of wars have broken out without warning to the participants beforehand. In a modern age, with the technology involved in weapons, the lead time to acquire them and to train people means that we simply do not have time to prepare. A country will finish a war with the resources it had when the war started, or a little less. I do not know what we can do to persuade the Labor Party. All I can say is that the Liberal and National parties believe in prevention. We believe we should be strong enough so that people can see that we can look after our essential interests. We will not have a bar of any no-threat doctrine. We believe that we have to be prepared to go at any time. The majority of wars start over small issues-border issues, trade routes and things like that. We are not necessarily looking at a World War III situation. As the recent Indonesian events have shown, things can happen overnight.

It is interesting to look at the region in which the Labor Party sees no threat. Just look up to the north-east, at New Caledonia. The decolonisation program there is being handled with the usual incompetence and intransigence of the French Government. It is repeating all the mistakes it made in Algeria and before that in Vietnam. One just cannot foresee what will happen in New Caledonia. We could see the separatist movement being cultivated and supported by a Soviet group, and we could see it being successful. If that happens we could have a Soviet naval base-a cherished goal of the Soviet strategic analysts-in the South Pacific. We could have an air base there. The problems that would bring for Australia are enormous. What can we do about it? Could we support the French authorities or a legitimate group in New Caledonia? Of course we could not at present because we do not have any way of getting there, of deploying air power or putting in a naval force.

I would like to look at the Fortress Australia concept because it is central to the Labor Party. It seems to believe that if we mind our own business no one will ever worry us. Of course, that does not extend to foreign affairs. The Labor Party goes around South East Asia making a damned nuisance of itself, telling every other country how to run its internal affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not how they see it.

—The problems with Indonesia are a part of that. Senator Robertson is very keen to tell the Indonesians what they might do with East Timor. He would be very upset if the Indonesians came in and made some suggestions about how Premier Wran should run New South Wales. Fortress Australia is rooted in part on this isolationist theory of the Labor Party. It is all very well to be self-reliant and self-sufficient, and I believe that that is a primary condition bearing upon us. But we see the Minister for Defence in interview after interview talking about the great moat that surrounds Australia, as though no one can overcome it. He tells us how the Japanese could not get here in 1942 and 1944. That was a different time, a different age and different technology. The geographic isolation of Australia is an advantage but it is not an insuperable barrier to anyone who wants to come here. The point is that we cannot be a fortress. We cannot lock ourselves up, close the door on the castle and live inside. It is not true to say that we can feed ourselves and clothe ourselves so the rest of the world can go to blazes. We have to be able to move through the region; we have to know what is going on there. At the end of the day, no isolated fortress in the history of mankind has survived. We cannot isolate ourselves from the world.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to the fundamental difference between the Liberal and National parties and the Labor Party. We do not believe that we can go it alone. We do not believe in this myth of self-sufficiency. Again the Minister, in relation to part of the Dibb report, says that we are technologically superior to other counties and we are one of the few countries in the world to which the United States will sell the latest mark 48 torpedo and Harpoon missile. That is perfectly true. Then the Minister goes on to say, however, that as soon as we become self-sufficient we will cut the links with the United States, ignoring completely the fact that technology goes on and on. While the mark 48 torpedo and the Harpoon might be the latest weapons at present, in five years time there will be another generation which Australian industry will not have developed.

Above all, Australia needs to recognise that its defence turns on a recognition of the fact that we are part of the region. There is not much point in going on with the sort of foreign affairs that this Government has practised of alienating everyone in the region. We want to build links and be friendly with the nations in the region. We must have alliances. We must support the United States through the ANZUS alliance, and I believe that that alliance puts a duty on us to perform. It is not only a guarantee that if things go bad the United States will come to help us. It is an alliance that puts an obligation on Australia to play its part in the security of the region. That regional security is determined not by the numbers of men or women in uniform in Australia. It turns on having good relationships and the ability to deploy Australian forces as required, either as single services or as joint services, to help countries in the South East Asia region when they ask us for help, so that through the whole of the island barrier north of Australia we set up a net of friendly, co-operative powers. If that happens our security will be ensured.

Turning to the consequences of the Dibb report in detail, I advert first to the way in which the Government has handled the morale of the Services. In my life I have never known a time when the Australian Defence Force was in worse shape from a morale point of view than it is at present. One can see that in the resignation rates, which have gone to record levels. The Government's policy makes it very clear to every serviceman and servicewoman: `We don't want you and we are not interested in your problems'. The advertisement published in all the major Australian dailies on 2 April with the slogan `Thank you gentlemen, your services are no longer required' in reference to an article on defence in the Bulletin struck a responsive chord with every serviceman and servicewoman in Australia. They knew that was where they stood with this Labor Government. They see no point in being in the Services when they do not know where they are going.

To deal with a few more detailed points in the Dibb report, I have every sympathy with the Navy and for the Chief of Naval Staff. This year marks the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy. Admiral Hudson will be the first Chief of Naval Staff to preside over the castration of the Australian Navy. The Navy has a bunch of old surface ships that it will not be allowed to replace. Despite what the Minister might say about having the technological edge in the region, Australia is outclassed by the Indonesians in surface ship capability. We are overwhelmed by the Soviets. Do honourable senators realise that the Soviet Pacific naval fleet is the largest of all the Soviet navies? In a few years time, in 1990, we will see the deployment of the 70,000-tonne nuclear powered conventional aircraft carrier and a Soviet carrier battle group in the Pacific region. They are not there for tourism, or to get leis around their neck when they go to Fiji.

What do we find from Mr Dibb? Mr Dibb, who has spent the short while he has been in Australia ridiculing and deriding the growing influence of the Soviet Navy in the Pacific region, is hardly likely now to admit that he has made a mistake and say: `We cannot run down the Navy'. Of course, we shall cut it down. We shall make it just a brown water fleet, fit for harbour protection duty with a submarine force so small that it will be ineffectual. The Navy must be able to protect surface shipping; it must be able to project power. We need a new generation of surface ships capable of giving ASW support to other ships, which means that they have to embark ASW helicopters. We do not have the ability in Australia today to get one of our Sea King anti-submarine helicopters to sea. If we cannot do that we cannot have an effective anti-submarine capability. We have no helicopter lift capability to put a force ashore. We have no air superiority since the carrier has been abandoned. I was opposed to buying the Invincible-not because it was a carrier, but because it was equipped with the Sea Harrier. I do not view the Sea Harrier as an adequate aircraft for air superiority. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the Minister that on Monday the Opposition put to the Prime Minister that the appropriate course of action was for Mr Justice Murphy to resign and that, failing that, a judicial inquiry be established. In view of the extraordinary developments since and the pressure these developments have placed on those who have sought to do their duty and on the very institution of the High Court of Australia, will the Government now do its duty, address itself to the gravity of the situation and implement the recommendation that was put to the Prime Minister by the Opposition at the beginning of the week by immediately establishing an inquiry into all outstanding issues relating to Mr Justice Murphy?

—I understand the question based on the saga of events which has taken place in the last week. The Attorney-General will be making a statement about this matter to the House of Representatives in the next few minutes, to which I have nothing to add.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Attorney-General is to make a statement and given the importance of this matter, will the Minister representing the Prime Minister or the Minister representing the Attorney-General also make that statement in this place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement which will be made by the Attorney-General in the other place is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I wish to advise the House that the Government intends to place before the House a Bill to establish a parliamentary commission of inquiry into various matters relating to the alleged conduct of Mr Justice Murphy. In reaching this decision it has had full regard to the necessity of the standing and integrity of the High Court to be properly protected. The Government will proceed with this matter as expeditiously as the constraints of legislative drafting and parliamentary process allow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an article in yesterday's Courier-Mail in which Mr Don Cameron, the Liberal member for Moreton, is reported as claiming that the fringe benefits tax will cost a Brisbane charity $1,500 a year for a car used to help transport blind people? Those activities would not be subject to the tax. The only part of vehicle usage to which the tax applies, be it a company car or whatever, is private usage. Going by the description contained in the article, there is very little, if any at all, private usage of that vehicle. —Order! I think the Minister is exceeding the bounds of standing order 418 in making that imputation against a member of another House. I suggest that he withdraw it.

—I withdraw the reference to misleading. It is, however, a fact that the former member for Fadden picked up nearly that amount of money as a lump sum, virtually free of tax. If the honourable member for Moreton fails to understand a matter as simple as the facts concerning this charity and the use of a car, I suggest that members of the organisation of which he is President might do well to elect a president with a greater degree of comprehension and responsibility.

—My question also is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I note Senator Button's answer to the previous question about this matter. —It is, of course, true that--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. —Come off it, Don!
—I would have thought that Senator Lewis would have had his fair share of politicking on this. He has been given a fair go. Mr President, I ask you to rule on this matter.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I am conscious of the operation of the sub judice rule in terms of asking questions. —On the point of order, Mr President, I simply say that I am sure that there is no formal reason why the question should not be asked. I do not think there is any basis for ruling the question out of order. —I will allow the question. When Senator Button made his statement in reply to Senator Chaney, I immediately became quite conscious of the type of problem that is posed by the point of order taken by Senator Chipp. However, it is not the Chair's desire to restrict Parliament's activities too unduly. Whilst I have taken on board the point that Senator Chipp has made, I intend to allow the question on the basis that the Minister will answer the question appropriately. However, any other questions related to this matter will be watched carefully by the Chair.

—I am not able to accede to Senator Puplick's request that I answer the question, without inducing some degree of conflict. Senator Grimes and I did go to see Mr Justice Murphy on Monday.
