—I direct a question to the Minister for Education. My question relates to the editorial in the March 1986 newsletter of the Queensland branch of the Australian Medical Association, a copy of which I have passed to the Minister. The editorial refers to the Regional Convention on the Recognition of Studies, Diplomas and Degrees in Higher Education in Asia and the Pacific. Disregarding the poor attempts at sarcasm in the editorial, will the Minister advise whether `a flood of overseas doctors' is likely to occur, as suggested in the editorial? Will the Minister advise the Senate of the way in which it is expected that the Regional Convention will operate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no reason whatsoever to believe that a flood of overseas doctors will occur as suggested in the editorial of the Newsletter. There is no requirement under the Convention for Australia to be forced to accept overseas qualifications as equivalent to our own simply because they have the same name. They must first be assessed by the appropriate assessing authorities in Australia as being of equal value. The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention is designed to encourage the evaluation by contracting states of higher education qualifications earned in other countries. The purpose of this Convention and the other UNESCO regional conventions is the praiseworthy one of facilitating the international movement of research workers, students and people working in the professions by removing any unnecessary barriers to the acceptance of their qualifications. The appropriate assessing authorities in Australia were referred to in the statement made by Australia at the time of accession to the UNESCO Convention. That statement was quoted in the newspaper article. It refers directly to professional bodies such as the Australian Medical Association and their responsibility for determining the recognition to be given to qualifications whether obtained in Australia or overseas for the purposes of registration or permission to practise a profession.

ANSWER.PARA: National legislation was not considered a necessary requirement of Australian accession to the Convention. Australia already has in existence national bodies, in particular the Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications and the Australian Council on Tertiary Awards, to assist the Commonwealth in transmitting the text of the Convention to the institutions and the authorities concerned and in using its best endeavours to obtain their co-operation.

Australian accession to the Convention can be of direct benefit to Australia as well as encouraging international co-operation. Some countries do not accept qualifications from some or all Australian tertiary institutions. In these cases such decisions may be based on nothing more than a lack of information about the courses offered by the relevant Australian institution. The Convention may be seen as an umbrella under which this situation can be overcome through more informed and therefore better assessment of tertiary qualifications.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. Has the Minister seen the article in today's Canberra Times detailing apparent deficiencies in the Cameron Offices complex in Belconnen which have led to 177 water leaks being identified in the nine buildings of the complex, 47 of which leaks are said to be jeopardising the personal safety of occupants? I am advised by the Minister that discussions have been held between the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, the Department of Territories and the Department of Housing and Construction, that the Department of Housing and Construction will carry out an extensive program of remedial work at the Cameron Offices, and that funding for the work has been sought in the context of the 1986-87 Budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is the Minister aware that a month ago in Sydney the price of petrol was 57.5c a litre? Two weeks ago it was possible to buy petrol at 39.8c a litre. Last Sunday morning one garage in the inner city was selling petrol at 46.9c a litre. Two and a half hours later the same garage was selling petrol at 49.9c a litre. Can the Minister explain why the prices fluctuate so much within very short periods? What do the price levels and the price fluctuations say about the profit level of the petrol companies, regardless of the level of government excise? In view of the impact on the consumer price index, should there not be a public inquiry into the profit margins of petrol companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It ought to be said at the outset that price discounting in fact may indicate very little about the profit levels of petrol companies as all these companies, importers, distributors and/or retail outlets, may decide to trade at minimal profit or at a loss in order to retain their market share. The phenomenon of the major refining and distribution companies making substantial losses has not been unknown in recent years. Nonetheless it must be said that some of the discounting that have been going on in recent months, in circumstances in which there have not always been shipments of imported product by independents to explain the market going down, sits rather oddly with some of the claims that have been made by refining companies about the extreme financial stress that they have been put under as a result of stock losses attributable to the decline in petroleum prices.

ANSWER.PARA: That having been said, it has to be acknowledged that all these companies operate in a highly competitive environment and one in which very substantial concessions are often made by the refiners to retailers in order to maintain market share as well as, of course, by the retailers themselves where that is possible. All of this is essentially beyond the capacity of the Commonwealth to control by its legislative authority. That authority lies essentially with the States, as I have had to say on numerous previous occasions. The Prices Surveillance Authority does not exercise mandatory controls but only recommendatory ones. In any event it deals only with wholesale price levels, rather than retail levels. There have been a number of inquiries in recent years into the petroleum industry and the phenomenom of discounting, particularly as it has occurred in highly competitive metropolitan markets. As well as the regular price assessments by the PSA and its predecessors, the Prices Justification Tribunal and the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority, there have been a number of wide-ranging inquiries by these and other bodies. It is unlikely-this has been the Government's position on this matter-that anything constructive would be achieved by setting up yet another inquiry into petrol prices, although I do take very much on board the concerns that have been expressed by Senator Childs which reflect widespread concern in the community as to just what on earth is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Community Services aware that the home nursing service in the Australian Capital Territory has closed its books to all new patients because of excessive work loads and has announced that those books will remain closed to all new cases, even the most desperate cases? I ask the Minister whether this is happening all around Australia as a result of excessive work loads in the home nursing service. How does the Minister justify his answer of 20 February this year that the Commonwealth is `presently taking all action possible to achieve improvements in the provision of domiciliary care services'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the report in the newspaper this morning concerning the home nursing services in the Australian Capital Territory. I have asked for a report on this, even though it is not directly my responsibility. Certainly when I get that report I will reply to Senator Lewis. No, this is not happening all around Australia. In fact, although there were incidents in New South Wales the year before last of the New South Wales Government restricting the capacity of people to get assistance under the home nursing service, it has not happened since.

ANSWER.PARA: My answer in February holds and will continue to hold. We have developed a home and community care program in conjunction with the State governments. As a result of this program more Commonwealth money has gone into home and community care, including domiciliary nursing. In other words, there is more money going into that area than there was before this Government introduced that program, and we will continue to combine with the States to provide improvements in all sorts of domiciliary services, including nursing care. Of course, the development of such a program takes time, but in the short time that we have been working in conjunction with the States there has been considerable addition to and improvement of existing domiciliary services. I know that we will be able to continue to do that as the years pass, so that we can get more people cared for at home and have fewer people in institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question arising out of that answer. If it is not happening in the States, why should it be happening in the Australian Capital Territory, where the Commonwealth has the sole responsibility?

—As I said to Senator Lewis, I noted the report in the newspaper this morning. I have asked for a report on this, even though it is not my direct responsibility. When I get a report I will respond to Senator Lewis and I hope that is very soon.

—Did the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry see the report in yesterday's Australian entitled `Rural gloom prophecy has provoked crisis'? In that report it was suggested that the rural task force set up by the Government has found that rural organisations have made bleak prophecies which are responsible for the poor price of land. Can the Minister confirm that in his view the gloomy predictions of some rural organisations and the Opposition are one of the major causes of the drop in farm prices?

—I do not think I saw the specific report to which Senator Foreman referred, but I am aware of statements some time ago by Mr Kerin pointing out that the descriptions such as `rural disaster' frequently used by the President of the National Farmers Federation to describe the present agricultural downturn are helping to fulfil the very predictions Mr McLachlan makes; that is, that there will be a fall in land prices to an unsustainably low level from a previously unsustainably high level. Mr McLachlan is certainly not doing the people he purports to represent any service in pursuing his own political obsessions or political egomania in the way he has been doing. I have noted also some very sensible comments from the honourable member for McMillan, Barry Cunningham, who is the chairman of the Government backbench rural task force, very similar to those made by Mr Kerin. In conclusion, it needs to be stated again that people such as Ian McLachlan are doing a disservice to the people they purport to represent in pushing land prices down to levels much lower than they ought to be. One can only speculate on whether Mr McLachlan's behaviour should be attributed to culpable ignorance or a desire to push land prices down so that he can gobble up a bit more.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Is it a fact that there are approximately 94,000 outstanding appeals against taxation assessments? Has the Commissioner of Taxation recently been calling in hundreds of taxpayers with disputed assessments seeking compromise settlements? Does this indicate a massive attempt to clean up the list of outstanding appeals before the introduction of a new system of appeals under the control of the legalistic Administrative Appeals Tribunal which will limit the rights of taxpayers to appeal against assessments?

—The figure of 94,000, from memory, if it is not correct, approximates the figure I have seen recently, but this qualification should be added: A large number of those cases would be cleaned up almost immediately once a test case had been determined. Therefore, the backlog is not nearly so formidable as it would appear to be just looking at the numbers. As to whether the Commissioner has been calling in hundreds of taxpayers to reach compromise settlements recently, I do not know. I will ask the Treasurer to get a response from the Commissioner.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women and arises from the results of a Federal Bureau of Labour Market Research study of 3,000 young out of work Australians reported in today's Canberra Times. There being few surprises among the findings of this survey, what measures are being taken by the Government to redress and, if possible, eliminate the psychological trauma of unemployment which the survey identified, especially among young women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the survey showing the extent of unemployment, particularly among young women. Obviously, although the Government is pleased that progress has been made in this area, there is no doubt that significant problems remain. Since March 1983 when the Labor Government came to power the unemployment rates for young women in the 15 to 19 and 20 to 24 years age groups have steadily decreased. In March 1983 the unemployment rate for young women aged 15 to 19 was 25.6 per cent; by February 1986 it had decreased to 22.7 per cent. For young women aged 20 to 24 the rate of unemployment has decreased from 12.5 per cent in March 1983 to 11.2 per cent in February this year. Over the past year over half of the increase in employment has been in women's employment, half of which has been in full time jobs. An additional 25,000 young women aged 20 to 24 were employed in February 1986 compared with March 1985.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has demonstrated its concern about unemployment among young women by taking a number of steps to achieve the improvements I have described and with the intention of further improving the employment prospects of young women. Within the community employment program the Government has achieved its target of 50 per cent employment of women, many of whom are young women. The Government's affirmative action legislation, requiring all higher education institutions and private sector employers of more than 100 persons to report annually on plans for providing equality of opportunity, will improve opportunities for women of all ages, including those under 25. The Government's traineeship scheme for young people is based on equity principles and young women are expected to take up approximately 60 per cent of the places.

The Commonwealth provides funds for technical and further education initiatives to increase young women's access to trade and other types of training where women are underrepresented. The youth affairs conference has recently established a working party on young women on which the Commonwealth is represented. The working party will address issues related to the employment prospects of young women and will advise the Youth Ministers Council on priorities and courses of action. There are other measures with which no doubt Senator Giles is familiar, but all in all the significant progress that has been made in addressing these problems will be accelerated by the measures I have just described.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I know the Government is concerned about our relations with Indonesia and I hesitate somewhat to raise the matter of General Dharsono and Mr Adnam Buyung Nasution. However, the matter raises issues of human rights so important that I feel it ought to be considered. Is it true, as detailed in a recent edition of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program Indian Pacific, General Dharsono, a former Secretary-General of the Association of South East Asian Nations and a widely respected person internationally, raised in a White Paper the grievances of Moslem leaders following the actions of the Indonesian army in putting down Moslem riots in Jakarta in 1984? Has the General been convicted, in an apparently politicised trial, of subversion and sentenced to 10 years gaol because he wrote that White Paper, which sought to establish the facts of what happened? Is it true that because of his normal and reasonable professional efforts to defend General Dharsono, one of the best known lawyers in Indonesia, Mr Adnam Buyung Nasution, a human rights activist and founder of the Legal Aid Institute in Jakarta, was castigated by the judge and is now under threat of being disbarred? Will the Government ask the Indonesian Government to consider the human rights issues involved in this matter and consider a retrial of General Dharsono and a reassessment of the position of Mr Nasution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Retired Lieutenant-General Dharsono was a signatory to a White Paper which raised a number of grievances about the actions of the Indonesian Army in its handling of the Tandjung Priok riots. Lieutenant-General Dharsono was convicted on charges of subversion on 8 January this year and was sentenced to 10 years gaol, minus 14 months detention. Dharsono has appealed against that decision. During the reading of the decision against Dharsono, it is the case that his defence lawyer, Buyung Nasution, made a vocal protest against the presence in the court of a policeman. As a result of this protest the Central Djakarta District Court which heard the Dharsono case wrote to the Minister of Justice recommending the revocation of Mr Nasution's licence to practice. No decision has yet been announced by the Minister of Justice.

ANSWER.PARA: The concern of the Australian Government for the promotion of the protection of human rights internationally, including in Indonesia, is well known to the Indonesian authorities. The Government has not hesitated to express its concern about individual cases where this has been warranted. I note that Lieutenant-General Dharsono has been tried and convicted under due process of Indonesian law and that an appeal is pending. No decision has yet been taken, as I have said, to revoke Mr Nasution's licence. While the Government is not in a position to judge whether Mr Nasution gave due respect to the court, it is aware of his reputation as a human rights advocate and certainly hopes that he will be able to continue to practise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services tell me what has been the response of local government to announcements by the Minister on future arrangements for Commonwealth general purpose financial assistance for local government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob has asked me a question about the reaction of local government to the Government's proposals for grants to that important third arm of government. There has been a very positive reaction, and my colleague the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services has already received congratulatory statements from the Australian Council of Local Government Associations, the Local Government and Shires Association of New South Wales, the Metropolitan Municipal Association of Victoria, and from numerous mayors, presidents, town clerks and elected representatives of local government authorities throughout Australia. I particularly want to draw attention to a letter received by the Minister on 15 April 1986. The President of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations sent the Minister a copy of a letter he wrote to the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. Amongst other things it says:

ANSWER.PARA: The ALGA wishes to place on record local government's appreciation of the Government's decision to accept the broad thrust of the report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance and to provide a real terms minimum guarantee in respect of funding for the next 2 years. Your decision on the funding level is especially welcome given the widespread recognition of the fact that the 1986-87 Budget is being framed in a difficult economic climate.

The Government's decision is to continue untied funding to local government and to ensure that funding is at least equivalent to that for the States in the long term. There is a guarantee that for the next two years local government will not receive less than last year in real terms, and in subsequent years local government will be receiving the same treatment as the States.

The Government has accepted the majority decision of the report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance and the letters from the President of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations recognises this. I am quite sure that when members of parliament make contact with the local government authorities in their electorates-whether they be senators or members of the House of Representatives-they will find great support for this Government's proposed Local Government Financial Assistance Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the statement made in today's Courier-Mail that the Leader of the Queensland Opposition, Mr Warburton, told cane growers yesterday in Nambour that he was not happy with the Federal Government's performance on the sugar issue and that the Hawke Government should stop arguing with the State Government and give the sugar industry the money it had been promised. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any such statement having been made by Mr Warburton. I am, however, aware of a report in today's Courier-Mail which states:

ANSWER.PARA: Innisfail canegrowers have accused the Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, of being out of touch with the reality of the local sugar industry.

Grower leaders from Goondi and South Johnstone mill areas yesterday slammed a proposal by the Premier to divide the Goondi cane supply principally between Babinda co-operative and Howard Smith's Mourilyan mill.

The report goes on in a similar vein. I am not aware of any report in the Courier-Mail about Mr Warburton. I am, however, aware of the fact that Mr Warburton made a comment this morning in which he drew attention to the fact that the most recent opinion poll in Queensland shows that the Queensland electorate now is ready to tip out the Bjelke-Petersen Government and either elect a Labor government or some sort of coalition government. Either way, it will see an end to the 20-year reign of misrule in Queensland under the Bjelke-Petersen regime.

Senator Boswell mentioned $240 a tonne. I am aware that in his irresponsible spending spree tour through north Queensland a couple of weeks ago, the Leader of the Opposition promised to underwrite a price of $240 a tonne. That would cost an additional $30m-additional to the undertaking this Government has given, subject to the Queensland Government doing its bit and pulling its weight, which is $30m additional to the $1.5 billion which the Leader of the Opposition has already promised as he sprays his promises and rhetoric around Australia, thereby confirming as Opposition Leader the record he established as Treasurer, that is, the most fiscally irresponsible Treasurer the country has ever seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen claims repeatedly made by members of the new Right that the economic policies of the Government favour big business and organised labour, but leave small businesses and self-employed people out in the cold? Is there any factual basis for the assertions that the self-employed in the non-farm sector of the economy have failed to share in the benefits provided by the economic policies of the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is certainly no evidence to support that assertion, but there is some evidence to the contrary. Between 1981-82 and 1982-83 the number of self-employed persons in the non-farm sector of the Australian economy shrank. The average real incomes of the non-farm self-employed fell by 8 per cent. In making these sorts of comparisons it is, of course, prudent to isolate the farm sector, the incomes of which fluctuate quite widely for seasonal reasons, among others, from the rest of the self-employed sector.

ANSWER.PARA: In the period since the present Government came to office the number of persons in self-employment in the non-farm sector has expanded and is now at an all time high level. If one looks at the incomes of the non-farm self-employed sector one sees that between 1982-83 and 1984-85 the average incomes of Australia's non-farm self-employed rose by over 16 per cent nominal or 2 per cent real. It is worth noting that over the same period the average incomes of non-farm wage and salary earners, measured on the same national accounts basis, rose by 12 per cent-that is, at the same time that the non-farm wage and salary earners experienced a decline in real incomes of 2 per cent, the non-farm self-employed had real income increases of the same magnitude. So the economic policies of the present Government are providing benefits for all Australian workers, employees and self-employed alike, and from those figures the self-employed have been beneficiaries to a greater extent than the employed, although, of course, it is possible that they came from a very low base to which they had been driven by the irresponsible former Treasurer in the Fraser Government.

If people like Katharine West, for example, and others among the ever growing number of what Ross Gittins described the other day as the extra-parliamentary pretenders to the leadership of the Liberal Party of Australia did a bit of economic homework instead of relying on empty and inflammatory rhetoric they would know that it was the years when Mr Howard was Treasurer which were a disaster for Australia's self- employed and that there has been a significant recovery from that low point that the self-employed people in Australia reached during Mr Howard's treasurership. I have previously referred to Katharine West's profound ignorance of Australian economic history in the more distant sense. It would appear that her ignorance of more recent Australian economic history is equally profound.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that at the Collinsville coal mine in Queensland, which is operated by Mount Isa Mines Ltd, three Clydesdale horses are still employed, two of them underground, and that the company claims that the retention in employment of these equines is no longer necessary and can no longer be justified given the advent of more modern methods of production? Is the Minister also aware that the miners union in Queensland is objecting to the retrenchment of the Clydesdales, is threatening to take strike action, and that already three court hearings have been held over the issue and a fourth is scheduled for 11 June? Will the Minister give an assurance that he will not say `neigh' to having the Government do what it can to assist settlement of this incredible dispute? More seriously, is this not an example of the type of industrial disputation that is totally contrary to the interests of this nation?
—I did not know all those things. If they are all true I would say that it seems to me that the Queensland National Party does not have a monopoly of idiocy in Queensland.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to reports of a case before the New South Wales Industrial Commission regarding two male employees of the St George Building Society Ltd who are being forced to retire at age 60. Is it true that these men are being forced to retire prematurely because it is believed that, as veterans who served in a theatre of war, they are eligible for the service pension at age 60? If so, what is his attitude to this practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of questions have been asked of me in recent times about the attitude taken by companies in respect of persons who are veterans and have reached the age of 60. In respect of the matters raised by Senator Richardson, I deplore the decision taken by the St George Building Society on its early retirement policy which discriminates against veterans. It is my understanding that these two men, Barry Morris and Dom Arrivolo, who are both employees of the St George Building Society, are being forced against their will into premature retirement because management believes they would be entitled to the service pension at the age of 60. I believe that these men have taken their case to the New South Wales Industrial Commission. Mr Morris has also written to me to alert me to what he believes-I totally agree with him-to be a case of discrimination against veterans.

ANSWER.PARA: This is not the first case that has come to my attention. In 1983 Senator Colston asked me about a similar case that took place in Queensland. I should add that offending employers in this regard have come from both the public and the private sectors. I regard this practice as wrong and discriminatory on two grounds. Firstly, it discriminates against war veterans because if they do not have war service they would not be eligible for the pension at age 60 and therefore would not be forced into early retirement. They could have been members of the Defence Force but they might not have had active war service. Secondly, the companies engaging in this practice are, in effect, throwing the burden on to the Commonwealth-that is, the taxpayer-to meet the costs of their labour-shedding practices when these costs should be met from their own resources. The injustice is compounded in the case of Mr Morris and Mr Arrivolo because, as I understand it, one of them would qualify for only a small part of the service pension at age 60 due to his wife's casual earnings, while the other does not have the necessary overseas service to qualify for the service pension.

The St George Building Society is well known, Mr President. It operates very extensively in the area where we both live. It is trying to project a caring public image in its attitude to upward pressures on home loan interest rates, but this image sits poorly with its approach to staff relations and particularly on the issue of forced early retirement. I can only say that perhaps the ex-service community should in future weigh its decisions as to whether to continue to patronise the St George Building Society rather less on its public image and rather more on its attitudes to veterans on its own staff. I would not go so far as to suggest a boycott, but it is a very unsatisfactory attitude that has been taken by the Building Society to long-standing members of its staff, and it is an attitude which the Government thoroughly deplores.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to a statement made by the Prime Minister last week that the delay in reaching a decision on the so-called productivity claim now before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission would act as a `circuit breaker' on the wage inflation spiral. Does the Minister agree that the delay in reaching the decision is helpful in reducing inflation? If so, would he agree that the longer the delay the better? Would he also agree that the abandonment of the claim altogether is the best option if the aim is to reduce inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I do not have the figures here. I suppose what ultimately sticks in the craw of Opposition members about all of this is that, having been the singularly most unsuccessful government in terms of restraining wages in 1981 and 1982, if they study the figures and the economic quarterly reports they will see, I think, that in every quarter since mid-1983 there has been a significant drop in real unit labour costs in Australia and that did not happen for the years in which they were in government. I think they should look at those figures. I am quite happy to bring them in tomorrow. If Senator Parer were to consult them, it might help him in a general education sense. Senator Parer should not get up to ask a supplementary question; I am still here.

ANSWER.PARA: I will now come to the important part of his question. I simply make the point again that, because delays have arisen in the national wage case and for other reasons, there will be only one significant wage increase this financial year. That is extraordinary. Overall economic management in a difficult situation, particularly with the Australian trade balance and so on, seems to be desirable and to have certain benefits. The honourable senator invites me-with mischievous intent-to extend my intellectual charity in going thus far to launch forth upon a much wider proposition which is singularly insupportable, having regard to the number of factors which have to be managed to secure wage restraint and a better wage outcome. I remind the honourable senator that, as I said at the beginning of my answer, it is sometimes said that nothing succeeds like success. In the case of this Opposition, nothing hurts like success-and we have had it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be aware of calls at the Tokyo summit for an effective international arrangement to respond urgently to nuclear accidents, particularly when these accidents have an effect beyond the borders of any one nation. Is it a fact that whilst the International Atomic Energy Agency has strict safety standards for the nuclear industry, these standards are not mandatory and are often not observed in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? Has the Chernobyl disaster revealed both the need for a mandatory international nuclear safety standard and also the inadequacy of emergency relief procedures, including the release of information? Can the Minister indicate what steps the Australian Government is taking to establish international arrangements that will ensure a co-ordinated international response in the case of any emergency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Internat- ional Atomic Energy Agency has done a vast amount of work over the last 25 years in developing detailed guidelines on nuclear safety and they provide the basis of the safety standards in Australia and other Western countries. But those guidelines are not internationally binding and, to put it mildly, I understand that they are not regarded as binding in the Soviet Union. The Chernobyl accident has clearly demonstrated the need for an early warning and notification system and for international agreements for emergency assistance in the event of nuclear accidents, as I have said in answers to questions and in debates in the last few days. Australia has supported such measures in the past but previous efforts have not received the necessary level of international support. We support the call by the Tokyo summit for effective international arrangements. Nuclear safety standards are also an important area for international action.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is in close contact with a range of countries on these matters and with the Director-General of the Atomic Energy Agency, Dr Blix. We are developing a comprehensive approach to early international action. The nuclear energy agency of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development will hold a special meeting on 9 May, at which Australia will be represented. The first opportunity for a broad, multilateral discussion will be at the June meeting of the IAEA board of governors, of which Australia is a member. We shall be consulting other members of the board over coming weeks to ensure that action is taken at that meeting to set in train the necessary machinery to establish an international convention dealing with nuclear accidents. I have also mentioned in this place that I have had discussions on this subject with one of my Japanese counterparts in the last few days with a view to getting support from that country for an initiative of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry whether, in the light of his answer to a previous question asked by Senator Foreman earlier today and in the light of Mr Kerin's statement of 21 April that it was `hogwash' to assert that Australia was witnessing the demise of the family farm, the Minister is aware of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics figures published in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning of a predicted 18 per cent fall of net farm produce in 1986-87 on top of the 31 per cent fall this year. If he is aware of that-and I doubt it-how does he reconcile those answers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not see any problem. But before going to the substance of the question, the 18 per cent figure reflects anticipated volume changes as well as prices. As I noted in a completely different answer, changes in farm incomes from year to year do not reliably reflect the underlying economic position of agriculture because they are subject to seasonal factors. As for Mr Kerin's statement that those who were predicting the demise of the family farm were mouthing hogwash, I entirely endorse that. I do not believe that the family farm is finished. If Senator Brownhill and his National Party colleagues believe that it is, they should say so and say that, therefore, every family farmer should sell up quickly while he can get any price above zero dollars for the farm and get out. I notice that those opposite are not saying that, so they do not believe that statement either. In the same comment by Mr Kerin, incidentally, he put to rest a number of other quite false or ill-informed assertions that are being made about agriculture. It is unfortunate that the comment was reported grossly out of context and in a typically unprofessional manner by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and mindlessly repeated in other sections of the Press.

ANSWER.PARA: Concerning the reference to my earlier answer, the assertion which is being made by Mr McLachlan and by most of Senator Brownhill's colleagues, if not by Senator Brownhill, is that because land prices have fallen-and some fall in land prices was necessary from the previously unsustainably high speculative levels-the equity which many farmers hold in their farms has reached the point where they are no longer viable. That is highly challengeable because what determines whether farmers are viable is the ability of the farm to generate income rather than its equity level. If a farmer has high equity, he may have the capacity to borrow more funds but the real determinant of viability is whether the farm has the income-generating potential to service existing financial and other obligations. That having been identified as a problem by some people, it follows axiomatically that statements by Senator Brownhill and his colleagues, people who say that the demise of the family farm is imminent-which Mr Kerin has quite rightly denied-are exacerbating the problem. Just as over-optimistic predictions talk land prices up, Senator Brownhill and his colleagues are now engaged in talking land prices down. They have talked them up to unsustainably high levels and are now trying to talk them down to unsustainably low levels.

One wonders whether some of the big land-holders in the National Country Party and one or two other organisations are doing this quite maliciously and consciously because they want to grab and gobble up a few more thousand acres at bargain prices to add to the millions that they already own. That question should be asked seriously. The effects of that sort of talking down of expectations about agriculture may spill beyond agriculture. They spill into the industries which supply farm machinery. Today's West Australian says that Mr Sandy Lewis-who, incidentally, is a Liberal Party member of the Legislative Council in Western Australia and who doubles as the Secretary of the Western Australian and Australian Farm Machinery Dealers Association-had stated that industry problems had been compounded because they had been `talked down' too far. I suggest to Senator Brownhill, his National Party colleagues, Ian McLachlan and anybody else who is doing this, that if they really want to do something for the people they purport to represent, they should cease using inflammatory and exaggerated rhetoric, cease asserting that the demise of the family farm is imminent, cease talking down land prices, and cease talking down expectations about agriculture's future, as they have been doing-and, in so doing, helping to exacerbate what they say is the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from the Minister's answer that he says that there is no rural crisis?

—If I recall correctly, crisis, by definition, is the point immediately preceding the point of change. I do not know whether we are now in that period immediately preceding the point of change. I would have thought actually that it is probably a year or two away before the well-known, though not regular, cyclical pattern of fluctuation in agriculture turns around. On that definition I do not think there is a crisis. There is certainly a quite serious downturn in farm incomes, as there has been on a number of occasions before. The most recent and very serious one was in 1969, 1970 and 1971, when a Liberal-National Party coalition government was in power incidentally, when precisely the same sort of dismal predictions were being made by precisely the same sort of people who are still making them. They were wrong then; they are wrong again. But if they are determined to try to convince family farmers around Australia that there is no future for the family farm, that they should get out and sacrifice the farm for any price above zero, let that be on their own heads.

—Earlier today in Question Time Senator Parer asked me a question about labour costs. In connection with the answer I gave I refer him to pages 12 and 13 of the Treasury Round-up for April 1986. The graph on page 12 indicates what has happened to labour costs under this Government. If the honourable senator looks at page 13 he will find that real unit labour costs have reduced each quarter, as I indicated in my answer to his question, varying in reductions between minus 0.1 per cent and minus 4.5 per cent.

He is aware of advice having been prepared by his Department in relation to the constitutional power of the Commonwealth to control logging operations but does not propose to disclose the contents of that advice.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRANS AUSTRALIA AIRLINES: CHANGE OF NAME

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last month Senator Coates asked me about the proposed change of name for Trans Australia Airlines. The Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) has provided me with the following answer. The Chairman of the Australian National Airlines Commission informed the Minister on 21 March 1986 of the Commission's decision that the trading name of Trans Australia Airlines should be changed to Australian Airlines. The Commission regarded this major step as an important ingredient in a series of strategies to project the airline as being aggressive, competitive and commercial. It saw this change as being a very public statement that the airline is owned by the people of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commission proposed that the name change occur in July 1986, to coincide with the arrival of the first of the new Boeing 737-300 aircraft. Expenditure to be incurred will be minimised by painting all new aircraft in the new livery, but altering others progressively. While TAA is a Commonwealth owned statutory authority, the Government has encouraged it to operate on a more commercial basis. The Government has therefore accepted the decision taken by the Commission on the basis of its commercial judgment.
