DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Messner proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Hawke Labor Government's destructive tax package which imposes enormous administrative burdens on small business and other taxpayers.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last July the Hawke Labor Government conducted its first and most disastrous National Taxation Summit. That was followed by the proposals for reform of the Australian taxation system, the so-called RATS proposals, that were put forward by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in September. Those proposals were dazzling in their presentation and offered the allure of tax cuts to the Australian people. But what is becoming increasingly clear to Australians is that those tax cuts are really built upon very flimsy foundations. We are hearing more and more from the Government now of the other side of that tax package. At last, almost nine months since the original announcements, we are starting to see legislation come through which is imposing new taxes on Australians. This comes on top of the announcements of a new assets test on pensioners and lump sum superannuation taxes and introduces a whole range of new tax measures which are designed to raise more tax from the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: First and foremost, the fringe benefits tax legislation has been introduced in the last day or so. The Opposition has been pointing out that this is a destructive measure and part of an overall destructive tax package because it seeks to destroy jobs in the Australian community. It will destroy jobs, as has already been demonstrated, in the motor vehicle industry. Even the Australian Democrats have taken flight and are raising alarm about this matter. We have heard from the trade union movement, as expressed in this place by the former South Australian Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia, Senator Foreman, that there could be upwards of 10,000 jobs lost in Australia as a result of the introduction of the fringe benefits tax. Even the Labor Premier of South Australia, Mr John Bannon, is lobbying the Federal Government heavily to try to ameliorate that problem. This comes on top of the denial of tax deductions for legitimate business expenses in the entertainment area which was legislated for last November and coupled with very onerous provisions for the substantiation of certain other expenses before tax deductions could be claimed. I would like to return to that matter a little later.

The fringe benefits tax and the other measures that have been taken are further impositions upon business and employers and are in the nature of a payroll tax. We have already seen the destructive effect of payroll tax in the States. Small businessmen, their representative organisations, farmers and others who employ people are constantly railing against the payroll taxes levied by the State governments, as they destroy people's incentive to be employed in industry. Surely the measures that have been announced by the Government are in the same category. They are just other types of payroll taxes imposed by the Federal Government rather than by the States. The destruction of investment incentive-what people might invest to create more jobs for Australians-follows automatically from that.

There is a somewhat significant threshold beyond which wages must go before the imposition of a State payroll tax. In other words, there is an exemption for a certain sized business. There is no such exemption for small business from the fringe benefits tax. We believe that that is a direct attack on small business. Certainly, it is ill-considered in terms of this Government's overall position versus the development of incentive for investment in this country.

I also look at the abolition of negative gearing for the purposes of property development. What will happen in this area is that people who may be trying to do small real estate projects on the side, so that they can build up their capital and provide for their retirement and not become a burden on the social security system, will now find themselves unable to save out of their incomes. Any excess interest that they will need to pay will be subject to taxation at the highest marginal rate upon which they earn their income. As a result the opportunity they would have had to save, to develop a capital item which would provide some income in their retirement, is lost. Not only is this poor thinking on the part of the Government but clearly it will lead to a drying up of the rental housing available in the market-place. This will automatically lead to higher rents, and this is already happening in Sydney and Melbourne. Consequently, people at the lower end of the income scale will be forced to pay higher and higher rents for properties. In turn that will put more pressure on the public housing system, which is already under strain in various States. As we can see from the statistics, since the Hawke Labor Government came to power in 1983 the number of people on waiting lists for houses to be provided by State housing commissions-this applies to the South Australian Housing Trust in my State-has gone up by about 30 per cent. This is during the whole period of the Labor Government. Yet this Government takes measures which are directly opposed to providing cheaper housing. It is trying to reduce the stock of available rental housing in the country which could be made available to low income earners.

A final point needs to be made and that is the utter stupidity of trying to examine and define such an abstract principle as negative gearing at a time when interest rates are the highest they have been for 50 years. Clearly, hardly anybody these days can enter into a real estate project and expect to be able to earn enough from it to pay the fantastically high interest rates which this Government has forced people in the community to pay. By the Government's definition today any project is automatically negatively geared.

Other matters are included in the legislation that is coming before us in dribs and drabs, nine months after it was originally announced. It is becoming increasingly clear that the measures are very burdensome and onerous for the businessmen and ordinary taxpayers who will be forced to comply with them. For instance, if a self-employed person seeks to claim his expenses for running a motor vehicle for his own business purposes, he will be forced to keep a log book in such minute detail, we are led to believe, as to be absolutely incredible. Already chartered accountants are making money out of selling log books to their clients to make it easy for them to keep proper records. The whole tax package really is an accountants and lawyers benefits Act. More and more people will be forced to use the services of such practitioners in order to keep the records they will be forced to keep under the new legislation.

In a country that strives to be modern and technologically proficient, we find, when looking at motor vehicle expenses for instance, that in order to substantiate that one has spent money on petrol or parts for one's motor vehicle, one needs to have a signed receipt for every transaction. This is in the days when the computer is striving to take us into the twenty-first century and develop our economy in a technologically proficient way. Yet we are going back to the Dark Ages by requiring people to have signed receipts. They do not mean a thing, of course; they could be signed by anybody. Clearly it is not proper evidence of expenditure.

The fringe benefits tax introduces a whole new range of similar impositions upon the business community. Employers will be required to pay tax on behalf of their employees when vehicles are provided for employees to take home. There will have to be the minutest recording processes in those individual companies so that the one dozen forms taxpayers will be required to submit each quarter to the Government, together with their cheque for the tax, can be completed. For instance, it will be necessary to keep separate records of the petrol used by each vehicle. That is just fine if there are 100 vehicles in a fleet! Just imagine the recording problems that will cause in a small business. I refer not only to those expenses but also to individual registration records, and on top of that individual mileage records for each vehicle and so on. It is absolutely inconceivable that a government living in the twentieth century and seeking to take us further into the technologically advanced age, seeks to impose such harsh and very expensive systems upon the business community. It must destroy jobs. Any cost that is imposed upon employers that leads to less investment and less job creation can mean only that in the long run there will be a further destruction of jobs.

These burdens come on top of a further major change that is now being initiated in the legislation before the Parliament in respect of negative gearing. Hidden away in the back of that legislation are some very major changes to the way in which the Government will assess taxpayers each time it issues assessments. In the present situation, generally speaking, where a taxpayer has been quite honest and has made a full, clear and true disclosure of all the material facts affecting his tax return he can expect, having received an assessment from the Commissioner of Taxation and having paid it, that he will no longer have any problems with the Tax Commissioner. But that will all change under the proposed legislation. It hands over automatically to the Tax Commissioner the right to amend assessments as he sees fit in any circumstances. So if the law changes, which may occur through legislation in the Parliament or alternatively by a decision of a court, a Board of Review or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, a new assessment can be issued years after the event so as to change the impact of taxation. If as a result of that assessment the amount of tax payable is increased, interest will be charged to the taxpayer at 14 per cent. The rub really comes when it is found that that interest is not tax deductible in any way by the taxpayer. Yet if the Commissioner makes a mistake and corrects an assessment in favour of the taxpayer and has to pay interest to him, that interest is assessable. This is totally unfair and unreasonable and it ought to be reconsidered by this Government. That is one of the reasons why I hope that the Australian Democrats will join the Opposition on this matter and refer the whole Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to investigate the area of self-assessment and to examine assessments generally and the way in which they impact upon Australians. A major change is being proposed on this matter and it will cause vast concern to Australians. It is being hidden in the back of a major Bill and Australians are not able to examine it fully. We will ensure that they can examine it via the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

I would like to refer to one other matter in respect of the administrative burden that is now occurring. Every taxpayer who lodges a return clearly has an opportunity to challenge the assessment made by the Tax Commissioner. The problem that quite often arises-we have seen it many times-is that sometimes taxpayers are in the twilight zone, if you like, in that they claim deductions which they may not know are incorrect or which through accident, misadventure or inadvertence may be incorrect. We are now being threatened not only with a change to the assessment procedure, which I have just outlined, but also with a change to the boards of appeal, which apparently are up for destruction as well. We will see vast changes to the rights of taxpayers.

I asked the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, at Question Time what he was going to do about the 94,000 outstanding cases. He gave us no indication at all as to whether or not the Government had in mind changing the system, yet we know that deputy commissioners of taxation in the various States are this very day interviewing taxpayers, trying to make settlements on various outstanding cases in order to push as many cases through the system as possible because a decision of this Government is pending which will change the whole situation from 1 July. That is something about which we know nothing, and again I hope that the Democrats are listening so that these matters can be exposed in a proper inquiry conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations into the Commissioner's administration of the tax law. There is considerable concern in the community. There is a growing groundswell of opinion amongst practitioners and certainly on the part of taxpayer representative organisations about the way in which the Commissioner is conducting his affairs at the moment. Indeed, the Government seems to be going right along with that without providing proper information to the Parliament.

On that very point I would like to make public an experience we have suffered in the last few days. We have a considerable number of amendments before us in respect of the fringe benefits tax and negative gearing adjustments, but as we understand the situation the Treasurer has refused the Opposition any briefings on those matters from departmental officers. It is outrageous that the Opposition has no access to departmental officers on some of the most complex legislation that has ever been brought before this Parliament in order to determine what will be the true impact and effects of that legislation on the people of Australia. In other words, the Government is trying to push this legislation through to ensure that it has very little coverage in the Press and is not properly exposed to the Australian people.

The other point I want to cover is this: We are now witnessing an attempt by this Government, by Senator Walsh and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to blame the Opposition in advance for the possible removal of the commitment to give tax cuts next September. This is despicable. It is quite clearly wrong, because the Government knows that, whereas it has promised total tax cuts of $4.5 billion over the next two years, it has new tax revenues of only $1.5 billion coming to it by way of the taxes it has already imposed or is about to impose. In other words, $3 billion is to be paid for out of inflation. Of course, under this Government this country has the highest rate of inflation that it has seen for many years. So the situation is that this Government is relying on inflation to pay that tax and is not relying on any tax imposed by it in other ways. In that case, if the Opposition chooses to oppose and defeat legislation which is as iniquitous as the fringe benefits tax, it is fully justified in so doing. It will not be blackmailed by this Government or anybody else. It will stand up properly on issues which are of the greatest concern to Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating as a matter of public importance raised by Senator Messner the alleged destructive tax package which has been introduced by this Government and the alleged administrative problems for small business and other taxpayers in Australia. The Opposition is just not credible on taxation. I regret to say that it destroyed its credibility last November and December by its attitude to the legislation this Government introduced to disallow tax allowances in regard to lunches. The Opposition destroyed its credibility at that time with claims of many thousands of job losses as a result of the disallowance of that tax privilege, enjoyed by very few taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner has used the word `destructive' in his matter of public importance, but the question that has to be asked by all persons in regard to this matter is: Destructive of what, destructive of whom? Is the tax package destructive of low income families? It certainly is not, when one looks at the figures. It is certainly not destructive of the average taxpayer and it is certainly not destructive of the vast majority of honest taxpayers in this country. It is the Government's intention-I support it wholeheartedly-that this package be destructive of tax avoiders, and rightly so. It is destructive of tax avoiders. Senator Messner addressed this chamber for 20 minutes but in his speech he made no reference at all to tax avoidance-not one reference in 20 minutes, in the lead speech on this matter of public importance. That is yet another reason why the Opposition has absolutely no credibility in Australia on the matter of taxation and tax reform.

The Government's tax measures constitute a package. It is a package which redistributes the tax burden throughout Australia but does not lift it overall. In that way it is consistent with the nine principles of taxation reform put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), one of which was that there should be no increase in the overall tax burden as a result of tax reform. As all these measures are a package, individual measures should not be seen in isolation. They should be seen as part of a comprehensive package of reform. Unfortunately the Opposition simply sees the individual tax measures as separate items and not part of an overall plan, an overall strategy, of tax reform in Australia. The tax package introduced by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, aims for a more equitable Australia and a more efficient Australian economy. In fact, taxation will be reduced for many Australian taxpayers as a result of this package. They will have greater disposable income; that is, more money in their pockets after taxation. They will be able to finance greater levels of expenditure from that income so that particular areas of the economy responsive to changes in incomes, such as consumer durables-cars, for example-and travel, will benefit in this way from the tax package brought down by this Government. As a result of having greater disposable income there will be greater expenditure on those items by those taxpayers who have received the tax cuts. The Liberal Party's whole attitude to tax reform in this country, its whole attitude to the Government's tax package, has completely ignored the effects of greater expenditure by some taxpayers as a result of the tax cuts they will be receiving from this Government.

Because there will be no overall lift in the tax burden in Australia as a result of this package, there should be no net effect on employment. There should be no net job losses in Australia because, as I have indicated, the overall tax burden will not rise as a result of tax reform. So it is not a destructive package when one looks at employment.

As I have indicated earlier, this Opposition's predictions about the impact of tax measures on the Australian economy simply cannot be believed. Let us look in some detail at predictions made by members of the Opposition in this place last November and December, when the Hawke Labor Government was proposing to remove the tax subsidy on business lunches. I would like to go through some of the dire predictions made by members of the Opposition on that legislation just to demonstrate to people present today and to those listening at home that this Opposition has absolutely no credibility on the effect of taxation on the Australian economy.

I refer first to Senator Messner, who led the debate this afternoon. He is a shadow Minister in the Howard Opposition, and on 3 December he predicted that the taxation measures to remove subsidies for business lunches would cost 18,400 jobs. A range of other predictions were made which demonstrate the sheer division and lack of unity in the Opposition as to policy measures. For example, Senator Boswell on 4 December, the very next day, said that 11,000 jobs would be lost as a result of the ending of the tax subsidies on business lunches. But he went further and said that by February or March 1986 there would be a massive fall in the numbers involved in the restaurant industry. What a categorical prediction. We are into May of this year and the industry seems to be flourishing.

Senator Short, who from time to time is a Liberal Party spokesman on tax measures and the economy, told the Senate that 20,000 could be out of work as a result of the disallowance of the tax subsidies on business lunches. That was yet another prediction by this raggle-taggle Opposition that cannot even get right its attitude to tax reform. There was also a statement by Senator Michael Baume, who will be taking part in this afternoon's debate. The honourable senator, who used to be an adviser to Mr Howard, the former Treasurer, said that many thousands of jobs in the Australian restaurant industry would be at risk as a result of the Government's tax package. That was yet another figure put forward by an Opposition spokesman on taxation, yet another demonstration of the lack of credibility and consistency by the Opposition on tax reform. The plum came from Mr Hodgman, a Liberal member from Tasmania, who told the House of Representatives that some 80,000 jobs could be lost in the Australian restaurant industry as a result of the Government's tax reform package.

So we have a range of five or six different estimates of the impact of one particular tax measure-just one of the measures, not the overall tax package and, with a categoric statement by one Opposition spokesman that the industry would be facing a massive fall by February and March this year.

Let us look at the facts in the restaurant industry by examining job vacancies, an objective measure of trends in the industry. The Commonwealth Employment Service has published figures relating to the restaurant and hotel industries. Despite the predictions of doom and gloom by Opposition spokespersons and conflicting claims by Opposition members, it is interesting to note that there has been a pronounced rise in the number of job vacancies in the restaurant and entertainment industries. In the quarter to December 1984, 15,996 new job vacancies were advertised in the restaurant and entertainment industries. By the quarter to December of 1985-three months after the Government's tax package was announced-a massive 20,730 jobs were advertised in the restaurant and hospitality industries. In one period of 12 months, a period in which the Government had announced a major package of tax reform, there was a 29.6 per cent increase in the number of new job vacancies advertised for those industries. That is a tremendous growth rate. It is a sign of confidence in the industry and indicates that the Government's disallowance of tax subsidies on free lunches for businessmen is not impacting hard on that industry. I am pleased that South Australia led the way during that period with a 72 per cent increase in the number of new job vacancies advertised with the Commonwealth Employment Service for work in the restaurant and hospitality industries.

These, then, are some of the claims made by Opposition spokespersons about that tax measure-clearly refuted by the facts as now on the public record. The fact is that the free lunch or tax subsidised lunch was a grossly inequitable arrangement in Australian society. While most Australian workers took their lunches to work, a very few taxpayers dined in luxury at taxpayers' expense. The figures made available by the Australian Bureau of Statistics are very clear on this matter. For example, across the board only 4.3 per cent of all Australian workers received an entertainment allowance, but 17.8 per cent in the highest income bracket-that is, over $600 a week, received such an allowance. Therefore, that allowance went disproportionately to the most well-off taxpayers in our society, who did very well at the expense of the rest of the community.

Overall, the current position in the restaurant industry, as I have demonstrated, indicates clearly that one cannot believe Opposition claims about the impact on the economy of the rest of this tax package. One cannot believe the Opposition's figures. I have indicated the range of different predictions made by Opposition spokespersons on this tax measure, and I am afraid that in regard to the rest of the tax package Opposition claims must be taken with a grain of salt, and this matter of public importance is seriously compromised as a result.

There will be significant benefits to small businesses and to other taxpayers as a result of the Government's taxation reform package. Those benefits will be available if the Opposition and the Democrats do not combine to block the Government's remaining tax Bills, thus reducing the amount of revenue available to government with which to finance the various taxation reductions we are proposing. Of course, there will be large benefits to the small businessman as a result of the tax package. For example, the top personal income tax rate in Australia will be reduced from 60c in the dollar, which was the figure when Mr Howard was Treasurer, down to 55c in the dollar in September this year under the Labor Government, and to 49c in the dollar from July next year. There are to be significant reductions in personal income tax rates. For those in the top income bracket, above $35,000 a year, there will be very large reductions in such rates which will greatly benefit small business people. The current tax rate of 46c in the dollar-a bracket in which there are many taxpayers indeed, the people earning between $19,000 and $28,000 a year-will be reduced to 43c in the dollar in September and will fall to 40c from July next year. Those are worthwhile reductions in marginal tax rates and will greatly benefit taxpayers.

The Opposition should stop criticising the Government's tax package and openly welcome these reductions. Opposition members should tell small business people that a reduction in the top marginal tax rate from 60c to 49c in the dollar is a welcome move indeed. With a top marginal tax rate of 49c, in future no taxpayer will have to pay more than half of any extra income in tax. That is a breakthrough and will be a boon to small businesses. The Liberal Party taxed small businessmen at 60c in the dollar. Labor will be taxing them at 49c in the dollar. It is important to appreciate that the tax package also lowers the bottom marginal tax rate, and I am very pleased that that is so. Under the Hawke Government the lowest income tax rate will be reduced to 24c in the dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we see it.

—That will be next year. If the Opposition does not block the Government's tax legislation, we will have the revenue with which to fund those reductions. We are waiting to learn the Opposition's position on this topic. Naturally, we are hoping that Senator Peter Baume and his colleagues will do the right thing by the taxpayer and ensure that marginal tax rates are lowered right across the board.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, under the Hawke Government the lowest marginal tax rate will be 24c in the dollar. The best the present Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, could do when he was Treasurer-we cannot forget that he was the Treasurer of Australia for five years-was 30c in the dollar. Our bottom tax rate is 24c in the dollar; Mr Howard's bottom tax rate, when he was Treasurer, was 30c in the dollar. Clearly, on that basis and judged by that criterion the Australian Labor Party is the low tax party of Australia. That makes this matter of public importance an absolute nonsense and a farce.

As a result of the Government's tax package the tax free threshold, that is, the first amount of income which is exempt from taxation, will be raised. Currently it is $4,595 a year. It will be increased to $5,100. That will bring significant benefits not only for low income taxpayers but for all Australian taxpayers. The higher tax free threshold combined with the lower personal income tax rates, which I have mentioned this afternoon, will provide very significant income tax cuts for average Australian workers. In fact, for a person on average income the tax cut as a result of those two measures will be around $6 a week. That will be on top of the $7.60 a week tax reduction which occurred from November 1984. That is a very good record by this Government-two major rounds of personal income tax cuts in approximately 2 1/2 years. Certainly, for the average Australian taxpayer this Government and this tax package have not been destructive.

A key area in the Government's tax package is the treatment of company dividends. Senator Messner has claimed that the package is destructive for small business and business generally. But this Government has ended the so-called double taxation of company dividends. That is a very big step forward. From now on there will be only one level of taxation on company income. That will occur from July next year as a result of the imputation system for company taxation which has been introduced by the Hawke Labor Government. This is a tremendous advantage for business. It took a Labor Government of Australia to end the double taxation of company dividends. It was not the Liberals or the National Party but the Labor Government which benefited business by ending the double taxation of company dividends. One of the important things that will do is to make investment in company shares and securities much more attractive to investors. It will mean that instead of industry being starved of funds and capital there will be a greater flow of funds into company shares and they will be a much more favoured investment for Australian investors.

As I have indicated, the tax package will not hit employment across the board. The tax package is consistent with the nine principles of taxation reform of the Prime Minister one of those principles being that there shall be no overall rise in tax levels. As a result there should be no overall effect on employment or destructive impact on the economy, as Senator Messner would have us believe. There certainly will be higher after tax incomes for many Australian taxpayers. They will have greater disposable incomes and will be able to undertake greater expenditures on the products of the Australian economy.

As a result of our policies the lowest income tax rate will be reduced to 24c in the dollar compared with the 30c in the dollar rate under the Liberals. The top rates of tax will be reduced from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. So clearly this Government, through its tax package, is not attacking small business. It is not hitting investment. It certainly offers a simpler, fairer and more efficient tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support this matter of public importance because, once again, the Opposition has failed to get the balance right. We agree that administrative burdens and additional costs will be imposed on business as a result of this package. We have never been happy about that aspect of the total tax package. We have criticised the Government loudly and clearly for it. We have adopted the attitude of negotiating with the Government in an attempt to lessen the more severe impacts of the package on the business sector. What has the Opposition done? It has stood flat-footed. It has said: `We oppose the tax package absolutely. There is nothing good in the tax package. We call on the Democrats also to oppose it flat-footedly'.
—Hear, hear!

—Senator, let us think for a moment about what would happen if the Democrats were to join with the Opposition and oppose this tax package flat-footedly. It would give the Government the perfect opportunity to renege on its tax cuts but, more importantly, it would give the Government the perfect opportunity to call a double dissolution and fight an election on the tax package.
—What a good idea.

—It is a magnificent idea for the Government, I suggest. Does the Opposition seriously want us to join it in opposing this tax package outright so that the Government can go to the people? Does the Opposition think that the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia are in any shape to fight a double dissolution now?
—Yes, and we would win.

—They are brave words but if one looks at the opinion polls one will find that it is a rolled gold certainty that an election now would give the Australian Labor Party control of both Houses of Parliament. There is no shadow of doubt about that. Is that what the Opposition wants? From the very beginning the Opposition adopted the weak-kneed attitude of boycotting the National Taxation Summit. It has provided no input whatsoever. It has left the entire burden of negotiating with the Government, of trying to get reforms in this tax package, to the Democrats. I believe that we have made significant advances in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the record. Before the tax package saw the light of day we negotiated with the Government on the capital gains aspect. Any reasonable Australian must admit that unless we have a capital gains tax there is no way tax avoidance can be cracked down on. Some sort of capital gains tax has to be imposed. We were at pains to make sure that the capital gains tax was in a mild and fair form. We were successful in getting the family home exempt from the tax. Taxes are levied only on the realisation of capital gains and not on notional capital gains. The capital gains tax is indexed for inflation. Losses are to be offset against capital gains. Most importantly, there is no retrospective element to the capital gains tax. All in all, if one considers the tax carefully, one will find that we have one of the mildest capital gains taxes in the Western world. If anyone were prepared to go through the arithmetic with me I would be delighted to show him the truth of that statement.

After the Government announced the details of its tax package we again negotiated with the Government. As a result of our efforts goodwill now will be allowed as a deduction for small businesses and farmers. We pushed the Government as hard as we possibly could to eliminate the quarantining of farm losses proposal from the package. We succeeded in getting the Government half-way along the road. We reduced the impact of quarantining by about half. When the Government said `we cannot go any further or else the whole tax package will be thrown out' we said `okay, we will have to leave it at that'. But we continued to pressure the Government on its unfair treatment of farmers and small business, as opposed to the fact that it was not prepared to worry about negative gearing by large, multinational corporations. I believe that pressure finally hit home. The Government has called it a day. There will now be no quarantining of farm losses-a very big victory which never would have occurred if we had adopted a flat-footed approach of blocking the whole package.

TALK.START.PARA: —And without our support.

—I have not seen too much of that support. Going through the list of concessions, the Government conceded to about 80 per cent of the things we negotiated with it. Retained earnings were a problem. They were to be taxed twice under the imputation system. That anomaly was overcome. Under the Government's original proposals employee share ownership would have been discouraged in a very large way. That has been overcome. We were successful in getting the Government to see our point of view on averaging. Small businesses would have been very severely hit if they had been taxed at the full capital gains tax rate in the year of the sale of their business. It is now to be averaged over a five-year period. So these were very substantial gains. While we are not happy with the additional burden on small business, we believe that overall, taking all things into account, it is the best package that can be negotiated in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that it is a government initiative and not an Australian Democrats initiative. We would have gone about this in an entirely different way; I will explain later the sorts of things that we would have done. But we are not the Government. The Government is elected and it has introduced this package. We are in a position where we can only amend it or block it. We will not block it; we have done our best to amend it.

Let us look at the tax cuts, which are a very big incentive to Australians. This is the first real reform of the marginal rates of taxation for many years. In September of this year $2 billion will be foregone to revenue in order to implement the cuts in the marginal rates of tax. The 48 per cent marginal rate will drop to 46 per cent and the 60 per cent rate will drop to 55 per cent. The tax cuts will cost $2 billion. The Government will fund that $2 billion-this is a very interesting point-by $800m worth of tax reform, that is, additional revenue. But $1.2 billion of that $2 billion will be financed through inflation and growth in the economy. Senator Messner very carefully did not mention the issue of growth in the economy. But I suggest that this is a vital part of the Government's proposals. If we do not get growth in the economy, the Government will be in all kinds of very deep trouble.

The further cuts in marginal rates of tax which have been promised in July 1987 amount to $4.5 billion of revenue forgone. The top rate of tax will drop to 49 per cent in July 1987. Of that $4.5 billion of revenue that the Government is forgoing, $3 billion will be financed out of growth and inflation and $1.5 billion out of additional revenue through tax reform. So the big burden for the revenue will rest on growth in the economy and inflation. Therefore, it is very important for the Government to be able to keep the economy moving at its projected rate. Will it be able to do that? The Democrats have grave reservations that the Government will be able to do it. Our fundamental criticism is of the way the Government is managing the economy overall. We are not carping about the minor points of the tax package. We are concerned about the fundamental approach to the management of the economy. On this point the Opposition is remarkably silent, and for a very good reason. It is silent because both major political parties are pursuing free market policies; they are sacrificing Australia on the altar of laissez-faire economic theory.

If we continue on this course, there is no doubt that Australia will sooner or later become bankrupt. The control of our economy is being surrendered to international financial interests. In simple terms, Australia is living beyond its means. We are in fact renting our country just as a family rents its home. If, in addition to paying the rent, a family continues to buy goods on credit and has massive time payments that it cannot afford, that family soon becomes destitute-and so too will our country unless we change the fundamental course of economic management. We have to do something about the enormous quantities of borrowed money flowing into the country and going into protecting companies such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Elders IXL from raiders. Over $3 billion has been spent on stock exchanges in that one instance alone without one iota of added productive capacity to the country.

We are whistling by the grave if we think that with a balance of payments deficit, and 30 per cent of incoming money going to pay interest commitments on money we have already borrowed, we can allow this money to flow in at its present rate purely for speculation on the stock exchange. We will very quickly face the day of reckoning. The Democrats believe that there have to be controls on money flowing into and out of the country. We believe that the Government has to direct its attentions to industries that have export potential. It has to consider all industries. Those that are assessed as having such potential is where Government funds should be directed. It should encourage those export-oriented industries, and do so quickly to earn foreign exchange.

We believe that there have to be changes to stock market regulations to stop the takeover racket. I was delighted to see in the paper this morning that at least some Government back benchers are trying to force the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to do something about it. So far he has refused to act. I just hope that they are successful because the position is desperate. Where is the Treasury's long awaited report on reform of the corporation tax legislation? I understand it will be introduced in about a week and then there will be a further committee to investigate it. But we have waited far too long and we are right now at the eleventh hour.

I do not have time to dwell on the other fundamental issues, but one fundamental of economic management that should be addressed is keeping in Australia more of the money from our superannuation savings. Fifty per cent of the money invested in the stock exchange comes from our superannuation funds. A large percentage of that superannuation money right now is being invested not in Australia but overseas. That is because the funds can get a marginally better rate of return from investing it overseas than from investing it in Australian industry. There are no regulations; it is a laissez-faire, let her rip approach; they invest in Saudi Arabia, the United Kingdom, South America or anywhere they think they will get a better return. That is the approach of the institutions at the moment. I suggest that our savings, which is what superannuation funds essentially are, should be subject to some sorts of guidelines so that at least the bulk of that money can be reinvested in the country to create jobs.

If we could stimulate our manufacturing industry and create the jobs that we need, the Government's economic problems would be solved overnight. For instance, there are now 583,000 people unemployed. Dole payments alone cost us $2.7 billion. If those people were put to work and earned the average wage of $320 a week, the Government would receive another $1.8 billion from income tax-a total of $4.5 billion just by attacking unemployment.

In conclusion, I simply say that the Government's tax package is far from perfect. It imposes additional burdens on small business in particular and business in general. But we must have tax reform. It is the first reform that we have had in 40 years. The Democrats, unlike the Opposition, are not prepared to stand flat-footed and reject the whole package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before beginning my remarks on this matter of public importance, I thank Senator Michael Baume for allowing me to swap with him on the speakers list. I have a pair and will be leaving for Sydney shortly; that is why there will be two Opposition speakers in a row after me. I thank Senator Baume for his indulgence. However, after I have spoken, perhaps neither of the next two Opposition speakers will wish to speak and the debate will conclude early.

SPEECH.PARA: Only a couple of weeks ago I heard Mick Young in the House of Representatives refer to the Opposition as `thick headed'. I thought we ought to change our attention from the head and look at the hide. When it comes to hide and the thickness of it, given the record of the Opposition during its years in government from 1975 to 1983, I find it extraordinary that even Senator Messner should use the words `imposing enormous administrative burdens on taxpayers'. He has come up with some pretty extraordinary things in the past, but this just about tops the list. This Opposition mentions imposing tax burdens in a Senate which witnessed its sad and sorry record over these years, and witnessed it run our taxation system completely into the ground. With the system being run into the ground, we had to witness average weekly earners and pay as you earn taxpayers being run into the ground with it. The Opposition showed no concern then. Now, late in the day, it rises to tell us of this sudden infusion of concern that was obviously lacking for so many years.

Let us go through some of that record. For five years of the Opposition's reign we witnessed the most blatant tax scandals in modern history-so much so that Costigan was moved to remark that as an industry tax avoidance had a rate of growth that could be compared only with the heady days of the Victorian gold rush. That is what the Opposition presided over. It ran down the taxation administration so that when we came to office there were not even enough employees in the Australian Taxation Office to deal with the scandal the Opposition had created. It failed to address the basic failings of the system. Let us not forget, as the Opposition so often attempts to do, that it broke a succession of promises on tax, one after the other, almost from the first day it got into government.

I do not have to remind honourable senators about our fantastic fistful of dollars election back in 1977. We all remember being shown that fistful of dollars, a fist crammed full of green notes, and told that if the Liberal Party of Australia was re-elected those notes would somehow find their way into the electors' pockets. The reality is that they did not, because the tax cuts that that fistful of dollars heralded were taken away as soon as the election was completed. Despite the promise to reduce the burden for ordinary taxpayers, that Government had the distinction of being the highest taxing Government in our history.

If honourable senators will bear with me for a few moments, I will produce some figures that show just what these taxing policies of the Liberal and National parties did to cripple wage and salary earners in this country. In the year 1982-83, we were seeing almost 1,000 people go out of work every day, and the activities of Malcolm Fraser and, more importantly, John Howard as the Treasurer of the day, were really biting. After seven years of their policies everything was in a nose-dive and the country was in strife. In 1982-83 46.1 per cent of total tax revenue was being paid by pay as you earn taxpayers, yet in 1975 when the coalition Government first came to office that figure was 41.7 per cent. So we witnessed a gradual rise, over every single year that John Howard presided over the economy in the amount of the tax burden shouldered by ordinary Australian families.

When we contrast that with what happened with the figures for corporations and non-pay as you earn taxpayers, the real truth emerges. In 1975-76, 24 per cent of total taxation came from non-pay as you earn taxpayers and corporations. By the time the Australian people had the good sense to throw out that Government in 1982-83, it had dropped to 18 per cent. It had dropped that low because the Opposition had presided over and encouraged tax avoidance to a degree that this nation had never seen before. Tax avoidance was the only thing that grew under that Government. Everything else in the economy collapsed. No, I am wrong. I have made a mistake-unemployment grew at a phenomenal rate, and inflation also grew, because when the Opposition left office inflation had hit 11 per cent.

Let us look at the proportion of gross domestic product paid in tax. When the Opposition came to office in 1975 it was 23.3 per cent and by 1984 it was 24.7 per cent. The reality once again was that the Opposition presided over the increase, even excluding Medicare. Contrast that enormous rise in taxation with the wording of the matter of public importance-and the Opposition has the hide to refer to the increasing burden on taxpayers! Let us look at average weekly earnings. They grew by 113 per cent during the years the Opposition was in government from 1975 to the end of 1982, but tax increases for average weekly earners rose by 122 per cent and for a person with a spouse and two children they rose by 150 per cent. Along every step of the way, the Liberal-National Party Government chose to kick ordinary Australians where it hurts.

Since this Government has been in office we have chosen exactly the opposite path. In contrast to the pathetic record of the Liberal- National Party Government, as soon as this Government came to office it instituted a vigorous campaign to close these tax loopholes. It was difficult to get all of that legislation through the Senate, and because some of it was not passed hundreds of millions of dollars in ill-gotten gains have escaped the net. Even so, this Government by its legislation on superannuation lump sums, income splitting, the abuse of unit trusts, leverage leasing, prescribed payments and sales tax avoidance-the whole gamut-was the first government in decades to do anything about it. This Government was the first to recognise that far too much of the taxation burden was being shifted to ordinary Australians and that we had to provide some sort of relief and release. So we set about invigorating our taxation administration and gave the Taxation Office major additions to its resources, as well as a massive overhaul of penalty and compliance provisions. Today we have a Taxation Office whose morale is high and which has people out there in the market-place working night and day to stop the rorts that were allowed to grow under the Liberal Party.

Our overhaul of the taxation system is the most comprehensive overhaul since the system was introduced. Let us look at some of the things the Government has done. We have closed loopholes in the area of fringe benefits. Today we have heard more on the issue of fringe benefits. As I said in a speech on a matter of public importance last week, the reality is that if we have a commitment to equity in a tax system we cannot allow a system whereby the free lunch and free car are enjoyed by the few at the expense of the many. That is what has happened. Over time the use of all these tax shelters had grown, and was growing, by the end of the Liberal Party reign by 25 per cent a year. No self-respecting government could stand by and let that continue; something had to be done. So we have closed many of these loopholes.

We have looked at capital gains. Australia struggled on for many decades as the only Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country without a capital gains tax and finally it has been introduced. The outcries and riots in the streets that we were promised just have not occurred. The reality is that in order to shift the burden away from ordinary Australian families, those are the sorts of measures the Government has to have the courage to take. The largest tax cuts in Australian history were introduced under our tax overhaul, so that the maximum rate of taxation is now 49c in the dollar. If it is the case that the Liberal-National Opposition is really about protecting its base, one wonders what it did for small businessmen when they found themselves paying the 60c taxation rate. The answer, as usual, is nothing.

While on the subject of small business, which is mentioned in the matter of public importance today, let us not forget the real threat to small business that this Liberal Opposition poses. When the crunch comes small business will never be able to withstand this crazy policy of deregulation of the labour market which is being espoused by the likes of John Howard and Neil Brown. If that comes about, what will happen is that big unions will break out with big increases and those increases will flow through to small businessmen. The very people whom the Opposition says it is trying to protect will be crushed under the weight of that burden. I wonder when we will hear what the Opposition intends to do about it. The reality is that it intends to do nothing. With this Liberal Opposition, it is all done with mirrors. The problem is that when that policy was exposed in 1981 and 1982 we had rises in average weekly earnings of 14 per cent and 17 per cent respectively. Consequently the economy went into a downward spiral, and that is what will happen again if ever we allow it. It is a crazy policy and we have to do all we can to expose it to the Australian people. After looking at the polls I might say that we do not have too big a job to do; the Australian people have already woken up.

Let us look at the burden that is allegedly being placed on small businesses. A significant proportion of small businesses do not pay fringe benefits tax, therefore, there will be no administrative burden for them. They will have absolutely no more money to pay in tax. The taxpayers likely to bear the most are the very large taxpayers, the very big companies and the corporations. They are the ones which will be hit most by this new tax. If one looks at the record, at the figures that I have just quoted, one will see the total amount that companies and corporations have paid as a percentage of total tax revenue. The facts are that this sort of policy will start to put them back where they were 10 years ago-paying their fair share. It will start to reduce the burden on ordinary Australian families, and that is what we are about.

The decision of the Government to impose a fringe benefits tax and levy the tax on the employer is obviously the most simple administrative way. It is the only way to clear the clog that occurs when we try to impose these sorts of obligations on too many people. By imposing these obligations on an individual employer rather than on a host of individual employees there is no doubt that we have a system that is harder to abuse and easier to administer; it is also cheaper to administer. No self-respecting government could have gone any other way. Given that the Government has decided to introduce a fringe benefits tax, the most sensible and the least burdensome way to do that is to do it exactly the way we have proposed.

Let us look at a capital tax on assets. The tax is on assets acquired in the future, not existing assets, because we recognise the enormous logistical problems that would have been involved in getting valuations for all the property involved. Also we do not seek to penalise people for the actions that they may have taken in the past. We have not sought to penalise them for the way in which they managed their affairs prior to the decision being taken. What we are saying is that from now on they will have to pay tax. We have made it clear what the tax is. It has been clear for a year. The whole of Australia knows what to expect. Contrast that with anybody in the public trying to find out what the Opposition's policies are, not only on taxation but on anything else. Over the last 12 months, despite repeated calls from the Government benches, but more importantly from their rather spectacular misadventures with the Business Council of Australia and with the Confederation of Australian Industry, no section of the community is able to find out just what the Opposition is about. So what we are faced with on this side of the chamber is a lot of individuals on the other side saying what they are about. The problem is that the individual voices never match, the disarray grows and the Australian people get more confused. That is why, when the next election comes, they will stick with the Government that delivers the goods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Richardson on one point. After listening to him, yes, the Australian people would be more confused. In the first place they would wonder what this matter of public importance was all about. It is a very simple proposition: That the Hawke Labor Government's destructive tax package imposes enormous administrative burdens on small businesses and other taxpayers. Senator Richardson spent a great deal of his time trying to rewrite history, saying, for example, that his is the first government to do anything about dealing with tax avoidance. That is total bunkum. He knows it is bunkum. But he enjoys rewriting history because it is a way of trying once again to confuse the Australian people. He has successfully done so for two consecutive elections, and I hope that the third will prove that one cannot fool all of the people all of the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us deal with the reality rather than the fiction. The reality is seen, by the way, in the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation for 1983, which says that in fact the previous Government brought to an end the paper schemes which were the burden of the tax avoidance industry, that that tax avoidance industry was wiped out by the previous Government's activity. An enormous amount of legislation was passed to wipe out tax avoidance under the previous Government. That tax avoidance had only developed because of some curious decisions-as the Opposition knows-by the legal system which, in general, have now been reversed, so rendering absolutely obsolete and unnecessary the great bulk of the legislation that was passed during the previous Government's period to wipe out individual tax avoidance practices. That is by the way. I just wanted to correct Senator Richardson's pretty incompetent attempt to rewrite history to the extent that the previous government was criticised for being too tough in the matter of blocking tax avoidance. In fact, on the bottom of the harbour scheme we were accused of introducing retrospective legislation of an unfair nature. The Government cannot have it both ways.

The worst element of this package is, strangely enough, not so much the package itself, which is appalling, but the disgraceful standover tactics this Government is endeavouring to apply to this chamber and, in fact, to the Parliament. The Canberra Times of 5 May states:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, warned yesterday that the tax cuts could be in jeopardy if the Government was denied substantial revenue from its tax reform package.

Following the line recently put by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, Mr Hawke said the Opposition and the Democrats must recognise that any such move `has implications for the Government in terms of capacity to deliver the tax cuts'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is blackmail.
—That is not only blackmail; it is monumentally dishonest blackmail. Of course one would expect that, when one looks at what Senator Walsh had to say in this chamber on 2 May. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let it be known if the taxation package is sabotaged by the Opposition in the Senate to the point where it is impossible to deliver the income tax cuts which the Government has promised the responsibility for that will rest fairly and squarely with members of the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats.

Let me say, for the benefit of the Senate and certainly for the benefit of those members of the Australian Labor Party who obviously are prepared to be led by the nose because they cannot think for themselves, that only $1 in every $6 of tax cuts promised for this year-I stress, only $1 in $6-will come from the fringe benefits tax. It is absolutely absurd for any member of the Labor Party, from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) down, to come into this place, as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) does, and falsely claim that they will not have the capacity to provide tax cuts when in fact only $1 in every $6 of those promised tax cuts will emerge from this fringe benefits tax.

The figures are clear. Next year, of the $2,000m promised tax cuts only $330m is to come from the fringe benefits tax. Here we have an attempt to deceive the people of Australia, an attempt to confuse this Senate, a deliberate attempt to mislead the Senate and, more significantly, an attempt to blackmail and stand over this place to try to force through some legislation which is a mixture of incompetence and savagery. It is severe in its impact on small business in particular but, as I have said, the manner in which it is being held over the Senate-like the sword of Damocles-to try to force the legislation through is to be condemned.

Of course the Australian Democrats have been dumb enough to fall for it. We heard Senator Siddons today saying: `We have to do it. After all, they won't have the revenue for their tax cuts otherwise'. Cannot Senator Siddons add up? Do not the Australian Democrats understand that the removal of $1 in every $6 can in no way justify the removal of $5 in every $6? The reality is that this Government went into the promise of a tax cut knowing full well that it did not have the capacity to meet that promise. The $6.4 billion forward estimate of the deficit for next year which has been leaked already clearly shows what sort of terrible trouble the Government is in. It seems to me that the Government's statement that the tax cut is in jeopardy if this legislation does not go through is a clear precursor to an attempt to withdraw from that promise. I would not be surprised if in fact the Government would not mind if this legislation were defeated. It would provide it with an excuse to escape from the $5 out of every $6 obligation which bears no relationship to this legislation and which it is simply using as an excuse.

It is further suggested that the Government wants to see some hostile approach to this legislation. It is further suggested by its refusal-as far as I know, it is an unprecedented refusal-to provide the Opposition with bureaucratic advice on what are the meanings and implications of some of the clauses in this legislation. To my knowledge, when we were in government, on no occasion in tax matters did we ever refuse access by the Opposition to the public servants involved. It is a disgrace, it is unprecedented,and it is an indication not only of the arrogance of this Government but also, I suggest, clearly, that it is part of a tactic of generating and reinforcing opposition to this legislation on the basis of lack of understanding.

We have already heard Senator Richardson say that there is confusion. If the Government genuinely wanted to get rid of the area of confusion it would provide the advice and assistance that we in government always provided to the Opposition, but which this Government is too arrogant and too offensive to provide to this Opposition. As I said, it is absolutely unpre- cedented. This is particularly disgraceful when it relates to legislation that in many instances has been in operation, through this package, since September last year but which is only just now seeing the light of day. Of course, in the capital gains tax area it is still to see the light of day. By the time the legislation comes through, people will have had to operate under it for the greater part of a year without knowing what on earth it is they are operating under. All they had was an outline or statement given on 19 September when this legislation was announced but not introduced. Of course, it has changed quite a bit since those original announcements. The fact that it has changed, the fact that no one knows what is in it anyway, and the fact that it need not necessarily coincide with the initial statement does not bother the strongly moral members of the Government here because they do not care about the fact that small business, in particular, has had to operate under tax laws which do not yet exist but which will bind them. This is intolerable.

We have already seen one example where the Government has been approached, because of a degree of confusion, in relation to what the deductibility entitlements for depreciation really are. That confusion will, in fact, cost people a large amount of money when they have acted in a way that they believed would fit in with the statement but which now appears not to fit in with the ultimate legislation. It is an immoral and improper procedure to operate this way, to have legislation start from a particular date but not be introduced until almost nine months later.

It is all very well for the Government to say that the Opposition did that when it was in power in relation to tax avoidance practices. That is quite right; we did. We would make a statement saying: `This particular practice gets around an existing law; in other words, it is a practice which is a dishonest and dishonourable one because it gets around a law clearly endeavouring to prohibit that practice'. What we would say was: `That practice is prohibited and we will introduce the legislation as soon as possible'. In many instances it did take a while to get that legislation through, but the fact is that those instances related to clear breaches of existing laws or the avoidance of existing laws and were not the introduction of a whole new approach-a whole new set of tax laws-called quaintly by this Government, `reform'. Whenever this Government changes anything, it is never just a change, it is a reform. It can be a reform for the worse, but it is still called a reform. This Goebbels technique of colouring one's activities with an appropriate word to give the appearance that it is something good when, in fact, in most instances this tax `reform' package has disastrous consequences for many people in business, is a hoax and a clear indication of Goebbels-type technique.

Let us have a look at the question of the impact of this legislation. On 30 April in the Sydney Morning Herald there appeared a report showing that Senator Button had again claimed that the car industry would be adversely affected by the fringe benefits tax. On top of that, of course, motor vehicle registration figures released then showed that sales in March were only three quarters of those recorded in the corresponding period last year. The important thing which that article stated is this:
Senator Button told the Senate:
``I have always felt that [the tax] would have some adverse effect, but there are a variety of factors which will adversely affect the production of motor vehicles in 1986.
``The precise effect of the fringe benefits tax on cars cannot be assessed, although added to other factors the effect is likely to be adverse.''

Here we have the Minister in charge of this industry saying that the precise effects of the fringe benefits tax on cars cannot be assessed. I can cheer him up by telling him that the industry certainly claims it can assess the impact. It says that the fringe benefits tax will mean that 30,000 fewer cars will be produced this year, costing 10,000 jobs and threatening the Government's car plan. It is an open secret that Senator Button and Mr Mick Young, two Ministers in this Government, were rolled on this matter within the Cabinet. Last night Mr John Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, made a stinging attack on this Government's lack of intelligence in this matter at a dinner at the Australian National University, which unfortunately was not reported. His attack on this Government was based not only on the fact that what it was doing was destructive of jobs and the industry but also that it did not know the consequences of its actions. This, of course, is probably one of the most disturbing elements.

Senator Walsh says that it is just scaremongering to talk in this way. Earlier today he referred to the fact that there had not been any falls in employment in the restaurant industry. His figures were deceptive and misleading. He took only the December figures from a new set of statistics and he failed to mention that some other statistics which go to February show, in fact, a fall in the number of people employed in the restaurant, hotel and club industry, and that that fall is significant because the figures he quoted clearly did not take into account in any way the seasonal factors involved in the Christmas trade in that industry. His figures also included personal services, whereas the later figures I quoted, which did not include personal services, show a fall from 230,600 in the November statistics to 229,800 in the February statistics. Senator Walsh simply was misleading this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance raised by Senator Messner on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia expressing concern that the Labor Government's destructive tax package imposes enormous administrative burdens on small business and other taxpayers. I not only wish to endorse that remark but also I wish to add a new dimension to that matter of public importance. I believe, arising from this particular tax package, that the aged, the infirm, the unemployed, small businessmen and farmers will emerge as a new underprivileged class. This is a tax package which is heavily impregnated with the Government's ideological preconceptions and it is a package which reflects an ideology of union bosses who seek to gain short term benefits for their members to the detriment of the competitiveness of Australian industry and others outside the immediate interests of the Trade union movement. I believe that such policies will further erode standards of living because they add nothing to productivity as such, but simply add costs to inputs and administrative structures and destroy both incentive and initiative across the board.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Government members across the way have said, this package is not intent on increasing taxes per se. It is interested in redistributing the tax burden. It is interested in redistributing wealth across the country. The Government is, therefore, pursuing a policy that runs counter to that adopted by all our major trading nations-all the countries around the Pacific basin area. This package is redistributing the tax burden by redistributing it to the middle income earners. It is not attacking the tall poppies as was traditionally a Labor Party exercise.

Let us look at the environment in which this tax package has been set. We should note the comments of Robin Speed of Sydney, who recently advised us that 300 years ago Daniel Defoe said that there was nothing as certain as death and taxes. Today, nothing is as uncertain as taxes, particularly under this Labor Party Administration, because never before have our tax laws been so complex and uncertain in their application. It is against this kind of complex and uncertain background that the Government is introducing a new range of income taxes-capital gains taxes, fringe benefits taxes, entertainment taxes and so on. On top of this, it is introducing a new concept of assessment called self-assessment. In theory it is fine but it will transfer the burden of uncertainty to ordinary taxpayers. This legislation has been introduced against the background of government refusal to make taxation officers available to the Opposition. This is unprecedented. When the Liberal Party was in government we always made tax officers available to Opposition committees and the shadow Minister. What has the Government to hide under these circumstances?

An important canon of taxation is the element of certainty. A new concept of uncertainty has now been introduced. If this happens, there must also be other consequential changes which I call upon the Government to implement. For example, until now the Australian Taxation Office has not given advice on the outcome of certain proposals put before it. Because of this new self-assessment system it is now up to the Government to change this philosophy. If it is to be three or four years before a taxpayer will be visited by a taxation officer to reappraise and assess a return, he needs advice from the Taxation Office on the outcome of an action. It is necessary for the Taxation office to implement and publish a taxation public information bulletin to advise taxpayers about procedures, rights and obligations consequential upon a visit by the so-called taxation auditors.

Let us consider the economic environment in which this range of new income taxes has been introduced. For example, we have a current account deficit of $1 billion a month with hardly a cent going into investment. Our foreign debt burden is approaching $80 billion. We have a high inflation rate, particularly when we compare it with that of our trading partners. In the United States of America it is 3.8 per cent, West Germany 1.3 per cent and Japan 1.8 per cent, against our rate of approximately 9.2 per cent. We have a rising level of imports and decreases in exports-in fact, they were down about $8m in March. This situation is leading to an ever-worsening balance of payments problem. The Government has adopted a so-called J curve philosophy on the basis that things might be a little difficult in the short term but there is a long road upwards to recovery. I submit that the J curve theory can be likened to a slippery slide with the Government coming down at an accelerating rate and the recovery being very short term and short lived.

We also have unacceptably high interest rates which are having a bad effect on long term investment. There is a decline of 20 per cent in rural export earnings, low prices for our commodities, reduced employment and investment opportunity, an uncompetitive manufacturing sector, unreal wage expectations and high costs to business because of indirect costs such as workers compensation. Our capacity to service our debt is becoming an increasingly great problem. Much depends on the performance of the export sector. The Government has placed too much reliance on the primary sector. The continuing neglect of the manufacturing sector is to be deplored. There has been no real effort to reduce the level of government spending. This is the problem. The Government must reduce its level of spending. It must change its level of priorities. There is a need to reduce government expenditure, to reassess the entire spending program, to cut out waste and inefficiency and the unnecessary advertising and self-promotion of Labor Party leaders to ensure that spending priorities reflect the real needs and aspirations of the community.

Unfortunately, the cost of government at all levels has increased fivefold in the last 10 years-a dramatic increase. This is the first problem that must be addressed in any realistic examination of taxation reform. For example, in 1973-74 government expenditure was 31 per cent of gross domestic product. In 1983-84 it had risen to 42 per cent, an increase in real terms of 70 per cent, far outstripping the economy, which grew at only 28 per cent. Middle income earners will foot most of the bills run up by this Government. The Government talks about tax reform redistributing the burden. Four years ago average wage earners paid 30c in the dollar in tax. They now pay 46c in the dollar. The number of people who pay this high rate of tax will increase by one million in the next few years if inflation continues at the present level.

Bracket creep has always been welcomed by Commonwealth governments because it enables them to become increasingly extravagant. This is the only way-by bracket creep or increasing the deficit-that the Government can ever hope to pay for this taxation package and provide some personal income reductions. What will be the consequences of this bracket creep in a few years? People who hope to receive a reduction in their taxation burden will soon find themselves in a very much higher bracket. Unfortunately, there is no commitment to indexing income tax scales to inflation. This would be a positive step by the Government. It has refused to do so. More and more people will be caught up in the so-called bracket creep.

Let us look at the contributions by some of the other speakers in the debate. The flaw in Senator Maguire's contribution was that he compared the Fraser Government's approach with what the Labor Party hopes to achieve in the future. The likelihood of it being able to bring forward tax cuts is very remote. If it does, that will be achieved only at the expense of higher inflation and higher Budget deficits. Senator Siddons berated the Liberal Party for not attending the National Taxation Summit. Surely he has become aware that many of the businessmen who did attend that charade now regret doing so because they are annoyed at the way they were used and abused. The Government has now found that it is impossible to squeeze any extra income tax from primary producers, whose income is less than the dole. What is it doing? The Government is imposing a capital gains tax on these people. It has found that it is impossible to squeeze any more money from the mining industry. Who is left? The manufacturing sector, the small businessman and the individual taxpayer.

Instead of treating the business community as an economic partner responsible for the generation of wealth, the Government has attacked and hammered it and squeezed it dry. What has the package done for these people? First and foremost is the tax on motor vehicles. We all acknowledge that fringe benefits must be subject to some taxation-my word we do! The fringe benefits tax proposed by the Labor Party departs from the basic principle of taxation which requires employers, rather than employees, to shoulder the burden of taxation. We do not see this anywhere else in the world apart from a proposal put forward in New Zealand. It will cause tremendous problems in the motor car industry. We have heard of predictions of a loss of up to 10,000 jobs and further losses of up to 25,000 jobs overall when we take into account the side effects. In Tasmania, industry has already suffered in the last month from a 27 per cent drop in sales. There will be an estimated cut in the production of 6-cylinder cars by something like 35,000 vehicles.

The fringe benefits tax paid by employers will impose very heavy costs on the private sector, but at the same time it will leave government undertakings virtually unscathed. It is not surprising that, under this sort of environment, the business sector is not investing at present. Even Simon Crean of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has said that business in Australia has gone on strike.

Who are some of the other people who have been disadvantaged as a result of this package? Charitable organisations will suffer. Up until now these organisations have been exempt from this tax. Families will suffer. The Australian Family Association claims that the Government's tax package will cost families $1 billion by 1988. Certain classes of pensioners will suffer. In fact a research paper of the Department of Social Security suggested that capital gains taxes associated with the assets test could disadvantage certain classes of pensioners and Senator Grimes would be well aware of that.

Other nasties in this tax package include the capital gains tax. The move to introduce a capital gains tax and to impose a foreign tax credits system can only militate against productive investment and thus reduce employment opportunities. There might be a case for a capital gains tax on short term speculative gains, but I believe that the imposition of a capital gains tax on long term, risky investments should be opposed. We are opposing these taxes on the grounds that it is unfair to impose a penalty on long term, often low return investments, such as farming.
