TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a matter of public importance introduced by Senator Messner which has just been supported by two Liberal senators. As usual the Liberal Party is leading with its chin. We have just heard two Liberal senators talk about confusion and uncertainty. They have congenital confusion. They have a fixation in time in the past and they have failed to see what has happened in Australia. Senator Watson, who has just spoken, invoked, as the Liberal Party always does, certain respectable segments of our community. For example, the matter of public importance has been brought forward in the name of concern about small business. Senator Watson spoke about other sections of our community. I point out to him that we had a Tax Summit in this country and, contrary to what he said, many Australians-wage and salary earners, small business owners, pensioners and families-all reflected at that Summit their belief that we were being ripped off by wealthy people-by people who were not paying their fair share of tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the speakers here today and the failure of the Liberal Party is that they stick to the old formulas that have been rejected by Australians. People, particularly pay as you earn taxpayers, knew that they were paying more than their fair share of tax. The Fraser-Howard Government favoured the rich and powerful people in this community, particularly the big corporations, when it was in power. Now, of course, the Liberal Party disowns them. It talks about small business. It does not mention big business now-those people to whom it is beholden-but we remember because we now know that there are 25,000 millionaires in Australia. When we look back we realise that, when the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia were in power, they listened to the voices of those 25,000 millionaires. When we came to power and we had the Tax Summit we knew that we had a crisis of confidence in the taxation system. It became a priority of this Government to turn that around, and that is what we have done.

I was shocked to hear Senator Messner today talk about the legislation as requiring a great number of accountants and lawyers to deal with when, under the previous Government, the tax avoidance industry was a growth industry. It is nit-picking of the Opposition to be introducing this matter of public importance and talking about administrative burdens-very few specific burdens have been referred to today. Members of the Opposition have referred to minor matters and ignored the total picture. Of course, that is a very Barwick-like approach that once again seems to be an old-fashioned style of dealing with things. For example, Senator Michael Baume talked about the $5 out of $6 that are not covered by a particular tax. What members of the Opposition have failed to realise is that the Australian people demand an equit- able system.

I believe that the overall conditions of small business are most important. I disagree with Senator Siddons, and I think I have to answer the points he made by giving a few simple facts about the economy at this moment. Firstly, let us look at the decline in the number of bankruptcies, because if there is one barometer for small business it is the number of bankruptcies. The facts are that in 1982-83, the final year of the Fraser-Howard Government's disastrous economic regime, there were 6,035 bankruptcies. In 1984-85 the number of bankruptcies had declined by nearly 25 per cent to 4,661. Secondly, the most important factor to small business is the inflation rate, and that is down. The constructive actions of this Government have reduced the inflation rate, both in relation to our major trading partners and in relation to the high levels experienced under the Howard years of management. In 1982-83 inflation was 11.5 per cent and in March 1986 it was 9.2 per cent. When Australia was suffering an 11.5 inflation rate under Mr Howard as Treasurer, our major trading partners had an inflation rate of 4.5 per cent; so Australia's rate was nearly 7 per cent higher. In March 1986, when our inflation rate was 9.2 per cent, our major trading partners' inflation rate was 5.4 per cent. My third point is that private demand-the most fundamentally important thing for small business-has improved spectacularly under our Government. In 1982-83 private demand was minus 2 per cent. In the last half of 1985-86 private demand was plus 3.5 per cent.

So that general situation has to be looked at in any examination of the climate of small business in this country. These are some of the startling improvements we have had under this Government and the milieu in which small business has to operate. I suppose I should add that we have the most peaceful industrial relations environment since 1969-another factor in stability. The Government has set our to restore the revenue base in this stable economic environment. Senator Watson referred to the stability of death and taxes and things of that nature, but he failed to recognise that this Government has given just that stability. The Opposition is trying to destabilise people in the community. Senator Watson referred to the family being threatened, which is a favourite cry of the Opposition, when what we are doing with these taxes is ensuring that ordinary people will be suitably recompensed. I like the word `bludging' because it is a good Australian expression to describe the people who no longer will be able to eat and drink at the expense of ordinary Australians. The Opposition said that this was all to do with administration. Senator Watson is one of the few speakers who has dealt at all with some of the administrative problems. The fringe benefit tax, which is absolutely essential, is reasonable tax. If people are to have tax advantages surely they should account for them. Does the Liberal Party want to go back to the style of the years when it was in government, when people ate and drank at the expense of the taxpayer?

What would occur if the Opposition had its way and the employee took responsibility? It is just a nonsense. First of all, if that occurred the employer would still have to do the paper work. Under the pay as you earn system the employer makes the deductions and keeps the records, so even if the Opposition's view were implemented there would be no lessening of the paper work that the employer would have to do. The other aspect of the argument which Senator Watson overlooked is the fact that the employer decides whether he will or will not offer a fringe benefit to his employee. So again the decision is up to the employer. If the administrative work of recording the details of fringe benefits is too difficult the employer can simply decide not to offer such a benefit to his employee.

Another criticism by the Opposition concerns substantiation. It seems that this is a dirty word. I make this point knowing that soon parliamentarians will have the same problem. It will be a bit inconvenient, but we have to remember that now, if we have public money, people demand that we account for it. A one-person business keeps records of cars and other matters. Unfortunately, it will have to follow certain procedures. I remember an anonymous call, which I am sure was fairly accurate, from a person who complained that three people involved in a fruit shop all drove Mercedes cars. That is the sort of thing that is said in the community, and no doubt that situation exists. Fringe benefits and a whole range of benefits have got out of hand. There has to be an attempt to get some substantiation of both what people have and the expenses that they incur. We just cannot continue to allow a system whereby people do not have to keep reasonable records. In many cases reasonable records are already kept.

I refer to some of the advantages that this Government has given to small business in particular, because one of the weaknesses of the Opposition's attack was not to refer to the measures that this Government has introduced for small business. For example, there is the foreign tax credit system. Senator Maguire referred to imputation, which will improve company arrangements. Most important of all, despite the Opposition's fear tactics, there has been the promised reduction in tax to all sections of the Australian community. Although the Small Business Council of Australia has reservations about the introduction of a capital gains tax, it has indicated that there is a desperate need to redefine the tax system. Contrary to the assertions of the Opposition, the tax package makes significant improvements to the administrative load of small business.

Senator Watson did not refer to the elimination of Division 7 tax which means that small business has been relieved of distributing 20 per cent of its income-a matter which, year after year, was raised with the Liberal-National Government by small business, and to no effect. This Government introduced a quarterly provisional tax system which will be of enormous benefit to small business and will bring people who run their own business into a system that is similar to that of other people who pay tax. The Government has placed provisional taxpayers on a similar basis to that of PAYE taxpayers. The Government will assist in the reduction of seasonal liquidity fluctuations which have seriously affected small business in the past.

Senator Watson also got very upset about self-assessment. This will lead to a massive reduction in the number of disputes. It will provide for much quicker assessments. Senator Watson seems to object to giving more power to people because finally people will have much more say and much more control. We will have many more inspectors to chase the tax avoiders that the Liberal Party seems to want to protect. We will have the inspectors chase the big fish and the people who want to take money from the system. Any honest small business person will know that the system gives him more control and allows inspectors to get the people who, at this moment, are defrauding every other taxpayer-the families, the pensioners and the very people to whom Senator Watson referred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably the only way to solve the tax problem is to introduce a whole new structure. The Government missed this opportunity at the National Taxation Summit last year. Our current tax system leaks so much that the Government spends a large proportion of our time in this place trying to plug the holes. This Government and its Liberal predecessors indulges in fiscal fiddles instead of fundamental reform. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) jumps to attention for his puppet masters-the Treasury-and introduces taxes which attack only the easy quarry, that is, the ordinary Australian. Who does the Treasury work for?

SPEECH.PARA: Transfer pricing rips $1.2 billion off the ordinary people of Australia each year while we cosset the large companies and the mineral monopolies. Those who pay the bulk of the tax are ordinary Australians-people like us. The new poor are the people with large families and single earner families. A married man supporting a wife and six children pays the same tax as a single 18-year-old and almost all of his child endowment has been withdrawn by the Hawke Government. An international corporate raider pays relatively little or no tax. The tax system leaks like a running sore and we are patching it up with band-aid upon band-aid.

The new entertainment tax is unworkable and unenforceable. It provides yet more loopholes for large corporations while taxing small exporters and small businesses which cannot afford to own their own company dining facilities. The proposed fringe benefits tax on tax exempt bodies will bear down heavily yet again on Australia's most disadvantaged people. Tax exempt bodies-that is, charities and government bodies-do not lightly provide fringe benefits as they are subject to very close public scrutiny. Councils in remote areas will now have to bear increased costs in employing professional help, as skilled, competent, energetic professionals tend to live in cities where there are much better educational and other facilities.

We need to start anew with a completely different tax base, preferably one which taxes consumption on non-renewable resources rather than work and production. The Australian Democrats have just voted for this type of system. Such a change in the tax base would completely bypass all the hotch-potch constructs of the tax avoidance industry and bring the smelly card houses tumbling down with a breath of fresh air. Because of the fringe benefits tax, charities will find similar difficulties in attracting suitable people to work in deprived areas.

While both Liberal and Labor governments give with one hand to large business, they take with the other from ordinary working people. The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1984 gave companies negative gearing benefits tax free. This group tax benefit allowed a company to offset interest paid in the purchase of a new company against the earnings of another company. This Bill was initiated by the Fraser Government and passed by the Hawke Government before I was elected to the Senate. Similarly, mining and oil exploration companies can deduct prospecting costs from income derived from any other source. Gold companies pay no tax at all, and one really has to ask why. We are prepared to give negative gearing to the Bonds, to the Holmes a Courts, to the Elliotts, to the Spalvins, to the Brierleys-to the corporate raiders for their rapacious takeovers-but not to the man in the street. The over-taxed junior public servant, the small entrepreneur, the small businessman and all the dedicated employees of small businessmen do not have a chance to get the types of benefits which come to the large multinational organisations and the corporate raiders.

The sleazy world of corporate finance treats us as fools, by exploiting deductions and through new creative accounting techniques which involve extraordinary ways of avoiding tax. The criminals and the launderers of money go scot-free while ordinary people continue to pay tax. Immediately after giving the tax concession to groups of companies the Hawke Government hit at ordinary people who were investing for their retirement by building accommodation for others and so helping to keep down the cost of rental housing. They can no longer claim the interest costs of such investment. It cannot be offset against other earnings, but the corporate raiders continue to get negative gearing advantages since the passage of that Bill in 1984.

Senator Messner spent a lot of time talking about the capital gains tax in its present form. I believe that it is an irrelevant tax because of the concessions obtained from the Government by the Australian Democrats during the initial negotiations. It will raise only $25m in five years time. At the same time, the people of Australia are being charged a massive $1.2 billion in hidden taxes, through the massive distortion which is caused through devaluation and the substantial inflation which in fact goes unnoticed and is cutting out the progressiveness in the current tax system. Even with the mooted tax cuts this will occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Labor Party be satisfied with its current capital gains tax, or is it just one foot in the door?

—I believe that the Labor Party will not be satisfied with its current capital gains tax, but I believe that by the time any great change is made to the level of capital gains tax the taxation system will have collapsed completely.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has distorted the consumer price index. It is no longer the same as it was when the whole of this process of observing the economy using the CPI was set up. The Fraser Government removed Medibank payments and thus a large part of health costs from the CPI. The distortion in relation to which Government charges go into the CPI has meant that it is now a meaningless index. It is a massive confidence trick to make ordinary people feel they are well off and to keep down wages while raising taxes, because some of these taxes and government charges are not taken into account. We have, unfortunately, the situation of a blind opposition letting a one-eyed government have a free rein.

No tax measures can be popular with people who are taxed. However, some government measures are acceptable on the grounds of equity. But the thrust of this package disadvantages ordinary Australians while benefiting the large corporate raiders and multinational companies. This is an amazing situation when this package is being introduced by a Labor government that says it represents ordinary Australians. Every Australian must ask who the Government is working for, who Treasury is working for, and try to examine what we should do in a taxation package to produce a fair way of raising revenue for running this country.

This very brief statement on the formation of a subsidiary company of Telecom Australia, to be called Telecom Australia (International) Ltd, is most welcome. At last we are looking at expanding the trade opportunities which our research and development in telecommunications can open up. For some time Australian personnel have worked on the setting up of microwave links in Indonesia, under the Colombo Plan. They have performed their task splendidly. They have shown their competence in all topographical environments and have turned their mastery of problems caused by geographical variations in Australia into a benefit for this country.

The Indonesian telecommunications operator, Perushahaan Umum Telekomunikasi, or Perumtel for short, is about to upgrade a lot of its infrastructure in this area. The objects of that company focus on the provision of program management consultancy services to Perumtel in Indonesia. These objects can always be broadened if Telecom's contacts with authorities in South East Asia and the Middle East lead to further overseas opportunities. This is really exciting.

This development shows that we are starting to look beyond our own shores in this area. Our research and development has been of outstanding quality, particularly in the burgeoning telecommunications area. However, we have fallen down in terms of market development. But for all this to happen, some inbred attitudes have to give way to dynamic thought. In last year's Estimates committee proceedings, Telecom saw itself basically as a modifier or adapter of overseas work. That constitutes a tragic waste of the magnificent resourcefulness of Telecom's own research and development laboratories at Clayton, which I recently visited. It stifles our prospects of entering growth areas in technology and improving our job opportunities within Australia. However, the recent opening of the technical liaison office of Telecom heralds some hope for the future. I believe that it is important for the whole of Telecom research to be geared to an export market. Our market is 2 per cent of the world's market. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Dolphins and Whales in Captivity

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Georges:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, `Dolphins and whales in captivity', is one of the worst reports we have ever had before this chamber. I am very surprised that somebody like Senator Georges could chair a committee that produced such a report, because he has produced some excellent reports in the past. The report on HMAS Tobruk, for example, was a classic.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two problems with this report. The first relates to the recommendations, and secondly the longer term and wider implications of the report, which very greatly devalues the currency of the debate on animal husbandry. The report lacks objectivity and scholarship and is written in emotional terms. To see an example of the lack of objectivity, I invite members of the Senate to turn to chapter 6, which deals with the subject of the welfare of animals. A clear bias is demonstrated in the material between page 61 and the end of that chapter. I quote paragraph 6.1:
Critics of oceanaria contend that the mental and physical welfare of cetacea suffers in captivity because their environment is so different.
Paragraph 6.2 states:
Some criticism of cetacean welfare centres on observations of the animal in the two different situations. Dr Sidney Holt believes that:
One has only to see animals in the wild in comparison with the appearance of those that have been for any time in captivity to see vast differences in condition and behaviour.

This lack of objectivity is very real. I have spent a large part of my life reading scientific papers and writing a few of them myself. This report deals with an important subject, but lacks the standard of scholarship that is required for a report of this nature. It would never get past the editorial committee or the board of referees on any respectable scientific journal. The report is quite emotional, and there is no place for emotion when dealing with a scientific topic. Emotion and reason are mutually exclusive. Emotion is linked with the belief that the animal concerned, the dolphin, has a very high IQ which the report almost puts at the level of human intelligence. Paragraph 1.11 on page 3 of the report states:
There has also been much debate about the nature of cetacea. Available evidence points to the probability that cetacea have complex social behaviours and are highly intelligent.
Then in paragraph 8.7 on page 95 we see the following passage:

The Committee is of the opinion that evidence points to the probability that cetacea are highly intelligent animals with complex social behaviour. As the scientific community has not yet reached a full understanding of the nature of the animal, the Committee believes that it is important to give the animal the benefit in considerations on its future in captivity, especially where captivity has been shown to be mainly for the purposes of entertainment in Australian oceanaria.

I suspect that the Committee got confused between complex social behaviour of an animal and the size of its brain and came up with the conclusion that, because it could be taught tricks, it was highly intelligent.

Complex social behaviour is a property possessed by ants and bees, and their colonies demonstrate a highly involved, organised social pattern, but nobody would suggest that ants or bees were highly intelligent. Because the dolphin has a large brain that is no indication of a high IQ. The size of the cranial cavity cannot be equated with intelligence. There is no scientific opinion in zoological literature which supports the contention that the dolphin is a highly intelligent animal. Indeed, the Nobel laureate Professor Crick puts forward the theory in respect of echidnas and dolphins, both of which have large cranial cavities, that the size of their cranial cavities is not to be attributed to intellectual capability, but to their sleep patterns and their metabolic activities. It is certainly a highly responsive animal; it can learn routines which the oceanaria develop. But is there anyone in the Senate who really believes that a dolphin can be ranked in intelligence ahead of domestic animals such as cats, dogs or horses? I do not think that allegation can be sustained. Clearly, compared with the primates, it does not measure up in the animal kingdom. That argument is not tenable, yet it is the theme behind the whole report. It is the stuff of comic books and science fiction. Let me turn to the recommendations. The committee recommends:

. . . that no further facilities for keeping captive cetacea be permitted to be established in Australia and that no further permits be issued for the capture of cetacea in Australian Commonwealth or State waters. It further recommends that importation of cetacea from overseas be banned.
The report also states:
The Committee also recommends that existing oceanaria be allowed to continue keeping cetacea for the time being but that the keeping of cetacea should eventually be phased out.

Together, those recommendations mean that we will not be able to do any marine research at all in Australia. A great deal is to be learned from research with respect to the physiology of animals, parasitology and so on. Many factors about marine life can be learned only by keeping animals in captivity and studying them. Recommendation 8.12 requires that those institutions that have dolphins shall embark on research and educational roles. One cannot enforce a research capability on an unwilling organisation. Either the organisation has the will and the ability to do it, or it does not. If it does not have that capability and is in a purely commercial sphere, it cannot be asked to become a research body.

Paragraph 8.13 refers to the abolition of any form of tricks being taught to dolphins kept in oceanaria, but no evidence is advanced as to why that should be done. Paragraph 8.15 recommends the drawing up of national standards for oceanaria, and we have no objection to that. In considering that recommendation I compliment the marine biologists in Australia and overseas on the very great strides they have made over the last 10 or 15 years in keeping animals in captivity. Paragraph 8.16 deals with a system of licensing for oceanaria. That may be just putting more bureaucracy into the system. Paragraph 8.21 recommends that all dolphins ultimately be returned to the wild.

As I said in the introduction to my speech, this is a very poor report. In fact, is is quite a silly report. It lacks scholarship. It is utterly devoid of any scientific content. It does not conform with the very high standards we have come to expect from Senate committee reports. I believe that it is quite damaging to marine research in Australia and to the academic world in general. Insofar as it demeans the whole debate on animal welfare and animal husbandry in Australia it is a most unwelcome addition to Senate reports.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Registrar of Cooperative Societies Annual Report 1983-84

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations I present a report on the Australian Capital Territory Registrar of Co-operative Societies annual report for 1983-84.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Australian Capital Territory Registrar of Co-operative Societies annual report for 1983-84 was not tabled until some 14 months after the end of the financial year the subject of the report. The Committee investigated the reasons for the delay and the Registrar's explanations are incorporated in the report that I have just tabled. In the course of our investigation we discovered that the general provision in section 34C of the Acts Interpretation Act, which requires the tabling of annual reports within six months, does not apply to statutory authorities set up by ordinances under section 12 of the Seat of Government Act. In our report we therefore recommend that the Government introduce amendments to the Australian Capital Territory Interpretation Ordinance to embody in that ordinance the same provisions as in section 34C of the Acts Interpretation Act. I urge the Government to act on this recommendation with some urgency so that Australian Capital Territory authorities do not continue to be treated differently in their accountability to Parliament as compared with other Commonwealth authorities. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As part of the general responsibility of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to monitor the activities and accountability of statutory authorities, we seek reasons for delays in the tabling of annual reports and for qualification of accounts. The two reports I have just tabled are examples of such investigations. The Committee usually receives good co-operation from Ministers and authorities when information is sought. However, I have to report that an unreasonable lack of response has resulted from my request for information from the Australian Capital Territory Parole Board.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Capital Territory Parole Board annual report for 1983-84 has not yet been tabled. I repeat, in case anyone is incredulous, that I am talking about the 1983-84 report. It is now 22 months after the end of the relevant period. On 18 October last year, when the report was 15 months overdue, I wrote to the Chairman of the Parole Board seeking an explanation on behalf of the Parliament, to which the Board has some responsibility. Six to seven months later, no reply has been forthcoming-not even a formal acknowledgment. The Committee Secretary has been in telephone contact with the Secretary of the Board several times to remind the Board about the matter and to emphasise the need for a response. We have been told only that my letter is being considered by the Parole Board Chairman. The Finance and Government Operations Committee believes that this situation is so deplorable that it decided I should make this statement to draw the Senate's attention to this aspect of the Board's performance.

I will send a copy of this statement to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) as the responsible Minister and to the Chairman of the Board, and will implore them to ensure an early response to the Finance and Government Operations Committee in our attempt to do our duty. I further hope that the still outstanding report will appear soon. I acknowledge, as I did in the statement I made on the report of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies, that there is not a legal obligation on Australian Capital Territory authorities to report within a six-month deadline, as we had thought, but in this case the delay is totally unreasonable. It is of crucial importance that annual reports be tabled promptly so that the information in them is of more than historical value.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1985-86[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1985-86APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1985-86]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch, when I was speaking to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1985-86 and cognate Bills in respect of the Department of Defence, I said that I was opposed to the purchase of the HMS Invincible some years ago, not because it was a carrier but because it was a vertical or VSTOL carrier and it embarked the Sea Harrier which was quite inadequate as a fighter aircraft. Since that time, of course, the Americans have taken the Sea Harrier in hand and have made the AV8B by putting a new wing on it and cleaning up the aerodynamics. They have made a decent aeroplane out of it, but it is still only a strike aircraft; it is not a fighter aircraft in any sense at all. The simple solution for the Royal Australian Navy in providing air power at sea is for the Australian Government to approach the Americans to get one of their conventional smaller carriers out of the reserve fleet and for us to embark FA18s. At the end of the day we must have a navy and we cannot have a navy without air power. It must have air cover at sea if it is to survive. It is absolutely important for us to be able to work through the whole of the South Pacific, the Indian Ocean and the archipelagic regions to the north of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the Army, unfortunately it has no role under the Australian Labor Party. It has two very crippling disabilities: It lacks mobility and fire power. I am pleased that the Government has moved to buy some new helicopters, but those helicopters have only a minor tactical role to play. They do not have the logistic ability to move large numbers of troops around this big continent. Even if we had a lot more helicopters, soldiers cannot fight from a helicopter; they have to get out, and when the soldiers get out they cannot fight wearing only a green shirt. This does not matter to the Labor Party because it has a grand doctrine of sinking ships as they are invading Australia with submarines or bombing the harbours, so we do not need an Army. Life is not like that and life will never be like that.

When soldiers get out of the helicopters in the battlefield they need armour and the only thing we have to support them is the antique M113 armoured personnel carriers. The M113 APC is a first generation weapons system. It is 30 years old, totally inadequate and dangerous on the battlefield because with the smallest calibre arms available today, the light calibre ammunition, if it is hardened, will go right through them. The previous Government started the Waler program to develop an Australian APC that met modern conditions. This Government cancelled it, ignoring the experience of the Americans and the Germans with the Mander and the Bradley of building a new generation APC, because the present Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has a belief that the Australian Army has to go everywhere into action by air, flying in Ansett Airlines of Australia or Trans Australian Airlines DC9s.

I turn to the Royal Australian Air Force. As an old airman I am very supportive of air power, but I am the first to recognise that it has limitations, that it is an inflexible weapon and it is also of a very transient nature. We cannot hold ground with an air force. I read in the Weekend Magazine of the Australian of 29-30 March that at a recent dinner party the Minister said:
Australia possesses the capability to cripple the Soviet forces at Cam Ranh Bay by deployment of our F111s with accurate fast bombing and our submarine fleet which would torpedo Soviet ships.

That statement was never retracted or corrected, so I presume that Mr Beazley said it. That is some of the most dangerous, hallucinating nonsense I have ever heard. It is the same as the claim that Singapore was impregnable, that generations of previous Australians were fed.

In summary, I am speaking about this because no debate on defence or foreign affairs has ever been initiated by this Government since it came into power. The Senate is the home of foreign affairs and defence. The importance accorded this subject and the understanding of it by the Labor Government is demonstrated by the fact that it has never brought up the subject in the three years that it has been in government. The only time the subject has been brought up is when some of my colleagues or I have spoken on it or raised it as a matter of public importance. The isolationist, non-aligned, fortress Australia policies, with their associated myths of no threats, long lead time and self-sufficiency, have been allowed to run unchecked. The consequences of that are the Australian defence forces are being constructed and moved in a way which will deny any future government the necessary range of options.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Later in this debate the Opposition will move an amendment in relation to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3). At this stage I foreshadow what the major amendment will be. It is that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) draws attention to the failure of the Government to fulfil its promises-
(i) to reduce interest rates,
(ii) to bring the rate of inflation down below 5 per cent,
(iii) to hold taxation as a percentage of gross domestic product down at least to the level of the 1984-85 financial year,
(iv) not to introduce a capital gains tax,
(v) not to raise the interest rate ceiling on housing loans, and
(vi) to bring about sustained reductions in unemployment, particularly youth unemployment.
Of course, all those promises have been shattered. The amendment further states that the Senate:

(b) notes the deterioration in the Australian economy as indicated by the continuing balance of payments crisis, an inflation rate twice that of our trading partners, excessively high interest rates, rising unemployment lagging private investment in new productive capacity and the severe downturn in the housing and motor industries; and

(c) calls on the Government to arrest the alarming deterioration in the balance of payments and the threat of a further fall in the value of the Australian dollar and severe hardship for Australian families by taking urgent steps to-
(i) introduce a mini-budget in May to reduce Government expenditures, to take effect from the beginning of the 1986-87 financial year-
which is in a little over a month-
and thereby reduce government borrowing,

(ii) make an application to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to defer the productivity wage case and to discount fully the indexation of wages for the effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar,
(iii) withdraw the anti-business and anti-rural elements of the tax package of 19 September 1985, which has the effect of inhibiting investment and depressing economic activity, and
(iv) significantly relax foreign investment controls to encourage job-creating equity investment in Australia.

That not only is clear criticism of what the Government has done but also is a clear prescription for resolving the problems. It seems to me to be important that the Senate and the people of Australia should recognise just how we have gone wrong and how we can fix it up. Let us look at the first of the Government's failures; the failure to reduce interest rates. The Government, because it does not have an effective fiscal policy, or any economic policy other than the prices and incomes accord, has had to rely on a policy of deliberate record high interest rates. The Government's advisers have been recommending against this for months. I remember last November the Secretary of the Treasury made a very significant speech in Perth, saying that if this continued for too long the Government's economic recovery would be destroyed, as would the employment levels and the objectives that the Government claims it has. Yet that policy has persisted.

We have also seen recently a major dispute that has developed between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Reserve Bank of Australia over the outlook for inflation and this whole question of high interest rates. This dispute between this major adviser of the Government, the Reserve Bank, and the Treasurer clearly raises serious doubts about the manner in which the Government is handling the economic problems we face and certainly raises serious doubts about the validity of what passes for the Government's economic policy. This particular dispute is significant in that the Reserve Bank has given a warning. I quote from the Reserve Bank bulletin of April, which states:
Australia's relative performance on inflation appears likely to worsen in the coming year.

That warning is in total conflict with the Treasurer's repeated assurances that Australia's inflation rate has peaked and will now improve. We heard these assurances when we raised in the Senate and in the other place our concerns about this enormous increase in inflation to 9.2 per cent in the past 12 months. This was more than a doubling of the rate that existed in the previous 12 months. This was at a time when the rest of the world's inflation had been going down.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was negative in many countries.

—As Senator Messner says, in many other nations of the world it is negative. The assertion by the Reserve Bank-and I support it because I think the Bank is totally right-is in conflict with the Treasurer's claims that there is no need for concern that Australia's inflation rate is now 2.4 times the OECD average-that is the average of the developed nations of the world-because Australia's inflation rate could not be related to those of other countries due to our devaluation. There are a couple of points to make about that claim. Firstly, the OECD average is artificially inflated by countries such as New Zealand and some other chaotic economies which have very high inflation rates. The inflation rates we should be looking at are much lower than the OECD average, because those we do most trade with these days, such as the United States and Britain, and so on, have an inflation rate far below the OECD average, and as Senator Messner said, some of those countries have negative inflation rates.

SPEECH.PARA: But the Treasurer has said: `No, we cannot even relate our inflation rate to the OECD average because we have had a devaluation'. The simple reality is that the Statistician has put out statistics to indicate what the devaluation impact has been on Australia's inflation rate of 9.2 per cent. In fact, since the beginning of last year our inflation rate has gone up to something like 10.5 per cent, but about 2.5 per cent of it clearly relates to the impact of devaluation. So we still have 7 to 8 per cent of that inflation rate being due to local consequences-due, in large part, to the result of the Government's economic policies.

Even if we take into account that devaluation, Australia's inflation rate is still just about double that which is expected for the OECD this year. The Reserve Bank's present concern over Australia's worsening relative inflation rate follows, as I was saying, very many months of repeated warnings from the Governor of the Reserve Bank and the Secretary to the Treasury over the consequences of the Government's continuing to rely on this high interest rate policy as the only way of managing the economy. The excessive use of this high interest rate monetary policy has resulted directly from the Government's continued refusal to take effective measures against rising government spending, for example, and, of course, rising labour costs, which are increasing mainly because of the Government's policy on wage indexation and on productivity claims. The Governor of the Reserve Bank warned only last week that `large current account deficits may be with us for some time' and that as a result `monetary policy may be called on to play a greater role than I consider to be desirable'. He added that the overall stance for economic policy would have to be tightened if the expected improvement in the current account was further delayed.

Within the polite language of the bureaucracy, and certainly within the polite language of the Reserve Bank, which does not like to appear to be in conflict with the Treasurer, the fact that the Governor of the Reserve Bank would say that `monetary policy may be called on to play a greater role than I consider to be desirable' is very severe criticism of the Government's current economic policy. It seems to me disappointing that the Reserve Bank's comments that Australia's relative performance on inflation appears likely to worsen in the coming year-which is a matter of immense significance and a matter of concern to me-should have received so little attention in the media. Apart from the Australian Financial Review mentioning it in passing in two articles, this very significant rejection of the attitude, of the statements, of the Treasurer, this severe criticism of the Government's economic policy, has received very little media attention, although it has been raised by the Opposition in the other place. But as is typical, unfortunately, matters of serious moment like this do not receive media attention at a time when the media seems to be obsessed with matters which may be more sensational but are of far less significance to the good government of Australia and the consequences of that good government for the welfare of the people. It disappoints me, as an ex-financial journalist, as a former finance editor with the Bulletin for example, and also having been investment editor of the Australian Financial Review, that the present crop of journalists who are reporting this place did not find it sufficiently important to let the people of Australia know about this major conflict particularly in respect of the significance of Australia's worsening inflation rate. As I said, I exempt the Financial Review from that comment because the Financial Review this week wrote an excellent editorial on this matter. It states:

When the latest inflation figures were released, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, tried to reassure us that the worst was now over. The fall in oil prices would result in an annual inflation rate of only 8 per cent, he stressed.
That is compared to the 9.2 per cent that we have had in the latest quarter. The editorial goes on:

However, he did not tell us that the oil price fall would have a greater effect on other economies rather than ours. It will only reduce our annual inflation rate by between a half and 1 per cent over coming quarters. Yet its effect on inflation rates in other countries is expected to be considerably higher.

What really matters and what will always matter in an environment of floating exchange rates is our relative unit labour costs and inflation rates, not the fact that we might have achieved a lower rate of increase in either.

That raises the next question-labour costs. Once we have indexation, we then clearly have a direct relationship between our inflation rate and what our labour costs are going to do. The Financial Review once again makes the very sound point that the government has been misleading us about this matter of labour costs. It states:
The last three years have seen a moderation in labour cost increases but those who ascribe this purely to the existence of the magical accord--
I inserted the word `magical' there, I must admit-
obscure two issues. The first is the fact that labour shedding in manufacturing would have produced a moderation in union demands, with or without the accord.

The second is that although increases in our unit labour costs have moderated since 1983, they have still run well ahead of those experienced by other major economies. Indeed, they are now accelerating in relative terms.

It is these relative terms, which the Treasurer does not like to use but which the Financial Review and the Governor of the Reserve Bank like to use, and which I think most responsible Australian commentators like to use, that indicate that we are continually getting worse, and will continue to get worse. As the Australian Financial Review states:
We get excited because we have slowed our increases down. But in the United States, Japan and West Germany nominal unit labour costs have actually fallen.
So, as a result:
Not surprisingly, the gap between our inflation rate and that of the other major economies is also widening rapidly.
The article goes on:

While our unit labour costs are likely to increase by about 6.5 per cent this calendar year, unless the Arbitration Commission is hit with a thunderbolt of commonsense, those in the seven major industrial countries are expected to rise at an average rate of only 2.5 per cent.
We will be increasing our labour costs almost three times as fast as those of our major industrial rivals. The article continues:
In these circumstances, sizable devaluations of the $A have been the only way in which we have been able to maintain a semblance of competitiveness.

In that context it is depressing to note that, at the AISEC Australia forecast for the Australian economy conference held last week, Professor Tom Valentine of the Macquarie University quite sensibly argued:
The dollar is likely to fall 5 per cent a year against the US dollar over the next decade . . .
The main reason is Australia's high inflation rate, which is 4 per cent higher than its major trading partners, the United States and Japan.
A report of his comments goes on:
``If this adjustment is put off for a long time, it will occur over a short period as it did in February last year,'' Professor Valentine said.

High interest rates were being used to keep the dollar at a level higher than its true value mainly because of the Government's faith in the J-curve theory. Any further depreciation would put pressure on the wages Accord.
Professor Valentine said it was unlikely that the Government would continue to use high interest rates to support the dollar because they were slowing economic growth.
``This outcome is indicated by the slowing down of retail sales, the problems being experienced by the housing and retail industries,'' he said.
``Continued use of tight monetary policy could push the economy into recession.''
``The only fully satisfactory answer to these problems is to attack them at their source-the wage-fixation process.''

That is exactly why the Opposition's policy on industrial relations is so important. That policy, of course, is to be released over the weekend. I am certain it will be one of the major elements in the policies that will bring the Opposition parties into power. There is no doubt when we look at what has happened--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you see the polls today?

—Indeed, the polls already indicate a great degree of concern by the man and woman in the street about the consequences of the policies this Government has maintained. There is no doubt that the Government appears to have got away with it. It is very difficult for people to recognise the direct consequences on them and on our nation of the policies the Government has introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I do not want the people of Australia to suffer as a result of these foolish policies the Government has maintained and is maintaining and to which so many commentators have pointed and the Opposition has pointed for a long time. But the fact is that unless people do suffer from these policies, they do not recognise their serious nature. I am afraid that suffering is soon to take place. Already, of course, those people in the motor industry are suffering from not only the specific anti-business policies relating to tax but also the impact of devaluation which has massively increased the costs of imported motor cars and the costs of components of motor vehicles made in Australia. There is no doubt that this magical J curve is not working. We all know what Senator Button has to say about that. We also know that some recent statistics demonstrate one of the major problems about the J curve.

I have here the export price index, which is one indication of why devaluation will not be getting us out of trouble. The export price index, one would expect, would have benefited substantially from the 25 per cent fall in the value of the Australian dollar. In other words, the exports we sell would naturally be worth more in Australian dollars, even though they were worth the same amount in whatever currency we sell them for because, in fact, the Australian dollar is worth less as a result of devaluation. That 25 per cent increase that should have taken place since the beginning of last year has turned out to be only a 6 per cent increase for all groups in the export price index. That is a disaster. It means that people who export have, in effect, received an increase in their prices in Australian dollar terms of only 6 per cent, even though the value of the Australian dollar has fallen 25 per cent. That means that, while our costs of all imports have gone up by something like 25 per cent as a result of this devaluation, the benefits we get from our exports are up only 6 per cent-a disastrous relationship.

More significant than that is the fact that in recent months there has been a significant fall. For example, from June of last year we have had something like a 3 1/2 per cent fall in the value of the export price index. That trend is even more serious in items such as crude materials, inedibles and so on, which are down 9 per cent. Mineral fuels are down 3 per cent since December last year and, of course, that group will suffer an enormous fall as a result of the fall in the oil price. Agricultural products-a disastrous result-have fallen 9.5 per cent since June last year in the export price index. Manufacturing is down about 8 per cent and mining is down about 4 per cent in the export price index.

We have a serious problem. The J curve is not going to work, on the one hand, because our export prices will not be adequate and, on the other hand, because so many of the nations in the world to whom we export have imposed limits, bans and prohibitions on our products in order to satisfy their domestic problems. We have this problem, and Mr Hawke went overseas to seek earnestly and energetically to improve our trading relationships. The week he came back we found the Americans dumping grain in Yemen. We hope that Mr Hawke does not go overseas, because we keep on getting bad news whenever he comes back. We find that further markets have been closed to us.

That is only part of the story. The other part of the story is what happens with imports. Theo- retically, when there is a devaluation, there should be a fall in imports. The Government kept talking about the J curve, how imports would fall and Australian products would fill that gap, how everything would be marvellous and how, to repeat what Mr Keating said, devaluation would be good for Australia because it would solve our problems. That shows what Mr Keating knows. As Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, has repeated, the J curve is bunk; it does not work. The reality is that devaluation has basically tended to increase the costs in Australia. It has been a factor in our increased inflation rate because the Government appeared to forget that the great bulk of Australian imports go into items that are produced in Australia. They are factors of production. They are used in making other things. They are machine tools and equipment. The Government apparently forgot this. This means that the price of goods made in Australia is increased as a result of the devaluation.

We have a devaluation which has resulted in only a minimal increase in nominal terms, in terms of the export price index-the price that exporters get-which is falling now. The trend is against us and at the same time our local costs are rising as a result of devaluation, which increases the cost of all imports that go into things that are made here and increases inflation. As a result of increasing inflation, it increases wages. As a result of wages increasing, our competitiveness decreases and as a result we lose all the benefits of the devaluation which have cost us so dearly.

In the amendment we will move later we call on the Government to arrest the alarming deterioration in the balance of payments and the threat of a further fall in the value of the Australian dollar and severe hardships to Australian families. The Government, of course, will not do what we are asking, for a very simple reason. It will not introduce a mini-Budget this month simply because there is going to be an Australian Labor Party biannual conference next month, when naturally all the factions will be fighting with the Government about whether or not there should be a reduction in government spending. There is no way the Government will come out with a statement before the biannual convention because, as we all know, the Left and the Centre Left have the numbers over the Hawke right wing faction in the Labor Party. That biannual convention would simply not wear the sorts of things that have to be done in the coming Budget. As the result of a leak, we have already heard that the prospective deficit for next year, about which Senator Walsh keeps talking, will be $6.4 billion. That is appalling, and because of that Government Ministers have been directed by the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to cut $1.4 billion off expenditure. We have heard all that because it was leaked, presumably by the people who want the cutting to be done.

The reality is that the spending Ministers involved do not want this. Senator Gietzelt, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, has said in this chamber that he will not cut his Department's expenditure because it cannot be cut. According to the leak, his Department was listed for a cut of $100m. He stoutly refused to agree to that. Ministers in the other place have said that there is no way they will accept the sorts of cuts that are involved. Yet if we do not have these cuts in government spending more and more money will be needed, more and more money will be dragged from the economy, and we will have bigger and bigger deficits. This Government is perpetuating policies which will cause greater and greater inflation an even worse balance of payments problem, and increasing labour costs because of the problems under the accord.

If this Government were sincere and had the stomach to face up to its constituents at the biannual conference, it would not be concerned about the politics of the matter, which it clearly is at the moment, and would introduce a May mini-Budget. Let us look at the consequences of its failure to make these cuts of $1.4m, and to make them now, so that they can operate from the beginning of this financial year. Even if these cuts go ahead, as no doubt the Treasurer hopes they will, they will not do so until after the Budget, towards the end of August. That means that if the Government is to cut the same amount of money over the whole year the cuts will have to be more severe than is already required. It is obvious that the Government has to do that, but it is unfortunate that because of the Government's fear of its supporters it will not do what it knows that it has to do. As a result, even more severe cuts in spending will be introduced which will have a tendency to be disruptive and will cause distress simply because the Government does not have the stomach to act now as it should.

There is no doubt that the Government should also make an application to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to defer the productivity wage case and to discount fully the indexation of wages to allow for the effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar. We devalued our dollar because we were living beyond our means as a nation. The Government accepted that point in the last Budget when the Treasurer said he would agree that wages should be discounted because we should not reward people for living beyond their means and going into debt. That is simply what the devaluation meant. The Treasurer agreed at that time, but the Australian Council of Trade Unions had sufficient effect on this Government, as it always seems to have had, to force the Treasurer to change his mind, with the result that there is only partial discounting of wages in the current round, at least in the Government's view, to be totally offset by a $2,000m tax cut in September. I have already mentioned today that it is appalling that the Government seeks to blackmail this place into passing these fringe benefit taxes that are before us by saying that otherwise it will not have the money to grant the tax cuts when we all know that the fringe benefit tax will provide only $1 in every $6 of the tax cuts to come. Obviously, that blackmail is stupid apart from being offensive.

We have a clear case, in the Australian Financial Review most commentators are pointing it out, that the Government's economic policies are causing the problems that are now before us, generating a situation in which inevitably we will have a worse inflation rate and worse interest rates, that the balance of payments will remain heavily in deficit, and where, as Professor Valentine said, the Australian dollar will inevitably decline by about 5 per cent a year against the United States dollar over the next decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the occasion presented by the second reading debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) to discuss some issues raised by the tabling last week of volume 1 of the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions and by the questions relating to the Age tapes which were raised by that report. It is my understanding that volume 1 of the report was tabled but volume 2 was not tabled because it has been sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions and the material in that second volume may be germane to matters that the Director of Public Prosecutions will consider which may lead to charges being laid and to prosecutions. The issues raised by the Age tapes and their handling are issues that go to the probity of government, the probity of the police-particularly in my State of New South Wales-and the probity of the judiciary. There can be no more important issues than these for a community. It is suitable that we take this opportunity to review some of the matters which the tabling of volume 1 of the report raise and to review some of the history of the Age tapes and their reception.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Justice Stewart and his Royal Commission have authenticated the Age tapes. It is timely to review the systematic attempts made before the authentication to denigrate the tapes and particularly the attempts to denigrate the authenticity of the tapes. The Royal Commission was the culmination of a series of investigations into organised crime and drug trafficking which began probably in 1981 with the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking which investigated the activities of Terrence John Clark, better know as Mr Asia, and the Mr Asia syndicate. This and succeeding royal commissions looked into the activities of organised crime, including the Nugan Hand Bank, as far back as the 1970s.

The original Stewart Royal Commission when looking into the activities of Terrence John Clark also examined the activities of Robert Trimbole, who was active in the Clark organisation until late 1979. During those investigations the Royal Commission received evidence that Trimbole had been tipped off by police about the Royal Commission, causing him to flee overseas. This led to the Commission requesting from the New South Wales Police all the material it had on the activities and disappearance of Robert Trimbole. This in turn led to material about Trimbole being published in the National Times and in the Age newspaper. This in turn led to the disclosure piece by piece of the existence of certain tapes of conversations between people, some of whom were associated with the criminal underworld. This led to both the Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales Labor Government launching investigations into the origins and authenticity of the tapes. These investigations into the Age tapes came about only because of the demands by the Opposition and the free Press that such investigations take place. These investigations came about in the face of continued and determined resistance by the Hawke Government and the Wran Government in New South Wales. Those governments not only dragged their feet but also obstructed these investigations in every way.

I am really understating the facts. Those Labor governments vigorously resisted any inquiry at all into the tapes, just as they have resisted over the years a series of calls for a number of inquiries into matters associated with corruption and crime, particularly in New South Wales, which we want to see brought to life. Eventually, because of the nature of the material that continued to emerge, the leaks and the public outcries absolutely forced the two Labor governments to undertake some investigations.

—We are sensitive, are we not? The Federal Government appointed Mr Temby as Special Prosecutor and the New South Wales Government had its Solicitor-General, Ms Mary Gaudron, investigate the origins and the authenticity of the Age tapes. After publication of further material in various newspapers, the Age tapes were investigated and referred to the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge and the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge. Eventually those tapes were investigated again by the original Stewart Royal Commission. Some tapes were available and some material was in transcript form. What is the Stewart Royal Commission's latest conclusion about the tapes? Let us take its conclusion first. I quote the words of the Stewart Royal Commission:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission accepts that the material appearing in verbatim form as a transcript of a telephone conversation has an acceptable degree of accuracy and probably fairly records that part of the conversation it purports to record.

The Stewart Royal Commission has concluded that, where the material related to a verbatim account of a telephone conversation, it could be accepted as a reliable and fair record of that part of the conversation. Given this conclusion by Mr Justice Stewart, we should recall, once again, the desperate attempts by now discredited Labor Party politicians and by now discredited Labor Party governments and their political appointees to denigrate the Age tapes and to claim that they were either worthless or inaccurate and that they could not be relied upon. There is no difficulty at all in identifying the leader of the gang who has attacked the Age tapes. That person, of course, is the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Neville Wran-the leader of a very tired and discredited government which is lurching through its last year in office. He is the man who fought every attempt to investigate corruption. He is the man who resisted every call for an investigation every time a new allegation was made; for example, the allegation against Mr Farquhar, allegations against Mr Humphreys and allegations against people who have now been shown to have been engaged in criminal activity. This was Mr Wran. When one of his Ministers was included, he asserted time and again that the allegations were automatically false and that he would have no part of investigations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before you go on, Senator Baume, you understand that it is against Standing Orders to impute improper motives to a State politician. You must confine yourself to factual evidence with no imputation of motive.

—Mr Deputy President, I will try to confine myself to facts. The Premier of New South Wales had to be dragged screaming to set up inquiries. I have Press statements which confirm that he is a person who spent a lot of time casting aspersions and smears on those who brought forward the material, those who were brave enough to publish the tapes and those who raised genuine complaints and concerns about organised crime and corruption in New South Wales-crime and corruption which was running rampant and about which nothing was being done. Right from the start he tried to discredit the Age tapes. What are some of the things Mr Wran said? Mr Deputy Speaker, I will try not to discredit him or to impute improper motives; I will quote his words. What has he said about the Age tapes? He said on one occasion:

SPEECH.PARA: They are variously described `the Age' tapes or the New South Wales Police tapes. They are neither. Indeed they are not even tapes.

I might add just for those who may not realise it that they had to be published in the Age newspaper because no one in New South Wales was brave enough to publish them even though they related to events in New South Wales. We know today that, because of the publication of those tapes, a series of events has been set in train, a series of prosecutions has occurred and a series of further prosecutions is likely to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Mackay murder had to be proceeded against in Victoria.
—The murder of Donald Mackay had to be proceeded against in Victoria. We know that Mr Wran said:

SPEECH.PARA: They are variously described `the Age' tapes or the NSW police tapes. They are neither.
What else did Mr Wran say? On another occasion he said:

The tapes are tapes of tapes of tapes, illegally obtained, edited, juggled, juxtaposed, transposed, illegally transcribed, falsified in their transcription, illegally divulged, illegally published, wilfully distorted in their publication, maliciously interpreted in their presentation . . .

But what did Mr Justice Stewart say? He said that, where they recorded verbatim conversations they did so fairly. Who are we to believe? Are we to believe Mr Wran, that they were `wilfully distorted' or `maliciously interpreted', or are we to believe Mr Justice Stewart? On other occasions Mr Wran had declared the New South Wales police tapes to be `getting a bit mouldy'. He had denied that the Stewart Royal Commission had made a finding authenticating the police tapes. What do we find now that that finding has been tabled? They have been authenticated all right. Not only do they exist but also they can be relied on where they record verbatim conversations. Mr Wran suggested that there was `the very big question' of whether the New South Wales Police had secretly or illegally made the tapes. Now we know why. The late Mr Landa, the former New South Wales Attorney-General, told the New South Wales Parliament in August 1984 that the Crown Solicitor and the Solicitor-General had told him that further investigations into allegations of wrong-doing in the Cessna-Milner drug case in 1979 would be futile in the absence of the authentication of the telephone material. Of course, we have the authentication now, but in fact a Dennis Shanahan commented:
The absence of authentication of the tapes was the Government's bulwark against consistent cries for investigation into the matters raised on the tapes.

This is an important point. The New South Wales Government continued to refuse to investigate or to involve itself in the content of the tapes, reserving for its defence its view that the tapes were not authentic or that they were inaccurate. We now have Mr Justice Stewart telling us that, where they record verbatim conversations, they can be taken to have an acceptable degree of accuracy and probably record fairly that part of the conversation they purport to record. This claim by the late Attorney-General, Mr Landa, was all part of a massive effort to discredit the tapes because they exposed corruption associated with the New South Wales Labor Government and associated peripherally with the Labor Party in New South Wales. His New South Wales political cronies, his political colleagues, joined the push and the chorus. Particularly prominent was the person who had been appointed to the position of New South Wales Solicitor-General, Mary Gaudron. She produced a report that called into question the authenticity of the tapes. She said that without full technical assessment she could not rule out the possibility that the tapes had been edited or patched. But Mr Justice Stewart has said that he now has no doubt that the tapes do have an acceptable degree of accuracy and that they do fairly record that part of the conversations they purport to record. Mary Gaudron also suggested-here she drew a very long bow-that any disclosure of the material contained on the tapes, even in parliament, could constitute an offence under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and also that the material could not be referred to in any special commission of inquiry or any similar judicial inquiry.

Senator Gareth Evans, then Federal Attorney-General, led the campaign in the Senate to try to discredit the veracity of the Age tapes, to cast doubts upon their authenticity. Senator Evans, in defending his New South Wales colleague on one occasion, said:
I simply make the point that there is, on the evidence now available to the Government, reason to question very seriously the authenticity even of the electronic tapes themselves.

The tapes have been tested and they have now been judged to be authentic. If they had not been published, how much worse off would the public be? How much less information would it have about organised crime in New South Wales? What an attempt was made by a Labor government in New South Wales and a Labor government in Canberra to denounce the people who had had the courage to publish this material and to make sure that the public knew some of the things that were going on in the cesspit that is New South Wales and New South Wales politics today! Senator Evans further stated:
My reaction now is really one of unadulterated anger at the way in which stuff as flimsy as that has been used . . .
That was another attempt to suggest that the material was unimportant or flimsy. Senator Evans continued:

I cannot emphasise too strongly the dubious status of the material. The tapes and transcripts given to me are clearly not original. The locations of the original tapes and transcripts are not known to the Government. Who took the copies from which the Age copies were derived is unknown completely to us. The material is therefore completely anonymous and completely unauthenticated.

That is a fair enough statement. I simply say to Senator Evans, through you, Mr Deputy President: We can now say that Senator Evans's questions have been answered, certainly adequately. If the defence of the Labor Party has been that it wants to ignore the material contained in the tapes because it doubts their authenticity, that is no longer an excuse available to it whether or not it was valid in the past. Senator Evans said finally:

We simply have no means and are unlikely in the future to have any means of being sure that we have a full, untampered-with, reliable account of the conversations that appear to have been intercepted.

I could go on and on, but the fact is that Mr Justice Stewart has also answered that question for Senator Evans. We can now say with certainty that we have good grounds, on the basis of the Royal Commissioner's findings, for believing the verbatim transcripts of telephone conversations contained on those tapes. Of course, what is needed now is for the two governments, which have resisted for so long and so hard, to get to work and start to investigate with energy and dispatch the matters which have been raised on these tapes.

My cousin Senator Michael Baume referred a moment ago to the case of Donald Mackay. Not only was he a Liberal candidate for parliament, he was a personal friend of mine. When I was engaged in my first Senate election campaign, we went to Griffith and the Mackay children baby-sat my children while Donald Mackay and I were campaigning. Honourable senators will remember that Donald Mackay was also an anti-drug campaigner who was murdered. Just a few weeks ago his children faced up the Premier of New South Wales to ask some questions concerning the unconscionable delays in dealing with matters associated with their father's death. Instead of getting sympathy and concern from the Premier of the State, they got a round of abuse. I must hand it to young Paul Mackay, who said: `Well, we just let him talk it out, and we were able to cope with that kind of thing'.

Mr Justice Stewart and the National Crime Authority have exposed the fact that there is no longer any merit in suggesting that the tapes or conversations are not authentic, for they are. I believe that the Government of New South Wales has been badly damaged by the whole attitude that it has taken towards the Age tapes. The Labor Commonwealth Government and the former Attorney-General, Senator Evans, have been badly damaged by their slowness and reluctance to examine the matters contained in the tapes, depending, as they did for so long, on the fact that they wished to question the authenticity of the tapes.

In New South Wales it does not matter all that much. People already have a perception of the Premier which will not change very much by this latest disclosure. But why has Labor generally engaged in a desperate cover-up and delay over the tapes? The only people who can benefit from delay in investigating organised crime are the criminals themselves. The delay and the cover-up has helped the drug pushers, the drug dealers, the mob, the Mafia, the Saffrons and the Trimboles, and it has helped undermine the values that a civilised society should attempt to uphold. The governments that have dragged their feet have played their part in making it more difficult in my State of New South Wales for the honest policeman to make his voice heard and for those who wish to clean up the State to get something done. The reason is that from many of the tapes, many of the stories and many of the events that have occurred over the last few years, the threads lead back again and again to the New South Wales Labor Party machine and to the corrupting influence it has had upon that Party and New South Wales.

I recall setting out for the Senate the story of the Baldwin bashing, of the Balmain welding company, of the Labor Leichhardt Council, and of the Royal Commission's findings that the people associated with those events were probably criminals, of Wings Travel. We have had Murray Farquhar, Kevin Humphreys, and a series of events. At present we have a Minister of that Government who is awaiting his day in court on probably the most serious charges that a State Minister has ever faced. Time and again, the threads lead back to the Labor Party in New South Wales. Each time that allegations have been raised about one of these matters, those who have raised them have been abused and ridiculed and the Labor Government has done all that it can to avoid investigating serious matters.

I remind honourable senators that when my friend and colleague John Dowd was Leader of my Parliamentary Party in New South Wales, he raised again and again the question of corruption in New South Wales and the reluctance of the Wran Government to act on matter after matter which he brought before the public and the Parliament of New South Wales. The Press at that stage went with the Premier and helped ridicule John Dowd. Today, matter after matter which John Dowd raised, and matter after matter about which he was ridiculed, has been shown to have substance, and he has been shown to have been right not once but in relation to most of the matters he raised and brought to the attention of the public of New South Wales.

I do not know what will flow from the consideration of volume 2 of the Stewart Royal Commission. I do not know all the matters which are contained in volume 2. I read the newspapers, like anyone else, and am aware of several matters that are of current concern. I hope that if prosecutions are to be laid, they will be laid expeditiously. I say to the Government that, if in the course of those prosecutions they lead back once more to the Australian Labor Party, to its branches or to its members, it should not shrink from laying charges against whoever might be involved. I hope that when the Director of Public Prosecutions has finished his job, has laid the charges he wishes to lay and has made what use he wishes to make of this confidential material, and once the cases which arise from that are out of the way, volume 2 will be made public so that those of us who live in New South Wales and who have to endure the state of corrupt politics that passes for government in that State will have a chance to examine further the matters Mr Justice Stewart has reported on and to determine then, as citizens, what further steps we may wish to take.

This is an even more serious matter than just for the persons concerned. If the Dibb report that we await recommends a more self-reliant Australia, I wonder who the Government intends to defend us.
