SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian Government has already contributed to the program on a two-for-one basis, and this should be the basis of the continuation of the program. Could it be that political rather than heritage considerations have prevailed? The Government seems to have plenty of money for one off projects like the Grand Prix and the America's Cup. By comparison, the Port Arthur project is one of major moment for the nation. Its importance is not restricted to its heritage implications, great though they are. The Port Arthur project has brought together experts in architecture, engineering, archaeology, history and conservation and their work is not yet finished. The work done to date has been the most complex historic conservation exercise yet undertaken in Australia. Its progress has attracted national and international attention. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some brief remarks about the situation that exists between Australia and Indonesia and the role played in this matter by the Sydney Morning Herald. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said last week:

SPEECH.PARA: The originating factor in this situation has been an article in the Sydney Morning Herald over which we, as a Government, not only have no control but no knowledge.

I agree. The issue that intrigues me, however, is the timing of the article. Let me explain. On 9, 10 and 11 April the fourth Indonesian-Australian Conference was held in Jakarta. The Australia delegation included members from both sides of this Parliament, senior officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs from both Canberra and Jakarta, representatives of Australian business, academics, trade unions and, most importantly, representatives of the Australian media, representing some media outlets that are currently refused access to Indonesia.

As the conference was held under Chatham House rules, I am constrained in what I can say. I will not name the participants as it would not be fair to them. However, one would not have to be a genius to realise that Australian-Indonesian relations were discussed both formally and informally during the conference and that the role of the media was an item of great interest. In the middle of the proceedings on 10 April the Sydney Morning Herald article was published. I therefore ask: Was it done deliberately or not? I find it hard to believe that the editor and/or the foreign editor of the Sydney Morning Herald did not know that the conference was taking place and what the repercussions would be. The Sydney Morning Herald might have thought that the story was of such interest it had to be printed as soon as possible. However, as nearly all the hard facts in the article had been in print in Australia previously, I find that very hard to believe. In fact, the article was described to me by a senior journalist in Australia as a scissors and paste job.

Having said that, I believe that the Indonesians have been guilty of over-reaction and double standards in their handling of this issue. There has been no action by Indonesia against the United States, despite much stronger recent Press criticisms of the Indonesian Government by the Washington Post and the New York Times than any that occurred in the Sydney Morning Herald. These articles in the United States papers appeared late in April and as yet there has been no reaction by the Indonesians. I believe that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was correct when he said that it was a paradox that Jakarta criticised the Australian Government for articles about the Suharto regime in a free, uncontrolled Press yet used its own media, an official army newspaper which is directly under the control of the army and senior members of the administration, to attack Australia. There are other examples of over-reaction which I do not have time to deal with now but which I will certainly deal with at some time in the future.

This Government, the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) have all gone to great lengths to improve our relations with Indonesia, as has our Ambassador in Jakarta, Bill Morrison. I find it appalling that apparently the relationship is so fragile that one newspaper article can totally disrupt three years good work, especially as the semi-official magazine Indonesia, available at the time of the conference, carried articles on the excellent relationship that existed between the two countries, including an article by Dr Mochtar, the Indonesian Foreign Minister, and photos of our Foreign Minister Hayden and Minister for Education, Senator Susan Ryan, during their recent visits to Jakarta.

Having said that, I believe that the Sydney Morning Herald must have known that the initial reaction to the article was going to be hostile and that printing it when the conference was in session would have meant that any chances of future media access to Indonesia were going to be jeopardised. I am not saying that the article should not have been printed, just that the timing was disastrous. In the final wash-up it has probably given a boost to Australian relations with the United States as the `Comment' column in the Australian Financial Review states today. In conclusion, I believe that if the timing of the Sydney Morning Herald article was not deliberate, it was a bungle. I will certainly be interested in perusing future Sydney Morning Herald articles and editorials on Australian-Indonesian relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the same subject, Australian-Indonesian relations. I was also a member of the delegation which attended the last Australian-Indonesian conference in Jakarta, together with Senator Sibraa. I regret to say that, although I have great respect for Senator Sibraa, on this occasion I think that much of what he said tonight was somewhat unfair. The Sydney Morning Herald published an article which, it seems to me, was newsworthy. It is not surprising that comparisons were being drawn between the Indonesian situation and the situation in the Philippines subsequent to the Philippine elections. That has been shown by the fact that similar articles have now been published elsewhere in the world. I have no evidence to suggest that the article was deliberately timed, in effect, detrimentally to affect Australia's relations because it was published at the time the conference to which I referred took place, nor to believe that it was timed to have the unfortunate response which it did-the cancellation by Dr Habibie of his proposed visit to Australia. Unfortunately, I feel that articles such as that will never be published at the right time. I suppose it is a bit like politicians increasing their salaries. There will never be a right time. Looking back with hindsight, a criticism of that nature is somewhat unfair.

SPEECH.PARA: I also think that Senator Sibraa has it wrong. Although the article may have caused the immediate response it did in relation to Dr Habibie, much of the deterioration of relations since then has occurred for other reasons which I very much attribute to the attitude of Prime Minister Hawke and his Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) since the unfortunate event relating to the Australians who arrived in Bali to find that visas were required. Let me expand this matter briefly because it is important. Under Liberal-National Party governments, Australia had an outstanding reputation in the international arena as a country which had always been sensitive to the realities of international politics and the players in the international fora. Yet, in the last few weeks since the visa incident, unfortunately the current Australian Government has driven Australia's foreign relations with our neighbour Indonesia into a most difficult and detrimental position. Unfortunately the Government has gone out of its way in the last two weeks to further the breakdown of Australian-Indonesian relations by simply dismissing Indonesia's reaction as a capricious response by an over-politically sensitive Third World country, without considering the repercussions it would have for Australia.

Let me remind the Senate of a little of the history of this matter. The Government was clearly disappointed by the Indonesian reaction to the Sydney Morning Herald article-the cancellation of Dr Habibie's visit to which I have referred-because it had no control over the contents of the article or the fact that it was published. That is fair enough up to a point. In the last couple of years, I am happy to concede, the Government has been active in fostering a good relationship. But the Government balanced the Indonesian response against those efforts, which have been made only over the last few years. In other words, it balanced the response against short-term efforts, forgetting the damage that the Australian Labor Party has done to our relations with Indonesia over a long period. It may well be that the Indonesians would look at the changed attitude of the Australian Government in a longer term context. Nevertheless, the Government was disappointed. It was then enraged when Indonesia precipitately changed its policies with respect to visas and, as I mentioned, caused a planeload of Australians to be stranded. I suggest that was both clumsy and offensive. It aroused anger within Australia and the Government. That is not surprising. It clearly called for a strong protest.

I suggest to the Senate that it was then that Prime Minister Hawke let his political perceptions of the value in responding to the domestic anger override what was in Australia's long term best interests and which culminated last Sunday in his offensive expression that Australia `would not grovel to Indonesia'. What an uncouth, limited and embarrassing way in which to conduct international relations! No sooner has the visa debacle come to light than the policy was changed, it is said by President Suharto himself. If ever there was a sign of wanting to end the derailing of relations that has occurred over the previous couple of weeks, I suggest that that was it. But Messrs Hayden and Hawke could not read the signs, or refused to read the signs. The Rambo factor, as it has been referred to in some of the media reports, had taken over. I suggest that rationality had suffered as a consequence. As honourable senators will recall, it was from Rome, when Mr Hawke was on his last trip, and after Indonesia has reinstated its no visa policy, that Mr Hawke still described the behaviour of Indonesia as capricious, even though the journalists gave him a chance to withdraw that description. We saw such headlines as: `Gloves are off'. Mr Hawke had decided that it was time to be tough.

What did the Australian Government do in response to the next, and what I readily concede was an unsatisfactory development, which was the refusal of Indonesia to grant visas to the two Australian Broadcasting Corporation reporters to cover President Reagan's visit to Bali? It hauled in an Indonesian diplomat in the middle of the night to give him a lecture. I suggest that that sort of behaviour may be expected in some places in the world but not, I hope, in Australia. As well as Mr Hawke responding to what he obviously saw as domestic community anger over the visas issue, I have no doubt that his hard line was also necessary to pacify internal Party critics already angry at the change of policy that he had made in relation to East Timor. We find that that was reinforced only yesterday at the Caucus meeting. We read in this morning's Press that not only did Caucus members suggest to Mr Hawke that perhaps it was time to change the East Timor policy back to that which existed before but also Caucus members commended Mr Hawke on his get tough approach and for the way that he handled the interview last Sunday to which I have referred.

A belligerent attitude towards Indonesia also would clearly be helpful for the forthcoming ALP national conference. If that is the way in which this Prime Minister is conducting foreign policy for this nation-if that is the way in which the ALP is governing this country-I suggest that it is most unsatisfactory. I suggest that, if that is the case, it is a damning indictment of this Labor Government.

What did Prime Minister Hawke then do after last Sunday's embarrassment? He would have had a chance to set about to repair the damage, but no, the answer that he gave was simply that the relationship with Indonesia had been overstated. I quote from Hansard what he said in answer to a question on Monday:

I was trying to indicate that in some quarters in Australia an absolute pre-eminence had been given to the relationship but, more importantly, that there was a feeling that perhaps more could be obtained from the relationship than the realities of our differing cultures and differing experiences would intrinsically allow to be extracted.

Who then has overstated this relationship? We remember that it was Prime Minister Hawke who went to Jakarta after the 1983 election, although I accept that it was in the face of considerable criticism from within his Party. It was Prime Minister Hawke who supported the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) going to Indonesia, only a short time later, to give the Indonesians a rundown on the still confidential Dibb report on Australia's defence needs, which privilege is more than has been given to this Parliament, I might add.

So who made the error? Who overstated the relationship such that it was necessary to give the Indonesians confidential information that the Australian Parliament has not even been given? Does Mr Hawke now say that he was in error or, as the relationship under his leadership has deteriorated so seriously, is he now saying that the relationship does not really matter, which allows him to get off the hook for his failures of the last fortnight; or does he by his statement on Monday wish to state that all the conciliatory gestures made towards Indonesia since 1983 were simply political expedient measures rather than genuine moves by a government pursuing a reasonable foreign policy which would benefit this country? It is open to interpretation. Whichever is the correct explanation, it is a serious indictment on a Prime Minister who in this issue has not served us well.

It is not surprising that he is getting the wrong advice from the Foreign Minister on this matter. We would be well entitled to question Mr Hayden's judgment in analysing the needs of the region, particularly after his less than sensitive handling of Vietnam's occupation of Kampuchea. Honourable senators will recall that he was successful in alienating the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations and it has taken great efforts by Australia's diplomats to mend that relationship since Mr Hayden's interference.

It is necessary to get it straight, even if Mr Hawke is not prepared to say so. Good relations with Indonesia are vitally important for Australia. It is our nearest neighbour, with 165 million people. It is a leader of ASEAN and a leader within the region. It is obvious that it would be naive to suggest otherwise. In the case of Mr Hawke, is it politically opportunistic to suggest otherwise?

If I had time, which I do not have, there are many important areas of that relationship that I could enumerate. The area of defence co-operation is obviously important for the information that we can get from Indonesia as to regional stability. One must also consider the importance of Indonesia in regional stability. In the area of joint exploration, honourable senators may know that the formalities for the joint exploration zone in the Timor Gap were near completion before this deterioration of relations and the talks have now been put off. That is a prospective area rich in oil and gas. Now the talks have been put off, which in no way can be to Australia's benefit. In the area of trade, although the trade figures have been disappointing, we know the opportunities that exist for the future if only a bit more imagination were shown, as was mentioned in a number of very worthwhile papers at the Australian-Indonesian conference to which I referred earlier.

The hurdle that we will come across from time to time is clearly that there are different value systems in our two countries. Obviously, we must not modify our democracy, which is vital to us-freedom of the Press is an important part of the democratic principles that we hold dear-but we must recognise that Indonesia has different values. It is much more concerned about communal interest rather than individual interest. Respect for leadership and a reluctance to criticise leadership is part of that different cultural value system. Of course, that system is very different from Australia's. Obviously, on occasions, these value systems will clash. Human rights abuses in Indonesia will clash with our standards. Press criticism in Australia of Indonesian leadership will offend Indonesian standards. We must understand that. That does not mean that the Press must not publish but rather that in doing so it must be sensitive of the Indonesian value system. Above all, I suggest that we must work at what we have in common that can build a bridge between our two cultures.

I have spoken in the past of expanding and advancing the people contact areas. Obviously, tourism is an area of people contact but, regrettably, nearly all of our tourists to Indonesia go only to Bali. It would be in our mutual interests if we could get them out of Bali and into other areas of Indonesia, and also get more Indonesian tourists into Australia. I mention the areas of cultural exchange and language training. It is pleasing that language opportunities in Indonesia and Australia are continually improving. Obviously, trade and aid projects are people contact areas that can help to bridge the cultural gap between our two countries. It can be done, but it will take time. It is a difficult enough challenge without having to overcome the errors of judgment of this Government.

I cannot work out for certain whether Prime Minister Hawke simply has been short-sighted or there is developing within this Government a deliberate isolationist attitude. There is some evidence to support the latter view-the withdrawal from Butterworth and the Sinai, and what we read about the Dibb report and its isolationist approach-but I hope that is not the case. In any event, in either of those cases, it would not be in Australia's best interests. Let us stop blaming the Sydney Morning Herald for what has happened; it is what has happened since the publication of that article that should be requiring our much more valued attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to briefly raise two matters for the consideration of the Senate. The first matter was brought to my attention by a constituent and relates to the fact that this constituent, who has been teaching at the University of Tasmania for some 12 years in a very senior position, requires a hearing aid which is absolutely essential to the discharge of his duties. Section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act provides that all losses and outgoings incurred in gaining or producing assessable income are deductible. One would expect, as a lay person, that where one has to have a particular medical appliance-for example, if one were a quadriplegic using a wheelchair, or in this case where a senior lecturer with a severe hearing disability must use a hearing aid-the expense incurred in gaining such an aid would fall within section 51 (1). But the taxation authorities have consistently ruled that this particular type of appliance is merely obtained in order to overcome an unfortunate disability suffered by the taxpayer, even though there is no argument that the real purpose of obtaining the medical aid, amongst other things, is that a large proportion of the time for which the aid is used is spent in gaining assessable income or carrying on some sort of business.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that there is a case for the taxation authorities to review their interpret- ation of section 51 (1) or for the Government, if it is satisfied that the interpretation is legally correct, to undertake a review. At the moment, the expense is allowed as a concessional expenditure rebate, but unless a taxpayer's concessional expenditure exceeds $2,000 in any year, the fact that $900 has been spent on a particularly sensitive hearing aid will not entitle the taxpayer to a concessional rebate. It seems to me that there is a case for the review of this matter, particularly where it can be demonstrated quite honestly that the purchase of a particular medical aid or appliance is necessary for the taxpayer to continue in the work force earning income or conducting some sort of business.

The second matter I raise refers to a report of the National Film and Sound Archive's advisory committee entitled `Time in Our Hands'. Page 111 of that very valuable document notes that the location of the Archive in Canberra, whilst it has certain promotional advantages, nevertheless does not deal with the simple fact that there is a demand for the sorts of services and materials which the Film and Sound Archive has in its possession and that they should be available to the many citizens of Australia, right around the country. A very clear case is made out in the advisory committee's report for maintaining officers throughout Australia so that they may develop liaison with local and State organisations which are endeavouring to preserve our sound and film heritage.

Reading that report reminded me of the fact that in Tasmania Mrs Gwen D'Emden has done a tremendous job in establishing the Sound Preservation Association of Tasmania. Mrs D'Emden called on my office some week or two ago in order to bring to my attention the fact that this organisation has undertaken a tremendous job in preserving old wirelesses, gramophones, record cylinders, theatre programs and sheet music which incorporate so much of our heritage of true historical value. If the Government, in its Budget considerations, were minded to take up the advice of the advisory committee to establish outposts of the National Film and Sound Archive throughout the Commonwealth, I believe that the Sound Preservation Association of Tasmania would be a very able and willing partner in the project of preserving our heritage, which is not always thought of when people throw away old records, mantle wirelesses, gramophones and so on, some of which not only incorporate records of stage and screen but also, in an informal way, cover many of the gatherings in market-places, people singing in the streets, children at play, and the various other indications of our history.

I am tempted to send a cheerio to my Aunty May, but we are not on the air so I think it is about time we all went home.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

Nurse education and training in Australia has traditionally been an area of State responsibility; the Commonwealth has offered for educational and health reasons, to assist those States which wish to implement a transfer to advanced education.
